<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 3</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>PART I</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 1.&#160; BUSINESS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Eastman Kodak Company (the Company or
Kodak) is the world&#146;s foremost imaging innovator, providing leading
products and services to the photographic, graphic communications and healthcare
markets.&#160; With sales of $14.3 billion in 2005, the Company is committed to
a digitally oriented growth strategy focused on helping people better use
meaningful images and information in their life and work.&#160; Consumers use
Kodak&#146;s system of digital and traditional image capture products and
services to take, print, store and share their pictures anytime, anywhere; businesses
effectively communicate with customers worldwide using Kodak solutions for
prepress, conventional and digital printing and document imaging; creative
professionals rely on Kodak technology to uniquely tell their story through
moving or still images; and leading healthcare organizations rely on
Kodak&#146;s innovative products, services and customized workflow solutions to
help improve patient care and maximize efficiency and information sharing within
and across their enterprises.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>REPORTABLE SEGMENTS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of and for the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company reported financial information for three reportable segments (Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems (D&amp;FIS), Health Group, and Graphic Communications Group).&#160; The balance of the Company&#146;s operations, which individually and in the aggregate do not meet the criteria of a reportable segment, are reported in All Other.&#160; However, in September of 2005, the Company announced that effective January 1, 2006, the Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems segment will be reported as two distinct segments, the Consumer Digital Imaging Group segment and the Film and Photofinishing Systems Group segment, thereby changing the reportable segments beginning with the first quarter of 2006.&#160; In connection with the realignment, the Company&#146;s new reporting structure will be implemented beginning in the first quarter of 2006 as outlined below: </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Consumer Digital Imaging Group Segment:</b>&#160; The Consumer Digital Imaging Group segment encompasses digital capture, kiosks, home printing systems, business development, inkjet systems, digital imaging services and imaging sensors.&#160; This segment provides consumers, professionals and cinematographers with digital products and services.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Film and Photofinishing Systems Group Segment:&#160; </b>The Film and Photofinishing Systems Group segment encompasses consumer and professional film, photographic paper and photofinishing, aerial and industrial film, and entertainment products and services.&#160; This segment provides consumers, professionals and cinematographers with traditional products and services.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Health Group Segment:</b>&#160; There are no changes to the Health Group segment.&#160;&#160; The Health Group segment provides digital medical imaging and information products, and systems and solutions, which are key components of sales and earnings growth. &#160;These include laser imagers, digital print films, computed and digital radiography systems, dental radiographic imaging systems, dental practice management software, advanced picture-archiving and communications systems (PACS), and healthcare information systems (HCIS).&#160; Products of the Health Group segment also include traditional analog medical films, chemicals, and processing equipment.&#160; Kodak&#146;s history in traditional analog imaging has made it a leader in this area and has served as the foundation for building its important digital imaging business.&#160; The Health Group segment serves the general radiology market and specialty health markets, including dental, mammography,
orthopedics and oncology.&#160; The segment also provides molecular imaging for the biotechnology research market.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 4</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Graphic Communications Group
Segment:</b>&#160; As of January 1, 2006, the Graphic Communications Group
segment consists of Kodak Polychrome Graphics LLC (KPG), a leader in the graphic
communications industry; Creo Inc., a premier supplier of prepress and workflow systems used
by commercial printers worldwide; NexPress Solutions, Inc., a producer of
digital color and black and white printing solutions; Kodak Versamark, Inc., a
provider of continuous inkjet technology; and Encad, Inc., a maker of
wide-format inkjet printers, inks and media.&#160; Kodak&#146;s Document
Products and Services organization, which includes market-leading production and
desktop document scanners, microfilm, worldwide service and support and business
process services operations, is also part of this segment.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Graphic Communications Group segment serves a variety of customers in the creative, in-plant, data center, commercial printing, packaging, newspaper and digital service bureau market segments with a range of software, media and hardware products that provide customers with a variety of solutions for prepress equipment, workflow software, digital and traditional printing, document scanning and multi-vendor IT services.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On April 1, 2005, the Company became the sole owner of KPG through the redemption of Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s 50 percent interest in the KPG joint venture.&#160; This transaction further established the Company as a leader in the graphic communications industry and complements the Company&#146;s existing business in this market.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 15, 2005, the Company completed the acquisition of Creo Inc. (Creo), a premier supplier of prepress and workflow systems used by commercial printers around the world.&#160; The acquisition of Creo uniquely positions the Company to be the preferred partner for its customers, helping them improve efficiency, expand their offerings and grow their businesses.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>All Other:</b>&#160; All Other is composed of Kodak&#146;s display and components business for image sensors, and other small, miscellaneous businesses.&#160; It also includes development initiatives in consumer inkjet technologies.&#160; These businesses offer imaging sensors to original equipment manufacturers (OEMs) and other specialty materials including organic light emitting diode (OLED) products to commercial customers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In 2003, Kodak announced a comprehensive strategy to be implemented through 2007 to complete its transformation as the leader of the traditional photographic industry to a leadership position in digital imaging markets. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Solid progress was achieved during 2005 in each area of this strategy.&#160; Kodak holds a leading position in key digital product categories where we participate.&#160; For the year ended December 31, 2005, Kodak achieved a level of digital revenues that exceeded traditional revenues.&#160; Additionally, through the 2005 acquisitions of KPG and Creo, Kodak has essentially completed its $3 billion investment and acquisition plan included in the 2003 strategy.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">For 2006, the Company&#146;s strategy includes the following priorities: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">- </font></p>  </td>
  <td width="93%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Continue the   focus on delivering cash flow</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">- </font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Revenue   growth from digital products and services is subordinated to expansion of   operating margin on digital products and services</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">- </font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Continue to   grow revenue from digital products and services</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As previously mentioned, the realignment and the new reporting structure are effective for the first quarter of 2006.&#160; Accordingly, the following business discussion is based on the three reportable segments and All Other as they were structured as of and for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; Kodak&#146;s sales, earnings and assets by reportable segment for these three reportable segments and All Other for the past three years are shown in Note 23, &#147;Segment Information.&#148;</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 5</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>DIGITAL &amp; FILM IMAGING SYSTEMS (D&amp;FIS) SEGMENT</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales from continuing operations of the D&amp;FIS segment for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were (in millions) $8,460, $9,366 and $9,415, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">This segment combines digital and traditional photography and imaging services in all its forms, including consumer, professional and motion picture.&#160; Kodak manufactures and markets films (consumer, professional, motion picture, aerial and industrial), photographic papers (consumer and professional), photographic processing services, photographic chemicals, and cameras (including one-time-use and digital).&#160; Kodak EasyShare Gallery has accelerated Kodak&#146;s growth in the online photography market and helped to drive more rapid adoption of digital and online sharing, printing and archiving services.&#160; Kodak EasyShare Gallery, which has more than 30 million members, offers digital processing of images&#160; - both digital and film - as well as the ability to go beyond printing 4x6 and create more margin rich items such as photo frames, calendars, photo playing cards, and a host of other personalized merchandise.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Digital product offerings are replacing some of the traditional film products at varying rates.&#160; For example, the workflow improvements offered by digital are having relatively more significant effects in the professional markets, while digital is having little impact in the entertainment markets.&#160; The future impact of digital substitution on these film markets is difficult to predict due to a number of factors, including the pace of digital technology adoption, the underlying economic strength or weakness in major world markets, and the timing of digital infrastructure installation.&#160; Film usage continues to decline as consumers continue to migrate from a film-only household, to a dual-use (digital camera and film) household, to a mobile phone use household.&#160; The mobile phone industry will continue to play a role in the digital camera market as phonecams rapidly improve their offerings with one and two megapixel cameras, convergence ability
such as wifi, and small, sleek design.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Marketing and Competition:</b>&#160; The key elements of the Company&#146;s strategy with respect to the digital and traditional products and services in this segment include growth in digital capture, expansion of online services and mobile imaging, leadership in professional lab solutions, leadership in distributed output at retail and in the home, and intelligent management of the traditional film and paper products and services.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s strategy in its
consumer digital business is to deliver innovative products and services that
deliver high quality, easy sharing and easy archiving to consumers,
professionals, retailers and labs, while not compromising on Kodak&#146;s
legendary ease of use.&#160; Consumer digital products, including digital
cameras, self-contained printer docks, which use thermal media to print pictures
from digital cameras without the need for a personal computer, and inkjet media,
are sold direct to retailers or distributors.&#160; Products are also available
to customers through the Internet via online digital services like Kodak
EasyShare Gallery.&#160; Products such as the Company&#146;s EasyShare digital
camera system with the camera docks are intended to simplify digital imaging for
consumers and thereby increase the popularity for sharing and printing digital
photo files.&#160; The ImageLink standard, introduced by Kodak and a consortium
of digital camera manufacturers (Nikon, Olympus, Pentax) in 2004, allows
non-Kodak cameras to connect to the EasyShare printer dock, enabling consumers
to print outstanding quality snapshots at the press of a button without
connecting to a computer.&#160; The Company faces competition from other
electronics manufacturers in this market, particularly on price and
technological advances.&#160; Rapid price declines shortly after product
introduction in this environment are common, as producers are continually
introducing new models with enhanced capabilities, such as improved resolution
and/or optical systems.&#160; Kodak EasyShare Gallery, the Company&#146;s online
imaging business, continues to demonstrate strong growth and began the
establishment of a customer base in selected overseas markets in 2003.&#160;
Late in 2003, the Company announced Kodak Mobile Service, which allows consumers
with image-enabled mobile phones to store, share and print their
images.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 6</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Traditional products and services for the consumer are sold direct to retailers and through distributors throughout the world.&#160; Price competition continues to exist in all marketplaces.&#160; To be more cost competitive with its traditional product offerings, the Company is continuing to rationalize capacity.&#160; As previously outlined, digital product offerings are substituting for some of the traditional film products, primarily in the U.S., Japan and Western Europe, as a large number of consumers actively use digital cameras.&#160; While this substitution to date has had an impact primarily on the Company&#146;s film and paper sales, and processing services in the U.S., Japan and Western Europe, there are moderating and declining sales in emerging markets as well.&#160; The Company&#146;s strategy is to partially mitigate this by providing its own digital products, digitization services and output services.&#160; In fact, growth in digital printing often

leads to output on silver halide paper.&#160; During 2005, as a result of the faster-than-expected decline in the Company&#146;s traditional film and paper business, the Company extended and accelerated its restructuring actions, and revised the useful lives of certain assets.&#160; The Company has sold or closed many of its photofinishing laboratories in certain parts of the world and repositioned its remaining labs for digital output as well as traditional processing services for retailers.&#160; Kodak also supplies photographic papers and chemicals to other entities that provide photofinishing services.&#160; The Company&#146;s remaining laboratories provide consumers the opportunity to receive film images in traditional formats or digital form, such as a Picture CD. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Traditional and digital professional products and services are sold direct to professional photographers and laboratories, or through dealers throughout the world.&#160; Although the Company continues to provide better performing and innovative traditional films and papers, the focus has shifted towards new products, systems and solutions focused on improving the digital workflow for professional photographers and laboratories.&#160; These solutions range from digital capture devices (digital cameras and scanners) designed to improve the image acquisition or digitalization process, software products designed to enhance and simplify the digital workflow, output devices (thermal printers and digital silver halide writers) designed to produce high quality images, and media (thermal and silver halide) optimized for digital workflows.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Throughout the world, almost all entertainment-imaging products are sold direct to studios, laboratories, independent filmmakers or production companies.&#160; Quality and availability are important factors for these products, which are sold in a price-competitive environment.&#160; When the entertainment industry adopts digital formats, the Company anticipates that it will face new competitors, including some of its current customers and other electronics manufacturers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak&#146;s advertising programs actively promote the segment&#146;s products and services in its various markets, and its principal trademarks, trade dress and corporate symbol are widely used and recognized.&#160; Kodak is frequently noted by trade and business publications as one of the most recognized and respected brands in the world.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>HEALTH GROUP SEGMENT</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales from continuing operations of the Health Group segment for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were (in millions) $2,655, $2,686 and $2,431, respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Products and services of the Health Group segment enable healthcare customers (e.g., hospitals, imaging centers, etc.) to capture, process, integrate, archive and display images and information in a variety of forms.&#160; These products and services provide intelligent decision support through the entire patient pathway from research to detection to diagnosis to treatment.&#160; The Health Group segment also provides products and services that help customers improve workflow in their facilities, which in turn helps them enhance the quality and productivity of healthcare delivery.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 7</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Health Group segment provides digital medical imaging and information products, and systems and solutions, which are key components of sales and earnings growth.&#160; These include laser imagers, digital print films, computed and digital radiography systems, dental radiographic imaging systems, dental practice management software, advanced picture-archiving and communications systems (PACS), and healthcare information systems (HCIS).&#160; Products of the Health Group segment also include traditional analog medical films, chemicals, and processing equipment.&#160; Kodak&#146;s history in traditional analog imaging has made it a leader in this area and has served as the foundation for building its important digital imaging business.&#160; The Health Group segment serves the general radiology market and specialty health markets, including dental, mammography, orthopedics and oncology.&#160; The segment also provides molecular imaging for the biotechnology
research market.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In March 2005, the Company completed the acquisition of OREX Computed Radiography Ltd. (OREX), a leading provider of compact, robust computed radiography systems that enable medical practitioners to acquire patient x-ray images digitally.&#160; This acquisition has added the technology of OREX&#146;s small format computed radiography products for use in various health imaging markets, such as orthopedics, diagnostic imaging centers, dentistry, and industrial non-destructive testing (NDT).&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Marketing and Competition:</b>&#160; In the U.S., Canada and Latin America, health imaging consumables and analog equipment are sold through distributors.&#160; A significant portion of digital equipment and solutions is sold direct to end users, with the balance sold through distributors and OEMs.&#160; In the U.S., individual hospitals or groups of hospitals represented by, as buying agents, group purchasing organizations (GPOs), account for a significant portion of consumables and equipment sales industry-wide.&#160; The Health Group segment has secured long-term contracts with many of the major GPOs and, thus, has positioned itself well against competitors.&#160; In Europe, consumables and analog equipment are sold through distributors and value added service providers (VASPs) as well as direct to end users.&#160; Hospitals in Europe, which are a mix of private and government-funded types, employ a highly regimented tender process in acquiring medical
imaging products.&#160; In addition to creating a competitive pricing environment, this process can result in a delay of up to 6 to 18 months between the time the tender is delivered to the hospital and the time the hospital makes a decision on the vendor.&#160; Additionally, the government-funded hospitals&#146; budgets tend to be limited and restricted.&#160; Government reimbursement policies often drive the use of particular types of equipment and influence the transition from analog to digital imaging.&#160; These policies vary widely among European countries.&#160; In Asia and Japan, sales of all products are split between distributors and end users.&#160; In Europe, Asia and Japan, consumables and analog equipment are often sold as part of a media/equipment bundle.&#160; Digital equipment and solutions are sold direct to end-users and through OEMs in these three geographic areas.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Worldwide, the medical imaging market is crowded with a range of strong competitors.&#160; To compete aggressively, Kodak&#146;s Health Group segment has developed a full portfolio of value-adding products and services.&#160; Some competitors offer digital solutions similar to those of Kodak, and other competitors offer similar analog solutions or a mix of analog and digital.&#160; The Health Group segment has a wide range of solutions from analog to digital as well as solutions combining both analog and digital technologies.&#160; Moreover, the segment&#146;s portfolio is expanding into new areas, including enterprise information management solutions, thus enabling the segment to offer solutions that combine medical images and information, such as patient reports, into one unified package for medical practitioners.&#160; Kodak will continue to innovate products and services to meet the changing needs and preferences of the marketplace. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>GRAPHIC COMMUNICATIONS GROUP </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales from continuing operations of the Graphic Communications Group segment for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were (in millions) $2,990, $1,343 and $967, respectively.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 8</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Graphic Communications Group segment serves a variety of customers in the creative, in-plant, data center, commercial printing, packaging, newspaper and digital service bureau market segments with a range of software, media and hardware products that provide customers with a variety of solutions for prepress equipment, workflow software, digital and traditional printing, document scanning and multi-vendor IT services.&#160; As of and for the year ended December 31, 2005, the Graphic Communications Group segment consists of subsidiaries Kodak Polychrome Graphics LLC (KPG), Creo Inc., NexPress Solutions, Kodak Versamark, Inc., and Encad, Inc.&#160; Products include high-speed, high-volume continuous inkjet printing systems, high-speed production document scanners, micrographic peripherals, digital on-demand color and monochrome printing equipment, wide-format inkjet printers, inks, media (including micrographic films) and services.&#160; The Company also
provides maintenance and professional services for Kodak and other manufacturers&#146; products, as well as providing imaging services to customers.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In January 2004, Kodak acquired Scitex Digital Printing, renamed Kodak Versamark.&#160; This entity is a wholly owned subsidiary of Kodak focused on high-speed, high-volume printing applications, including those in transaction and industrial market segments.&#160; Kodak Versamark provides a full set of high-speed, variable-data inkjet printers, inks, service and other consumables.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In May 2004, Kodak acquired Heidelberger Druckmaschinen AG&#146;s (Heidelberg) 50 percent interest in NexPress Solutions LLC, a 50/50 joint venture of Kodak and Heidelberg that makes high-end, on-demand digital color printing systems, and the equity of Heidelberg Digital LLC, a leading maker of digital black-and-white variable-data printing systems.&#160; Kodak also acquired NexPress GmbH, a German subsidiary of Heidelberg that provides engineering and development support, and certain inventory, assets, and employees of Heidelberg&#146;s regional operations or market centers.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On April 1, 2005, the Company became the sole owner of KPG through the redemption of Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s 50 percent interest in the KPG joint venture.&#160; This transaction further established the Company as a leader in the graphic communications industry and complements the Company&#146;s existing business in this market.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 15, 2005, the Company completed the acquisition of Creo Inc. (Creo), a premier supplier of prepress and workflow systems used by commercial printers around the world.&#160; The acquisition of Creo uniquely positions the Company to be the preferred partner for its customers, helping them improve efficiency, expand their offerings and grow their businesses.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Marketing and Competition:</b>&#160; Throughout the world, graphic communications products are sold primarily through a variety of direct and indirect channels.&#160; The end users of these products include businesses in the commercial printing, data center, in-plant and digital service provider market segments.&#160; While there is price competition, the Company has been able to maintain price by adding more attractive features to its products through technological advances.&#160; The Company has developed a wide-range portfolio of digital products to meet the needs of customers who are interested in converting from traditional analog technology to new enterprise digital workflow solutions.&#160; Maintenance and professional services for Kodak products are sold either through the product distribution channel or directly to the end users of equipment.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The growth in digital printing workflows has negatively affected the sale of traditional graphic films.&#160; As a result, the Company has become more active in digital printing products and services in order to participate in this growth segment through the acquisitions of Scitex Digital Printing, renamed Kodak Versamark, the NexPress-related entities, KPG and Creo.&#160; Traditional graphic products, primarily consisting of graphic films and chemistry, were formerly sold directly by the Company to the KPG joint venture.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Inkjet products are sold primarily through a two-tiered distribution channel.&#160; The Company remains competitive by focusing on developing new ink and media formulations, new printer technologies, new software and training enhancements.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 9</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ALL OTHER </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales from continuing operations comprising All Other for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were (in millions) $163, $122 and $96, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All Other consists primarily of the Kodak components group, representing an effort by Kodak&#146;s move into high-growth product areas that are consistent with the Company&#146;s historical strengths in imaging science.&#160; As of and for the year ended December 31, 2005, the Kodak components group was comprised of the imaging sensor solutions business and Kodak display business.&#160; Products of this group include imaging sensor solutions and OLED materials and products.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">OLED technology, pioneered by Kodak, enables full-color, full-motion flat-panel displays.&#160; Kodak has a leading intellectual property position in this field.&#160; Unique from traditional liquid crystal displays, OLEDs are self-luminous and do not require backlighting.&#160; Their imaging performance, together with extremely fast response time, makes them well suited for video and other image intensive applications.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In 2001, the Company and SANYO Electric Co., Ltd. established a global business venture, the SK Display Corporation, to manufacture OLED displays for consumer devices such as cameras, and portable entertainment devices.&#160; Kodak held a 34% ownership interest and SANYO held a 66% interest in the business venture.&#160; In January 2006, Kodak announced that it will broaden its participation in the OLED industry.&#160; To facilitate this move, Kodak granted full control of SK Display Corporation to SANYO.&#160; Kodak will continue as exclusive licensing agent on behalf of Kodak and SANYO for certain OLED intellectual property. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>FINANCIAL INFORMATION BY GEOGRAPHIC AREA</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Financial information by geographic area for the past three years is shown in Note 23, &#147;Segment Information.&#148;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RAW MATERIALS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The raw materials used by the Company are many and varied, and are generally available.&#160; Silver is one of the essential materials used in the manufacture of films and papers.&#160; The Company purchases silver from numerous suppliers under annual agreements or on a spot basis.&#160; Raw base paper is an essential material in the manufacture of photographic papers.&#160; The Company has contracts to acquire raw base paper from certified photographic paper suppliers during the next several years. Lithographic aluminum is the primary material used in the manufacture of offset printing plates.&#160; The Company procures raw aluminum coils from several suppliers, with contracts generally in place over the next one to two years.&#160;Electronic components are prevalent in the Company&#146;s equipment and digital product offerings.&#160; The Company has entered into contracts with numerous vendors to supply these components over the next one to two years.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>SEASONALITY OF BUSINESS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales and earnings of the D&amp;FIS segment are linked to the timing of holidays, vacations and other leisure activities.&#160; In 2005, sales of digital products were highest in the last four months of the year.&#160; Digital capture and home printing products have experienced peak sales in this period as a result of the December holidays.&#160; Sales are normally lowest in the first quarter due to the absence of holidays and fewer people taking vacations during that time.&#160; Sales and earnings of traditional products, including photofinishing services, of the D&amp;FIS segment are normally strongest in the second and third quarters as demand is high due to heavy vacation activity and events such as weddings and graduations.&#160; These trends are expected to continue as the Company continues to experience growth in sales of digital products.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Sales and earnings of the Graphic Communications Group segment exhibit modestly higher levels in the fourth quarter.&#160; This is driven primarily by the sales of continuous inkjet and document scanner products due to seasonal customer demand linked to commercial year-end budgeting processes.&#160; In addition, sales of consumable products in this segment tend to occur uniformly throughout the year.&#160; Sales and earnings generated by the recent acquisitions of KPG and Creo are not expected to significantly impact the seasonality for this segment. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 10</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">With respect to the Health Group segment, the sales of consumable products, which generate the major portion of the earnings of this segment, tend to occur uniformly throughout the year.&#160; Sales of equipment products, which carry lower margins than consumables, are highest in the fourth quarter as purchases by healthcare customers are linked to their year-end capital budget process.&#160; This pattern is also reflected in the third month of each quarter. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Through the years, Kodak has engaged in extensive and productive efforts in research and development.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Research and development expenditures for the Company&#146;s three reportable segments and All Other for 2005, 2004 and 2003 were as follows:</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">36</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All Other</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">

  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>
