 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:3em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Total</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">892</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">836</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">760</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The downward trend in research and development expenditures in the D&amp;FIS and Health Group segments and upward trend in the Graphic Communications Group segment and All Other reflects the acquisitions completed in the current year as well as a continued focus on developing digital product areas.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Research and development is headquartered in Rochester, New York.&#160; Other U.S. groups are located in Boston, Massachusetts; Dallas, Texas; Oakdale, Minnesota; New Haven, Connecticut; and San Jose and San Diego, California.&#160; Outside the U.S., groups are located in England, France, Iceland, Israel, Germany, Japan, China, Singapore and Canada.&#160; These groups work in close cooperation with manufacturing units and marketing organizations to develop new products and applications to serve both existing and new markets.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">It has been Kodak&#146;s general practice to protect its investment in research and development and its freedom to use its inventions by obtaining patents.&#160; The ownership of these patents contributes to Kodak&#146;s ability to provide leadership products and to generate revenue from licensing.&#160; The Company holds portfolios of patents in several areas important to its business, including color negative films, processing and papers; digital cameras and image sensors; network photo sharing and fulfillment; x-ray films, mammography systems, computed radiography, digital radiography, photothermographic dry printing, medical and dental image and information systems; flexographic and lithographic printing plates and systems, digital printing workflow and color management, proofing systems; color and black &amp; white electrophotographic printing systems; inkjet inks, media and printing systems; thermal dye transfer and dye sublimation printing systems; digital
cinema;&#160; and organic light-emitting diodes.&#160; Each of these areas is important to existing and emerging business opportunities that bear directly on the Company&#146;s overall business performance.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s major products are not dependent upon one single, material patent.&#160; Rather, the technologies that underlie the Company&#146;s products are supported by an aggregation of patents having various remaining lives and expiration dates.&#160; There is no individual patent or group of patents the expiration of which is expected to have a material impact on the Company&#146;s results of operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak is subject to various laws and governmental regulations concerning environmental matters.&#160; The U.S. federal environmental legislation and state regulatory programs having an impact on Kodak include the Toxic Substances Control Act, the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA), the Clean Air Act, the Clean Water Act, the NY State Chemical Bulk Storage Regulations and the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, as amended (the Superfund Law).</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 11</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">It is the Company&#146;s policy to carry out its business activities in a manner consistent with sound health, safety and environmental management practices, and to comply with applicable health, safety and environmental laws and regulations.&#160; Kodak continues to engage in a program for environmental protection and control.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Based upon information presently available, future costs associated with environmental compliance are not expected to have a material effect on the Company&#146;s capital expenditures, earnings or competitive position.&#160; However, such costs could be material to results of operations in a particular future quarter or year.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Environmental protection is further discussed in the Notes to Financial Statements, Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies.&#148; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>EMPLOYMENT</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At the end of 2005, the Company employed approximately 51,100 full time equivalent people, of whom approximately 25,500 were employed in the U.S.&#160; The actual number of employees may be greater because some individuals work part time. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The current employment amounts are
expected to decline more over the next few years as a result of the personnel
reductions yet to be made under the 2004-2007 cost reduction program, which
contemplated a 40 percent reduction in headcount below 2003 levels of 62,300
full time equivalents worldwide. </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>AVAILABLE INFORMATION</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company files many reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC), including annual reports on Form 10-K, quarterly reports on Form 10-Q and current reports on Form 8-K.&#160; These reports, and amendments to these reports, are made available free of charge as soon as reasonably practicable after being electronically filed with or furnished to the SEC.&#160; They are available through the Company&#146;s website at www.Kodak.com.&#160; To reach the SEC filings, follow the links to Corporate, and then Investor Center.&#160; The Company also makes available free of charge through its website, at www.Kodak.com/go/annualreport, its summary annual report to shareholders and proxy statement.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The public may also read and copy any materials the Company files with the SEC at the SEC&#146;s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, N.E., Washington, D.C.&#160; The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.&#160; The SEC also maintains an Internet site, at www.sec.gov, that contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We have included the CEO and CFO certifications required by Section 302 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 as exhibits to this report.&#160; We have also included these certifications with the Form 10-K filed on April 6, 2005.&#160; Additionally, we filed with the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) the CEO certification, dated June 3, 2005, regarding our compliance with the NYSE&#146;s corporate governance listing standards pursuant to Section 303A.12(a) of the listing standards, and indicated that the CEO was not aware of any violations of the listing standards by the Company. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 12</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 1A.&#160; RISK FACTORS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Set forth below and elsewhere in this report and in other documents that the Company files with the Securities and Exchange Commission are risks and uncertainties that could cause the actual future results of the Company to differ from those expressed or implied in the forward-looking statements contained in this document and other public statements the Company makes.&#160; Additionally, because of the following risks and uncertainties, as well as other variables affecting our operating results, the Company&#146;s past financial performance should not be considered an indicator of future performance.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we do not effectively execute our digital transformation, this could adversely affect our operations, revenue and ability to compete. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company continues with its transformation from a traditional products and services company to a digital products and services company.&#160; This transformation includes an aggressive restructuring program to reduce its traditional infrastructure to cost-effectively manage the declining traditional business and to reduce its general and administrative costs to the level necessary to compete profitably in the digital markets.&#160; The Company expects these actions to be largely completed by mid 2007.&#160; As a result of the digital transformation, the Company has established three key financial metrics against which it will measure success: digital earnings growth through expanding margins from the Company&#146;s digital businesses, digital revenue growth and cash generation.&#160; Accordingly, the success of the Company&#146;s transformation is dependent upon the execution of the Company&#146;s transformation initiatives including (1) managing the amount and
timing of the cost savings resulting from the restructuring of its traditional infrastructure and the reductions in general and administrative costs, (2) Kodak&#146;s ability to continue its development and sale of digital products and services that deliver competitive margins in each of its segments, (3) the Company&#146;s ability to manage the traditional business for cash generation in a cost-effective manner and (4) Kodak&#146;s ability to successfully integrate its acquisitions, including KPG and Creo.&#160; If Kodak cannot successfully execute its transformation initiatives, the Company&#146;s ability to compete as a profitable and growing digital company could be negatively affected, which could adversely affect its results of operations and its ability to generate cash.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we fail to comply with the covenants contained in our Secured Credit Agreement, including the two financial covenants, our ability to meet our financial obligations could be severely impaired.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">There are affirmative, negative and financial covenants contained in the Company&#146;s Secured Credit Agreement.&#160; These covenants are typical for a secured credit agreement of this nature.&#160; The Company&#146;s failure to comply with these covenants could result in a default under the Secured Credit Agreement.&#160; If an event of default were to occur and is not waived by the lenders, then all outstanding debt, interest and other payments under the Secured Credit Agreement could become immediately due and payable and any unused borrowing availability under the revolving credit facility of the Secured Credit Agreement could be terminated by the lenders.&#160; The failure of the Company to repay any accelerated debt under the Secured Credit Agreement could result in acceleration of the majority of the Company&#146;s unsecured outstanding debt obligations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we cannot effectively manage transitions of our products and services, this could adversely affect our revenues. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The industries in which Kodak competes are rapidly changing and becoming increasingly more complex.&#160; Kodak&#146;s ability to successfully transition its existing products to new offerings requires that Kodak make accurate predictions of the product development schedule as well as volumes, product mix, customer demand, sales channels, and configuration.&#160; The process of developing new products and services is complex and often uncertain due to the frequent introduction of new products that offer improved performance and pricing.&#160; Kodak may anticipate demand and perceived market acceptance that differs from the product&#146;s realizable customer demand and revenue stream.&#160; Further, in the face of intense industry competition, any unanticipated delay in implementing certain product strategies (including digital products, category expansion and digitization) or in the development, production or marketing of a new product could decrease any advantage
Kodak may have to be the first or among the first to market and could adversely affect Kodak&#146;s revenues.&#160; Kodak&#146;s failure to carry out a product rollout in the time frame anticipated and in the quantities appropriate to customer demand, or at all, could adversely affect future demand for Kodak&#146;s products and services and have an adverse effect on its business.&#160; This risk is exacerbated when a product has a short life cycle or a competitor introduces a new product just before Kodak&#146;s introduction of a similar product. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 13</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we cannot effectively anticipate trends and respond to changing customer preferences, this could aversely affect our revenues.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Due to changes in technology, the market for traditional photography products and services is in decline and, as a result, product development has focused on digital capture devices (digital cameras and scanners) designed to improve the image acquisition or digitalization process, software products designed to enhance and simplify the digital workflow, output devices (thermal printers, digital silver halide writers and commercial printing systems and solutions) designed to produce high quality images, and media (thermal and silver halide) optimized for digital workflows.&#160; Kodak&#146;s success depends in part on its ability to develop and introduce new products and services in a timely manner that keep pace with technological developments and that are accepted in the market. The Company continues to introduce new consumer and commercial digital product offerings, however, there can be no assurance that the Company will be successful in anticipating and
developing new products, product enhancements or new solutions and services to adequately address changing technologies and customer requirements.&#160; In addition, if the Company is unable to anticipate and develop improvements to its current technology, to adapt its products to changing customer preferences or requirements or to continue to produce high quality products in a timely and cost-effective manner in order to compete with products offered by its competitors, this could adversely affect the revenues of the Company.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we cannot adequately protect our intellectual property, our business could be harmed.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak has made substantial investments in
technologies and has filed patent applications and obtained patents to protect
its intellectual property rights as well as the interests of Kodak
licensees.&#160; The execution and enforcement of licensing agreements protects
the Company&#146;s intellectual property rights and provides a revenue stream in
the form of royalties that enables Kodak to further innovate and provide the
marketplace with new products and services.&#160; There is no assurance that
such measures will be adequate to protect the Company&#146;s intellectual
property.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our revenue, earnings and expenses may suffer if we cannot continue to implement our intellectual property licensing strategies.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak&#146;s ability to execute its intellectual property licensing strategies could also affect the Company&#146;s revenue and earnings.&#160; Kodak&#146;s failure to develop and properly manage new intellectual property could adversely affect market positions and business opportunities.&#160; Furthermore, Kodak&#146;s failure to manage the costs associated with intellectual property generation, licensing and litigation could adversely affect the profitability of Kodak&#146;s operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our revenue, earnings and expenses may suffer if we cannot continue to license or enforce our intellectual property rights.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak relies upon patent, copyright,
trademark and trade secret laws in the United States and similar laws in other
countries, and agreements with its employees, customers, suppliers and other
parties, to establish, maintain and enforce its intellectual property
rights.&#160; Any of Kodak&#146;s direct or indirect intellectual property
rights could, however, be challenged, invalidated or circumvented, or such
intellectual property rights may not be sufficient to permit the Company to take
advantage of current market trends or otherwise to provide competitive
advantages, which could result in costly product redesign efforts,
discontinuance of certain product offerings or other competitive harm.&#160;
Further, the laws of certain countries do not protect proprietary rights to the
same extent as the laws of the United States.&#160; Therefore, in certain
jurisdictions, Kodak may be unable to protect its proprietary technology
adequately against unauthorized third party copying or use, which could
adversely affect its competitive position.&#160; Also, because of the rapid pace
of technological change in the information technology industry, much of our
business and many of our products rely on key technologies developed or licensed
by third parties, and we may not be able to obtain or continue to obtain
licenses and technologies from these third parties at all or on reasonable
terms, or such parties may demand cross-licenses.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 14</font></p>



<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our revenue, earnings and expenses may suffer if third parties assert that we violate their intellectual property rights.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Third parties may claim that Kodak or customers indemnified by Kodak are infringing upon their intellectual property rights.&#160; In recent years, individuals and groups have begun purchasing intellectual property assets for the sole purpose of making claims of infringement and attempting to extract settlements from large companies like Kodak.&#160; Even if Kodak believes that the claims are without merit, the claims can be time-consuming and costly to defend and distract management&#146;s attention and resources.&#160; Claims of intellectual property infringement also might require Kodak to redesign affected products, enter into costly settlement or license agreements or pay costly damage awards, or face a temporary or permanent injunction prohibiting Kodak from marketing or selling certain of its products.&#160; Even if Kodak has an agreement to indemnify it against such costs, the indemnifying party may be unable to uphold its contractual agreement to
Kodak.&#160; If we cannot or do not license the infringed technology at all or on reasonable terms or substitute similar technology from another source, our revenue and earnings could suffer.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we are not successful in transitioning certain financial processes and administrative functions to a global shared services model and outsourcing some of their work to third parties, our business performance, cost savings and cash flow could be adversely impacted.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company continues to migrate various administrative and financial processes, such as general accounting, accounts payable, credit and collections, call centers and human resources processes to a global shared services model to more effectively manage its costs.&#160; Delays in the migration to the global shared services model and to third party vendors could adversely impact the Company&#146;s ability to meet its cost reduction goals.&#160; Also, if third party vendors do not perform to Kodak&#146;s standards, such as a delay in collection of customer receipts, the Company&#146;s cash flow could be negatively impacted.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our inability to develop and implement e-commerce strategies that align with industry standards, could adversely affect our business. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the event Kodak were unable to develop and implement e-commerce strategies that are in alignment with the trend toward industry standards and services, the Company&#146;s business could be adversely affected.&#160; The availability of software and standards related to e-commerce strategies is of an emerging nature.&#160; Kodak&#146;s ability to successfully align with the industry standards and services and ensure timely solutions requires the Company to make accurate predictions of the future accepted standards and services.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>System integration issues could adversely affect our revenues and earnings. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak&#146;s completion of planned information systems upgrades, including SAP, if delayed, could adversely affect its business.&#160; As Kodak continues to expand the planned information services, the Company must continue to balance the investment of the planned deployment with the need to upgrade the vendor software.&#160; Kodak&#146;s failure to successfully upgrade to the vendor-supported version could result in risks to system availability, which could adversely affect the business.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Our inability to effectively manage our acquisitions, divestitures and other portfolio actions could adversely impact our revenues and earnings. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak has recently completed two large business acquisitions in its Graphic Communications Group segment in order to strengthen and diversify its portfolio of businesses, while establishing itself as a leader in the graphic communications market.&#160; At the same time, Kodak is accelerating the current restructuring of its traditional manufacturing infrastructure.&#160; In the event that Kodak fails to effectively manage the continuing decline of its more traditional businesses while simultaneously integrating these acquisitions, it could fail to obtain the expected synergies and favorable impact of these acquisitions.&#160; Such a failure could cause Kodak to lose market opportunities and experience a resulting adverse impact on its revenues and earnings.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 15</font></p>


<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Economic trends in our major markets could adversely affect net sales.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Economic downturns and declines in consumption in Kodak&#146;s major markets may affect the levels of both commercial and consumer sales. Purchases of Kodak&#146;s consumer products are to a significant extent discretionary.&#160; Accordingly, weakening economic conditions or outlook could result in a decline in the level of consumption and could adversely affect Kodak&#146;s results of operations. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we do not timely implement our planned inventory reductions, this could adversely affect our cash flow. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Unanticipated delays in the Company&#146;s plans to continue inventory reductions in 2006 could adversely impact Kodak&#146;s cash flow outlook. Planned inventory reductions could be compromised by slower sales due to the competitive environment for digital products, and the continuing decline in demand for traditional products, which could also place pressures on Kodak&#146;s sales and market share.&#160; In the event Kodak is unable to successfully manage these issues in a timely manner, they could adversely impact the planned inventory reductions. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Delays in our plans to improve manufacturing productivity and control cost of operations could negatively impact our gross margins. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak&#146;s failure to successfully manage operational performance factors could delay or curtail planned improvements in manufacturing productivity.&#160; Delays in Kodak&#146;s plans to improve manufacturing productivity and control costs of operations, including its ongoing restructuring actions to significantly reduce its traditional manufacturing infrastructure, could negatively impact the gross margins of the Company.&#160; Furthermore, if Kodak is unable to successfully negotiate raw material costs with its suppliers, or incurs adverse pricing on certain of its commodity-based raw materials, reduction in the gross margins could occur.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>We depend on third party suppliers and, therefore, our revenue and gross margins could suffer if we fail to manage supplier issues properly.</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak&#146;s operations depend on its ability to anticipate the needs for components, products and services and Kodak&#146;s suppliers&#146; ability to deliver sufficient quantities of quality components, products and services at reasonable prices in time for Kodak to meet its schedules.&#160; Given the wide variety of products, services and systems that Kodak offers, the large number of suppliers and contract manufacturers that are dispersed across the globe, and the long lead times that are required to manufacture, assemble and deliver certain components and products, problems could arise in planning production and managing inventory levels that could seriously harm Kodak.&#160; Other supplier problems that Kodak could face include component shortages, excess supply and risks related to terms of its contracts with suppliers.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If our planned improvements in supply chain efficiency are delayed, this could adversely affect our revenues and earnings. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As the Company continues with its transformation from a traditional products and services company to a digital products and services company, Kodak&#146;s planned improvement in supply chain efficiency, if delayed, could adversely affect its business by preventing shipments of certain products to be made in their desired quantities and in a timely and cost-effective manner.&#160; The planned efficiencies could be compromised if Kodak expands into new markets with new applications that are not fully understood or if the portfolio broadens beyond that anticipated when the plans were initiated.&#160; Any unforeseen changes in manufacturing capacity could also compromise the supply chain efficiencies.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 16</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>The competitive pressures we face could harm our revenue, gross margins and market share. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Competition remains intense across all segments in which Kodak competes.&#160; In the D&amp;FIS segment (which has been realigned into the Consumer Digital Imaging Group and the Film and Photofinishing Systems Group effective January 1, 2006), price competition has been driven somewhat by consumers&#146; conservative spending behaviors during times of a weak world economy, international tensions and the accompanying concern over war and terrorism.&#160; In the Health Group and Graphic Communications Group segments, aggressive pricing tactics intensified in the contract negotiations as competitors were vying for customers and market share domestically.&#160; If the Company is unable to obtain pricing or programs sufficiently competitive with current and future competitors, Kodak may lose market share, adversely affecting its revenue and gross margins.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we fail to manage distribution of our products and services properly, our revenue, gross margins and earnings could be adversely impacted. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The impact of continuing customer consolidation and buying power could have an adverse impact on Kodak&#146;s revenue, gross margins, and earnings.&#160; In the competitive consumer retail environment, there is a movement from small individually owned retailers to larger and commonly known mass merchants.&#160; In the health market, there is a continuing consolidation of various group purchasing organizations.&#160; In the commercial graphic communications market, the Company&#146;s products are sold primarily through a variety of direct and indirect channels.&#160; These resellers and distributors may elect to use suppliers other than Kodak.&#160; Kodak&#146;s challenge is to successfully negotiate contracts that provide the most favorable conditions to the Company in the face of price and aggressive competitors.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Economic uncertainty in developing
markets could adversely affect our revenue and earnings. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak conducts business in developing markets with economies that tend to be more volatile than those in the United States and Western Europe.&#160; The risk of doing business in developing markets like China, India, Brazil, Argentina, Mexico, Russia and other economically volatile areas could adversely affect Kodak&#146;s operations and earnings.&#160; Such risks include the financial instability among customers in these regions, political instability and potential conflicts among developing nations and other non-economic factors such as irregular trade flows that need to be managed successfully with the help of the local governments.&#160; Kodak&#146;s failure to successfully manage economic, political and other risks relating to doing business in developing countries and economically and politically volatile areas could adversely affect its business.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Because we sell our products and services worldwide, we are subject to changes in currency exchange rates and interest rates that may adversely impact our operations and financial position. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak, as a result of its global operating and financing activities, is exposed to changes in currency exchange rates and interest rates, which may adversely affect its results of operations and financial position.&#160; Exchange rates and interest rates in certain markets in which the Company does business tend to be more volatile than those in the United States and Western Europe.&#160; There can be no guarantees that the economic situation in developing markets or elsewhere will not worsen, which could result in future effects on earnings should such events occur.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Management has concluded that the Company did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2005 due to a material weakness in internal controls surrounding our accounting for income taxes.&#160; If we fail to remediate this material weakness or any material weaknesses we may discover in the future, we may not be able to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of our financial statements. As a result, our business, brand and operating results could be harmed. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effective internal control over financial reporting is necessary for the Company to provide reasonable assurance with respect to our financial reports.&#160; If the Company cannot provide reasonable assurance with respect to its financial reports, its business, brand and operating results could be harmed.&#160; As disclosed in the Company&#146;s 2004 Annual Report on Form 10-K, and in its Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q for each of the first three quarters of 2005, management&#146;s assessment of the Company&#146;s internal controls over financial reporting identified material weaknesses in the Company&#146;s internal controls surrounding the accounting for income taxes and in its internal</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 17</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">controls surrounding the accounting for pension and other postretirement benefit plans.&#160; In addition, in the Company&#146;s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the three and nine-month periods ended September 30, 2005, the Company also reported a material weakness in its internal controls surrounding the preparation and review of spreadsheets that include new or changed formulas.&#160; During the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company has made significant progress in executing the remediation plans that were established to address the material weaknesses identified above.&nbsp; This resulted in material improvements in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting, including the successful remediation of the material weaknesses in internal controls surrounding its accounting for pension and other postretirement benefits and spreadsheet controls as of December 31, 2005.&#160; Internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect
misstatements because of its inherent limitations, including the possibility of human error, the circumvention or overriding of controls or fraud. Therefore, even effective internal control over financial reporting can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to the preparation and fair presentation of financial statements. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>If we cannot protect our reputation due to product quality and liability issues, our business could be harmed.</b></font></p>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak products are becoming increasingly sophisticated and complicated to design and build as rapid advancements in technologies occur.&#160; Although Kodak has established internal procedures to minimize risks that may arise from product quality and liability issues, there can be no assurance that Kodak will be able to eliminate or mitigate occurrences of these issues and associated damages.&#160; Kodak may incur expenses in connection with, for example, product recalls, service and lawsuits, and Kodak&#146;s brand image and reputation as a producer of high-quality products could suffer. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 18</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 1B.&#160; UNRESOLVED STAFF COMMENTS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 8, 2005, the Company received a comment letter from the staff of the Division of Corporation Finance of the SEC.&#160; The comments from the staff were issued with respect to its review of the Company&#146;s Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2004, the Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended March 31, 2005 and the Form 8-K filed on April 22, 2005 relating to the Company&#146;s first quarter 2005 earnings release.&#160; In addition to other comments, the staff&#146;s June 8, 2005 letter included three comments relating to the Company&#146;s restatement of (1) the 2003 quarterly and full-year periods and (2) the first three quarters of 2004 (the &#147;restatements&#148;).&#160; The substance of those three comments is summarized below:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In Note 1,   &#147;Significant Accounting Policies and Restatement,&#148; to the Consolidated   Financial Statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2004 (Note 1),   the Company provided disclosure summarizing the nature of the income taxes,   pensions and other postretirement benefits and other errors that resulted in   the restatements.&#160; In its comment letter,   the staff requested additional detailed information regarding the individual   errors within these categories, including an analysis of the impact of those   errors on each of the five years in the period from 2000 through 2004;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In Note 1,   the Company provided disclosure of the net impact of the errors relating to   periods prior to 2003 of $1.2 million (net adjustment) and the fact that,   because these errors did not have a material impact on the periods prior to   2003 or to the first quarter of and full-year 2003, the Company recorded the   net adjustment as a charge to Selling, General and Administrative expenses   (SG&amp;A) in the quarter ended March 31, 2003.&#160; In its comment letter, the staff requested that the Company (1)   explain its treatment of the net adjustment as a charge to SG&amp;A in the   first quarter of 2003 and (2) provide an analysis demonstrating that the   items comprising the net adjustment were not material to the periods prior to   2003; and</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In its   comment letter, the staff requested that the Company provide quantitative and   qualitative analyses supporting its materiality judgments for each of the   five years in the period from 2000 through 2004. The staff requested that   these analyses consider the materiality of each misstatement individually and   in the aggregate, including their impact on individual balance sheet and   income statement line items, quarterly and annual earnings per share, gross   margins and the segment data.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company responded to all of the staff&#146;s comments in a letter it filed with the SEC dated August 9, 2005.&#160; Included in the Company&#146;s response were the supplemental analyses and information requested by the staff.&#160; As of the date of the filing of this Form 10-K, the staff continues to review the Company&#146;s responses and, therefore, these comments remain unresolved.&#160; </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 19</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 2.&#160; PROPERTIES</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The D&amp;FIS segment of Kodak&#146;s business in the United States is centered in Rochester, New York, where photographic goods are manufactured.&#160; Another manufacturing facility in Windsor, Colorado, also produces sensitized photographic goods.&#160; Kodak EasyShare Gallery&#146;s operations are located in Emeryville, California.&#160; Digital product manufacturing is located in China and is also outsourced to third parties.&#160; Additional D&amp;FIS segment manufacturing facilities outside the United States are located in the United Kingdom, Brazil, China, France, India, Mexico and Russia.&#160; Kodak maintains marketing and distribution facilities in many parts of the world.&#160; There are also several photofinishing laboratories located across the United States and certain countries in Europe. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Products in the Health Group segment are manufactured in the United States, primarily in Rochester, New York; Windsor, Colorado; Oakdale, Minnesota; and White City, Oregon.&#160; Manufacturing facilities outside the United States are located in Brazil, China, France, Germany, India and Mexico.&#160; The segment provides digital and traditional products and services including picture archiving and communications systems, radiology information systems, enterprise and departmental healthcare information systems, digital and computed radiography systems, laser imaging, mammography and oncology systems, x-ray film systems for general radiography, and dental imaging products. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Products in the Graphic Communications Group segment are manufactured in the United States, primarily in Rochester, New York; Dayton, Ohio; Columbus, Georgia; Weatherford, Oklahoma; Windsor, Colorado; and San Diego, California.&#160; Manufacturing facilities outside the United States are located in the United Kingdom, France, Germany, South Africa, Israel, Bulgaria, China, Japan, Canada and Mexico.&#160; The segment provides digital and traditional products and services including digital printing, industrial solutions, prepress consumables and workflow and prepress equipment.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Properties within a country may be shared by all segments operating within that country.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Regional distribution centers are located in various places within and outside of the United States.&#160; The Company owns or leases administrative, manufacturing, marketing and processing facilities in various parts of the world.&#160; The leases are for various periods and are generally renewable.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company anticipates that its property portfolio will be reduced significantly over the next few years as a result of the 2004-2006 cost reduction program.&#160; Under this program, the Company expected to reduce its worldwide facility square footage by approximately one-third.&#160; In July 2005, the Company expanded this program and now plans to reduce its traditional manufacturing infrastructure by two-thirds below 2004 levels.&#160; This program has been renamed the &#147;2004-2007 Restructuring Program&#148; and is expected to be largely complete by mid-2007.&#160; During 2005, the Company made significant progress towards achieving this goal and remains committed to this plan.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 3.&#160; LEGAL PROCEEDINGS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During March 2005, the Company was contacted by members of the Division of Enforcement of the SEC concerning the announced restatement of the Company&#146;s financial statements for the full year and quarters of 2003 and the first three unaudited quarters of 2004.&#160; An informal inquiry by the staff of the SEC into the substance of that restatement is continuing.&#160; The Company continues to fully cooperate with this inquiry, and the staff has indicated that the inquiry should not be construed as an indication by the SEC or its staff that any violations of law have occurred.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 20</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 13, 2005, a purported shareholder
class action lawsuit was filed against the Company and two of its executives in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New
York.&#160; On June 20, 2005 and August 10, 2005, similar lawsuits were filed
against the same defendants in the United States District Court for the Western
District of New York.&#160; The cases have been consolidated in the Western
District of New York and the lead plaintiffs are John Dudek and the Alaska
Electrical Pension Fund.&#160; The complaints filed in each of these actions
(collectively, the &#147;Complaints&#148;) seek to allege claims under the
Securities Exchange Act on behalf of a proposed class of persons who purchased
securities of the Company between April 23, 2003 and September 25, 2003,
inclusive.&#160; The substance of the Complaints is that various press releases
and other public statements made by the Company during the proposed class period
allegedly misrepresented the Company&#146;s financial condition and omitted
material information regarding, among other things, the state of the
Company&#146;s film and paper business.&#160; An amended complaint was filed on
January 20, 2006, containing essentially the same allegations as the original
complaint but adding an additional named defendant. Defendants&#146; initial
responses to the Complaints are not yet due. &#160;The Company intends to defend
these lawsuits vigorously but is unable currently to predict the outcome of the
litigation or to estimate the range of potential loss, if any.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On or about November 9, 2005, the Company was served with a purported derivative lawsuit that had been commenced against the Company, as a nominal defendant, and eleven current and former directors and officers of the Company, in the New York State Supreme Court, Monroe County.&#160; The Complaint seeks to allege claims on behalf of the Company that, between April 2003 and September 2003, the defendant officers and directors caused the Company to make allegedly improper statements, in press release and other public statements, which falsely represented or omitted material information about the Company&#146;s financial results and guidance.&#160; The plaintiff alleges that this conduct was a breach of the defendants&#146; common law fiduciary obligations to the Company, and constituted an abuse of control, gross mismanagement, waste and unjust enrichment.&#160; Defendants&#146; initial responses to the Complaint are not yet due.&#160; The Company intends to
defend this lawsuit vigorously but is unable currently to predict the outcome of the litigation or to estimate the range of possible loss, if any.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is named a Potentially
Responsible Party (&#147;PRP&#148;) along with seven other companies in
connection with certain alleged environmental contamination at the Rochester
Fire Academy, located in Rochester, New York.&#160; The Company provided
flammable materials to the Fire Academy, which were used in fire-fighting
training.&#160; The Company and the seven other PRPs have been negotiating with
the New York State Attorney General&#146;s office.&#160; On November 15, 2005,
the New York State Attorney General filed a complaint in the U.S. District
Court, Western District of New York against all eight PRPs seeking recovery of
expenses to remediate the site.&#160; The Company has not yet been served and
therefore its initial response is not yet due.&#160; The potential monetary sanction will be in excess of&#160; $100,000 but is not
expected to be material. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 4.&#160; SUBMISSION OF MATTERS TO A VOTE OF SECURITY HOLDERS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">None. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 21</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2000</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2000</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">

  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kevin J.   Hobert</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="top">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">66</font></p>  </td>

  <p>

 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Daniel T.   Meek</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">54</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Senior Vice   President</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2004</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">1998</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Antonio M.   Perez</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">60</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Chairman of   the Board, Chief Executive Officer</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2003</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2005</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Executive officers are elected annually in February.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">All of the executive officers have been employed by Kodak in various executive and managerial positions for at least five years, except Mr. Hobert, who joined the Company on September 30, 2002; Mr. Perez, who joined the Company on April 2, 2003; Mr. Lloyd, who joined the Company on June 16, 2003; Mr. Langley, who joined the Company on August 18, 2003; Mr. Richard Brown, Jr., who joined the Company on December 17, 2003; and Mr. Faraci, who joined the Company on December 6, 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The executive officers&#146; biographies follow: </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Robert L. Berman</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Berman was appointed to the position of Director, Human Resources in January 2002 and was elected a Vice President of the Company in February 2002.&nbsp; In March 2005, he was elected a Senior Vice President by the Board of Directors.&nbsp; Prior to this position, Mr. Berman was the Associate Director of Human Resources and the Director and Divisional Vice President of Human Resources for Global Operations.&nbsp; His responsibility in that role included leadership in the delivery of strategic and operational human resources services to Kodak&#146;s global manufacturing, supply chain and regional operations around the world.&nbsp; He has held a variety of key human resources positions for Kodak over his 22 year career, including the Director and Divisional Vice President of Human Resources for the Consumer Imaging business and the Human Resources Director for Kodak Colorado Division. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 22</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Charles S. Brown, Jr. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brown began his Kodak career as a process engineer in the Synthetic Chemicals Division in 1973 and served in various technical and supervisory capacities until 1982.&nbsp;Mr. Brown&#146;s Kodak management experience has been primarily in manufacturing serving as the Director, Manufacturing Research and Engineering Division; Manufacturing Manager, Materials for Ektacolor Paper and Chemicals; and Manager, Synthetic Chemicals Division.&nbsp;In 1993, he was named the General Manager of Sensitized Goods Platform Center, the Company&#146;s unit responsible for the development of new photographic films, papers and photochemical products, and manufacturing technologies. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In September 1995 he was named Chief Operating Officer, Consumer Imaging and in October of that same year, the Board of Directors elected him a Vice President of the Company. His primary responsibilities included Consumer Imaging&#146;s film, paper and camera businesses.&nbsp;Mr. Brown was then named the Assistant Director, Imaging Materials Manufacturing beginning September 1, 1997.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brown was named Director, Global Manufacturing and Logistics, effective February 1, 1999.&nbsp;In this position, he provided leadership for Kodak&#146;s global operations for film, photographic paper, chemical products and equipment. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On April 14, 2000, Eastman Kodak Company&#146;s Board of Directors elected Mr. Brown a Senior Vice President. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In June 2004, Mr. Brown was promoted to
Chief Administrative Officer and is responsible for such corporate functions as
Health, Safety &amp; Environment, Human Resources, Corporate Security, Information Security and the Legal
department.&nbsp;He also oversees the Company&#146;s international regions.
</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Richard G. Brown, Jr. </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brown joined Eastman Kodak Company in December 2003 as Chief Accounting Officer and Controller. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brown was previously a partner at Ernst &amp; Young LLP, serving SEC registrants and privately held companies in such industries as consumer products, manufacturing and services.&#160; During his 32-year career at Ernst &amp; Young, he had significant experience in dealing with matters governed by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission, and participated for the last 15 years of his career there in the firm&#146;s National Accounting and Auditing Control Program. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Robert H. Brust</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brust was named Chief Financial Officer and Executive Vice President of Eastman Kodak Company, effective January 3, 2000.&nbsp; On January 30, 2006, the Company announced that Mr. Brust plans to retire from the Company effective January 31, 2007.&#160; Prior to joining Kodak, Mr. Brust was Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Unisys Corporation, a global information services and technology company with $8 billion in revenues, located in Blue Bell, Pennsylvania.&nbsp; He joined Unisys in 1997, where he directed the company&#146;s financial organization, including treasury, controllers, tax, information systems, mergers and acquisitions, strategy, procurement, and investor relations.&nbsp; He is largely credited for strengthening Unisys&#146; balance sheet and achieving a significant upgrade in the company&#146;s credit ratings. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Brust went to Unisys following a distinguished 31-year career at General Electric Co, where he last ran the finance operations of that company&#146;s plastics division as it grew from $900 million in revenues to about $8 billion.&nbsp; He joined General Electric in 1965, working in a variety of financial and financial management positions in businesses as diverse as motors, capacitors, steam turbines and generators, and engineering services.&nbsp; He joined the plastics division in 1983, directing the financial operation of that business through its dramatic period of growth. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 23</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Philip J. Faraci</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Faraci was named President, Consumer Digital Imaging Group in September 2005, effective January 1, 2006.&nbsp;He oversees Kodak&#146;s consumer, digital capture, printing, kiosk, and imaging systems businesses.&nbsp;He joined Kodak as Director, Inkjet Systems Program in December 2004. In February 2005 he was elected Senior Vice President of the Company. In June 2005, he was also named Director, Corporate Strategy &amp; Business Development. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to Kodak, Mr. Faraci served as Chief Operating Officer of Phogenix Imaging and President and General Manager of Gemplus Corporation&#146;s Telecom Business Unit. Prior to these roles, he spent 22 years at Hewlett-Packard, where he served as Vice President and General Manager of the Consumer Business Organization and Senior Vice President and General Manager for the Inkjet Imaging Solutions Group. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Carl E. Gustin, Jr.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Carl Gustin joined Kodak as Vice President and General Manager of the Digital and Applied Imaging Division in August 1994.&nbsp; In October 1995, he was appointed to his present position as Chief Marketing Officer and Senior Vice President, Eastman Kodak Company, in addition to his role as acting President and General Manager of Digital and Applied Imaging, which he did through 1996. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As Chief Marketing Officer, Mr. Gustin has been breaking new ground in the areas of advertising and marketing in an effort to fuel new market growth while further enhancing and broadening the reach of the brand. His areas of responsibility include: corporate-wide general marketing, internet marketing, customer relationship marketing, presence marketing, corporate branding, new business incubation, multicultural marketing, business research and corporate design, as well as providing leadership and direction for the marketing functions across the Company.&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Joyce P. Haag</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Ms. Haag began her Kodak career in 1981, as a lawyer on the Legal Staff. She was elected Assistant Secretary in December 1991 and Corporate Secretary in February 1995.&nbsp; In January 2001, she was appointed to the additional position of Assistant General Counsel.&nbsp; In August 2003, she became Director, Marketing, Antitrust, Trademark &amp; Litigation Legal Staff and in March 2004, she became General Counsel, Europe, Africa and Middle Eastern Region (EAMER). In July 2005, she was promoted to General Counsel and Senior Vice President. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to joining the Kodak Legal Staff, Ms. Haag was an associate with Boylan, Brown, Code, Fowler Vigdor &amp; Wilson LLP in Rochester, New York. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Mary Jane Hellyar</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mary Jane Hellyar joined Eastman Kodak Company in 1982 as a Research Scientist in the Kodak Research Laboratories.&nbsp; She held a variety of positions within R&amp;D and in 1988 she joined Film Manufacturing as a product engineer for motion picture films.&nbsp; In 1992 Ms. Hellyar was named Director of the Chemicals Development Division, responsible for process development of chemical components for Kodak.&nbsp;&#160; Following a one-year program at the Sloan School, she joined Consumer Imaging in the Strategic Planning function in 1994. In 1995 Ms. Hellyar was named Director of the Color Product Platform, responsible for development and commercialization of color negative films, papers and chemicals.&nbsp; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effective May 1999, Ms. Hellyar was named General Manager, Consumer Film Business, Consumer Imaging and was elected to Corporate Vice President. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In October 2001, Ms. Hellyar&#146;s responsibilities were expanded and in 2003 she added responsibilities for professional films.&#160; In November 2004, she was named President, Display and Components Group.&#160; In January 2005, the Board of Directors elected her to Senior Vice President. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 24</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In September 2005, the Company moved to four vertical businesses.&nbsp;Ms. Hellyar was named President, Film &amp; Photofinishing Systems Group, effective January 1, 2006, while also continuing responsibility for Kodak&#146;s Display business.&nbsp;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Kevin J. Hobert</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kevin Hobert was appointed President of Kodak&#146;s Health Group and a Senior Vice President of the Company in February 2005. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to his current position, Mr. Hobert was General Manager, Digital Capture Systems and Vice President of Kodak&#146;s Health Group.&#160; He drove significant process and product improvements that delivered revenue growth and improved margins.&#160; Under his leadership, the computed radiography business achieved the number two position worldwide, a digital radiography business was established and breast cancer computer aided detection, Kodak&#146;s first FDA PMA product, was introduced to the market. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Hobert joined Kodak in 2002 from General Electric Medical Systems (GEMS), a division of General Electric Co., with 11 years experience in the medical imaging market.&#160; At GE he was responsible for leading GEMS&#146; global business comprised of digital, analog and mobile radiography market segments and remote, classical and multipurpose fluoroscopy market segments. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>James T. Langley</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">James Langley joined Kodak as President, Commercial Printing, in August 2003. The Commercial Printing Group was renamed Graphic Communications Group in May 2004.&nbsp; In September he was elected to Senior Vice President of the Company. His responsibilities include leveraging Kodak&#146;s intellectual property to create new streams of revenue from the commercial printing market, as well as managing the Company&#146;s Encad, NexPress, Versamark, Kodak Polychrome Graphics and Creo subsidiaries.&#160; Mr. Langley has extensive expertise in printing technologies and both low-volume and high-volume manufacturing, stemming from a 30-year career at Hewlett-Packard Company (HP).&#160; Most recently, he was Vice President of Commercial Printing at HP from March 2000 to August 2002, where he created a business plan, built a team and successfully moved the company into that market. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to that assignment, Mr. Langley served for three years as Vice President of Inkjet Worldwide Office Printers, responsible for expanding the presence of HP&#146;s inkjet products in new, higher-end markets.&#160; This included all-in-one office printing devices, large format printing, photofinishing and commercial printing.&#160; During his tenure, revenue and earnings at the business grew annually at a double-digit pace. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">From August 1993 to June 1997, Mr. Langley served as the General Manager of HP&#146;s Vancouver Printer Division, a new unit whose sales represented incremental business for the company. As General Manager, he led the development of high-performance inkjet technology and products for retail and commercial channels. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Langley joined HP in 1972, working in a variety of technical and management positions involving laser printers. His achievements in that time included writing the Printer Control Language for use with HP LaserJet printers.&nbsp;&nbsp; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>William J. Lloyd</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Bill Lloyd joined Kodak in June 2003 as Director, Portfolio Planning and Analysis.&nbsp; In October 2003, he was named Director, Inkjet Systems Program, and was elected to Vice President of the Company.&#160; In February 2005, he was elected to Senior Vice President.&#160; His current title became effective March 1, 2005. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to Kodak, Mr. Lloyd was President of the consulting firm, Inwit, Inc. focused on imaging technology.&nbsp; From November 2000 until March 2002, he served as Executive Vice President and Chief Technology Officer (&#147;CTO&#148;) of Gemplus International, the leading provider of smart card-based secure solutions for the wireless and financial markets. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 25</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In 2000, Mr. Lloyd served as the Co-CEO during the startup phase of Phogenix Imaging, a joint venture between Eastman Kodak and Hewlett-Packard.&nbsp; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Lloyd has extensive expertise in imaging and printing technologies, stemming from his 31-year career at Hewlett-Packard Company where he was Group Vice President and CTO for consumer imaging and printing.&nbsp; In his career at HP, Mr. Lloyd held a variety of positions in product development and research both in the US and Japan.&#160; During his tenure in Japan (from 1990 until 1993), he directed the establishment of a branch of HP Laboratories.&nbsp; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Daniel T. Meek</b></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Daniel Meek was named Director, Global Manufacturing &amp; Logistics effective June 2004.&#160; In this position he provides leadership for Kodak&#146;s global operations for film, photographic paper, chemical products and equipment, as well as global logistics.&nbsp; In April 2004, he was elected to Senior Vice President of the Company by the Board of Directors.&nbsp; In October 2003, he was named Corporate KOS (Kodak Operating System) Director on a full time basis.&nbsp; Since January 2003, he was both the Director of the Global Capture Flow, part of Global Manufacturing &amp; Logistics and the Corporate KOS Director.&nbsp; In November 2002, he was named Director of the Global Capture Flow, Global Manufacturing and Logistics, which included the merger of the Color Film, Graphics, and Document Imaging Flows, as well as Estar Manufacturing.&nbsp; In December 1999, he was named Director of Worldwide Color Film Flow, Imaging Materials Manufacturing.&nbsp;
Previously, in October 1998, he was named Director of Worldwide Manufacturing Services, Imaging Materials Manufacturing, and elected to Vice President, Eastman Kodak Company. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to joining Kodak, from 1995 to 1998, Daniel Meek was Vice President of Operations at NYPRO, Inc., a worldwide custom injection molding company. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">He previously worked for Kodak and originally joined the Company in 1973 as a systems analyst and later held a variety of positions in the Paper Manufacturing Organization. In 1985, he joined Verbatim Corporation after Kodak acquired it, subsequently serving as Senior Vice President for North American operations. In 1990, the Verbatim Corporation was sold to Mitsubishi Chemical Corporation and Dan remained at Verbatim until 1995 continuing in his executive operations role. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Antonio M. Perez</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Antonio M. Perez joined Kodak as President
and Chief Operating Officer in April 2003, and was elected to the Company&#146;s
Board of Directors in October 2004.&nbsp;In May 2005, he was elected Chief
Executive Officer, effective June 1, 2005, and on December 31, 2005, he became Chairman of the
Company&#146;s Board of Directors. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Perez is leading the digital transformation of Kodak, aimed at delivering innovative digital products and services to consumer and commercial customers in the fastest-growing segments of the imaging industry. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Perez has extensive expertise in digital imaging technologies, stemming from a 25-year career at Hewlett-Packard Company, where he was a Corporate Vice President and a member of the company&#146;s Executive Council.&nbsp;As President of HP&#146;s consumer business, Mr. Perez spearheaded the company&#146;s efforts to build a business in digital imaging and electronic publishing, ultimately generating worldwide revenue of more than $16 billion. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to that assignment, Mr. Perez served as President and CEO of HP&#146;s inkjet imaging business.&nbsp;During the five years in which he led the business, the installed base of inkjet printers grew from 17 million to 100 million worldwide, with total revenue of more than $10 billion. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Just prior to joining Kodak, Mr. Perez served as an independent consultant for large investment firms, providing counsel on the effect of technology shifts on financial markets. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 26</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">From June 2000 to December 2001, Mr. Perez was President and CEO of Gemplus International, where he led the effort to take the company public.&nbsp;While at Gemplus, he transformed the company into the leading smart card-based solution provider in the fast-growing wireless and financial markets. In the first fiscal year, revenue at Gemplus grew 70%, from $700 million to $1.2 billion. </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>PART II</b></font></p>


<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="8%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 5.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="92%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>MARKET FOR THE REGISTRANT&#146;S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Eastman Kodak Company common stock is principally traded on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol &#147;EK.&#148;&#160; There are 76,539 shareholders of record of common stock as of January 31, 2006.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
