  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">-</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">100% of the   stock of NexPress GMBH &#150; a R&amp;D center located in Kiel, Germany</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">-</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Certain   sales and service employees, inventory and related assets and liabilities of   Heidelberg&#146;s sales and service units located throughout the world</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">There was no consideration paid to Heidelberg at closing.&#160; Under the terms of the acquisition, Kodak and Heidelberg agreed to use a performance-based earn-out formula whereby Kodak will make periodic payments to Heidelberg over a two-year period, if certain sales goals are met.&#160; If all sales goals are met during the two calendar years ending December 31, 2005, the Company will pay a maximum of $150 million in cash. &#160;During the first calendar year, no amounts were paid.&#160; Additional payments may also be made relating to the incremental sales of certain products in excess of a stated minimum number of units sold during a five-year period following the closing of the transaction.&#160; The acquisition is expected to become accretive by 2007.&#160; During the eight months since closing, the NexPress-related entities contributed $177 million in sales to the Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On January 5, 2004, Kodak announced the completion of its acquisition of Scitex Digital Printing, the world leader in high-speed, variable data inkjet printing systems.&#160; Kodak acquired the business for $239 million in net cash.&#160; Scitex Digital Printing now operates under the name Kodak Versamark, Inc.&#160; During 2004, Kodak Versamark contributed $198 million in sales to the Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Worldwide Revenues <br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net worldwide sales for the Graphic Communications Group segment were $1,343 million for 2004 as compared with $967 million for 2003, representing an increase of $376 million, or 39%, including a favorable impact from exchange of less than 1%.&#160; The increase in net sales was primarily attributable to the acquisitions of Kodak Versamark and the NexPress-related entities, which contributed approximately $375 million in net sales to the Graphic Communications Group segment.</font></p>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 52</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net sales in the U.S. were $587 million for 2004 as compared with $415 million for 2003, representing an increase of $172 million, or 41%.&#160; Net sales outside the U.S. were $756 million in the current year as compared with $552 million in the prior year, representing an increase of $204 million, or 37%, which includes favorable impacts from exchange of 1%. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Digital Strategic Product Groups&#146; Revenues <br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Graphic Communications Group segment&#146;s digital product sales, which consist of Kodak Versamark, the NexPress-related entities, Encad, Inc. products and services, and document imaging service and support, were $1,065 million for the current year as compared with $665 million for the prior year, representing an increase of $400 million, or 60%.&#160; The increase is primarily attributable to the acquisitions of Versamark and the NexPress-related entities.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak Versamark experienced strong sales performance driven by increased placements of color printing units in the transactional printing market coupled with a growing consumables business.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Traditional Strategic Product Groups&#146; Revenues<br>
</b></font>
  <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Graphic Communications Group segment&#146;s traditional product sales were primarily attributable to sales of traditional graphics products to the KPG joint venture, and document imaging imagelink equipment and media sales.&#160; Net worldwide sales of traditional products for the Graphic Communications Group segment declined $24 million or 8% from $302 million in 2003 to $278 million in 2004.&#160; This decline was primarily attributable to negative price/mix for graphic arts products, partially offset by increasing volumes. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Gross Profit<br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Gross profit for the Graphic Communications Group segment for 2004 increased $81 million, or 32%, from $257 million for 2003 to $338 million for 2004.&#160; The gross profit margin was 25.2% for 2004 as compared with 26.6% for 2003.&#160; The decrease in the gross profit margin of 1.4 percentage points was primarily attributable to (1) an increase in manufacturing cost, which negatively impacted gross profit margins by approximately 3.2 percentage points, primarily due to an increase in silver prices and additional costs incurred in relation to the relocation of manufacturing facilities for graphics products from Mexico to Great Britain and the U.S., (2) volume declines, which negatively impacted gross profit margins by 0.9 percentage points, and (3) negative price/mix of 0.6 percentage points.&#160; Partially offsetting these negative impacts were the acquisitions of Kodak Versamark and the NexPress-related entities, which contributed 2.1 percentage points to
gross profit margin for the current year period.&#160; This is despite the fact that Kodak Versamark&#146;s margins were negatively affected by the impact of the purchase accounting for the inventory that was acquired with Kodak Versamark at its fair value, which was sold during 2004.&#160; This negative impact was partially offset by a positive impact of purchase accounting for the inventory that was acquired with the NexPress-related entities at its fair value.&#160; Additionally, favorable exchange positively impacted gross profit margins by 1.5 percentage points.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Selling, General and Administrative Expenses <br>
</b></font><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">SG&amp;A expenses for the Graphic Communications Group segment were $259 million for 2004 as compared with $139 million in the prior year, representing an increase of $120 million, or 86%, and increased as a percentage of sales from 14% in the prior year to 19% in the current year.&#160; The increase in SG&amp;A expenses is primarily attributable to the acquisitions of Kodak Versamark and the NexPress-related entities, which together accounted for $120 million of SG&amp;A expenses in the current year period.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Research and Development Costs<br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">R&amp;D costs for the Graphic Communications Group segment increased $82 million, or 228%, from $36 million for 2003 to $118 million for the current year, and increased as a percentage of sales from 4% in the prior year to 9% in the current year.&#160; The increase was primarily attributable to the acquisitions of Kodak Versamark and the NexPress-related entities, which together accounted for $90 million of R&amp;D in the current period, and includes a $10 million charge for purchased in-process R&amp;D associated with the Kodak Versamark and NexPress-related entities acquisitions.&#160; </font></p>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 53</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Earnings&#160; (Losses) From Continuing Operations Before Interest, Other Income (Charges), Net and Income Taxes <br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Earnings (losses) from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges), net and income taxes for the Graphic Communications Group segment decreased $121 million from earnings of $82 million in 2003 to losses of $39 million in 2004.&#160; This increase in losses is primarily attributable to the acquisition of the NexPress-related entities on May 1, 2004, the purchase of Scitex Digital Printing (renamed Kodak Versamark) on January 5, 2004, and the other factors described above.&#160; As noted above, the NexPress-related entities are expected to become accretive by 2007, and Kodak Versamark is expected to be slightly dilutive through 2004 and accretive thereafter.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">KPG&#146;s earnings performance continued to improve on the strength of its leading position in digital printing plates and digital proofing, coupled with favorable operating expense management and foreign exchange.&#160; The Company&#146;s equity in the earnings of KPG contributed positive results to other income (charges), net during 2004.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ALL OTHER</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Worldwide Revenues <br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net worldwide sales for All Other were $122 million for 2004 as compared with $96 million for 2003, representing an increase of $26 million, or 27%.&#160; Net sales in the U.S. were $57 million in 2004 as compared with $45 million for 2003, representing an increase of $12 million, or 27%.&#160;&#160; Net sales outside the U.S. were $65 million in the current year as compared with $51 million in the prior year, representing an increase of $14 million, or 27%.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Losses From Continuing Operations Before Interest, Other Income (Charges), Net and Income Taxes<br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Losses from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges), net and income taxes for All Other increased $98 million from a loss of $93 million in 2003 to a loss of $191 million in 2004.&#160; Increased levels of investment for the Company&#146;s display business and consumer inkjet development activities primarily drove the increase in the loss from operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>EARNINGS FROM DISCONTINUED OPERATIONS, NET OF INCOME TAXES</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Earnings from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, for 2004 were $475 million, or $1.66 per basic and diluted share and were primarily related to the sale of Kodak&#146;s Remote Sensing Systems business (RSS), which contributed $466 million to earnings from discontinued operations, including the after-tax gain on the sale of $439 million.&#160; The 2003 earnings from discontinued operations, net of income taxes, were $64 million, or $.22 per basic and diluted share and reflects net of tax earnings of $27 million primarily related to reversals of tax and environmental reserves as well as $40 million of after-tax earnings from RSS.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NET EARNINGS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net earnings for 2004 were $556 million, or $1.94 per basic and diluted share, as compared with net earnings for 2003 of $253 million, or $.88 per basic and diluted share, representing an increase of $303 million, or 120%.&#160; This increase is primarily attributable to the reasons outlined above.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>


<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 54</font></p>
<p>

 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(57</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">)</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s results as noted above include certain one-time items, such as charges associated with focused cost reductions and other special charges.&#160; These items, which are described below, should be considered to better understand the Company&#146;s results of operations that were generated from normal operational activities.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s results from continuing operations for the year included the following:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $1,118 million ($1,020 million after tax) related to focused cost reductions implemented primarily under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program.&#160; See further discussion in the Restructuring Costs and Other section of Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations (MD&amp;A) and Note 16, &#147;Restructuring Costs and Other.&#148;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Net charges of $52 million ($38 million after tax) related to purchased in-process R&amp;D incurred in the second quarter (adjusted for credits of $12 million ($2 million after tax) in the third quarter) related to the acquisitions of KPG and Creo.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $44 million ($35 million after tax) related to a $19 million impairment of the investment in Lucky Film and a $25 million ($16 million after tax) asset impairment.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $21 million ($21 million after tax) related to unfavorable legal settlements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other income of $41 million ($39 million after tax) related to the gain on the sale of properties in connection with restructuring actions.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Income tax charges of $6 million related to a change in estimate with respect to a tax benefit recorded in connection with a land donation. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 55</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s results from continuing operations for the year included the following:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $889 million ($620 million after tax) related to focused cost reductions implemented primarily under the Third Quarter, 2003 Restructuring Program and 2004-2007 Restructuring Program.&#160; See further discussion in the Restructuring Costs and Other section of MD&amp;A and Note 16, &#147;Restructuring Costs and Other.&#148;</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $12 million ($7 million after tax), including $2 million ($1 million after tax) for inventory write-downs and $10 million ($6 million after tax) for the write-off of fixed assets related to Kodak&#146;s historical ownership interest in the NexPress joint venture in connection with the acquisition of the NexPress-related entities incurred in the second and fourth quarters.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $15 million ($10 million after tax) related to purchased in-process R&amp;D incurred in the first and third quarters.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $6 million ($4 million after tax) related to a legal settlement.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other income of $101 million ($63 million after tax) related to two favorable legal settlements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Income tax charges of $31 million related to valuation allowances for restructuring related deferred tax assets. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2003</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s results from continuing operations for the year included the following:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $552 million ($396 million after tax) related to focused cost reductions implemented primarily under the First Quarter, 2003 Restructuring Program and the Third Quarter, 2003 Restructuring Program.&#160; See further discussion in the Restructuring Costs and Other section of MD&amp;A and Note 16, &#147;Restructuring Costs and Other.&#148;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $16 million ($10 million after tax) related to venture investment impairments and other asset write-offs incurred in the second and fourth quarters.&#160; See MD&amp;A and Note 7, &#147;Investments,&#148; for further discussion of venture investment impairments.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $31 million ($19 million after tax), including $21 million ($13 million after tax) in the first quarter and $10 million ($6 million after tax) in the fourth quarter, related to purchased in-process R&amp;D.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $14 million ($9 million after tax) connected with the settlement of a patent infringement claim.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $12 million ($7 million after tax) related to an intellectual property settlement.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $14 million ($9 million after tax) connected with the settlement of certain issues relating to a prior-year acquisition. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $8 million ($5 million after tax) for a donation to a technology enterprise. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Charges of $8 million ($5 million after tax) for legal settlements. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reversal of $9 million ($6 million after tax) for an environmental reserve. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Income tax benefits of $13 million, which included tax benefits related to the donation of patents in the first and fourth quarters, amounting to $8 million and $5 million, respectively. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 56</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RESTRUCTURING COSTS AND OTHER</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is currently undergoing the transformation from a traditional products and services company to a digital products and services company. &#160;In connection with this transformation, the Company announced a cost reduction program in January 2004 that would extend through 2006 to achieve the appropriate business model and to significantly reduce its worldwide facilities footprint.&#160; In July 2005, the Company announced an extension to this program into 2007 to accelerate its digital transformation, which included further cost reductions that will result in a business model consistent with what is necessary to compete profitably in digital markets.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In connection with its announcement relating to the extended &#147;2004-2007 Restructuring Program,&#148; the Company has provided estimates with respect to (1) the number of positions to be eliminated, (2) the facility square footage reduction, (3) the reduction in its traditional manufacturing infrastructure, and&#160; (4) the total restructuring charges to be incurred.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The actual charges for initiatives under this program are recorded in the period in which the Company commits to formalized restructuring plans or executes the specific actions contemplated by the program and all criteria for restructuring charge recognition under the applicable accounting guidance have been met.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 57</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Restructuring Programs Summary</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The activity in the accrued restructuring balances and the non-cash charges incurred in relation to all of the restructuring programs described below was as follows for fiscal 2005:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>(in   millions)</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>Balance<br>   Dec. 31,<br>   2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

</table>

<BR>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="top">
  <hr size="1"  align="Left" width="25%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(1)</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The total   restructuring charges of $1,133 million include: (1) pension and other   postretirement charges and credits for curtailments, settlements and special   termination benefits, and (2) environmental remediation charges that resulted   from the Company&#146;s ongoing restructuring actions.&#160; However, because the impact of these charges and credits relate   to the accounting for pensions, other postretirement benefits, and   environmental remediation costs, the related impacts on the Consolidated   Statement of Financial Position are reflected in their respective components   as opposed to within the accrued restructuring balances at December 31, 2005   or 2004.&#160; Accordingly, the Other   Adjustments and Reclasses column of the table above includes: (1)   reclassifications to Other long-term assets and Pension and other   postretirement liabilities for the position elimination-related impacts on   the Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement
employee benefit plan arrangements,   including net curtailment losses, settlement losses, and special termination   benefits of $(98) million, and (2) reclassifications to Other long-term   liabilities for the restructuring-related impacts on the Company&#146;s   environmental remediation liabilities of $(8) million.&#160; Additionally, the Other Adjustments and   Reclasses column of the table above includes: (1) adjustments to the   restructuring reserves of $14 million related to the Creo purchase accounting   impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to   Restructuring charges, (2) foreign currency translation adjustments of $(12)   million, which are reflected in Accumulated other comprehensive loss in the   Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, and (3) rebalancing reclassifications   between the restructuring reserves, which net to zero on a consolidated   basis.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The costs incurred, net of reversals, which total $1,118 million for the year ended December 31, 2005, include $391 million and $37 million of charges related to accelerated depreciation and inventory write-downs, respectively, which were reported in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The remaining costs incurred, net of reversals, of $690 million, were reported as restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The severance costs and exit costs require the outlay of cash, while long-lived asset impairments, accelerated depreciation and inventory write-downs represent non-cash items. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>



<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 58</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004-2007 Restructuring Program</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company announced on January 22, 2004 that it planned to develop and execute a comprehensive cost reduction program throughout the 2004 to 2006 timeframe.&#160; The objective of these actions was to achieve a business model appropriate for the Company&#146;s traditional businesses, and to sharpen the Company&#146;s competitiveness in digital markets.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Program was expected to result in total charges of $1.3 billion to $1.7 billion over the three-year period, of which $700 million to $900 million related to severance, with the remainder relating to the disposal of buildings and equipment.&#160; Overall, Kodak&#146;s worldwide facility square footage was expected to be reduced by approximately one-third.&#160; Approximately 12,000 to 15,000 positions worldwide were expected to be eliminated through these actions primarily in global manufacturing, selected traditional businesses and corporate administration. &#160;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On July 20, 2005, the Company announced that it would extend the restructuring activity, originally announced in January 2004, as part of its efforts to accelerate its digital transformation and to respond to a faster-than-expected decline in consumer film sales.&#160; The Company now plans to increase the total employment reduction to a range of 22,500 to 25,000 positions, and to reduce its traditional manufacturing infrastructure to approximately $1 billion, compared with $2.9 billion as of December 31, 2004.&#160; When largely completed by the middle of 2007, these activities will result in a business model consistent with what is necessary to compete profitably in digital markets.&#160; As a result of this announcement, this program has been renamed the &#147;2004-2007 Restructuring Program.&#148;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company implemented certain actions under this program during 2005.&#160; As a result of these actions, the Company recorded charges of $742 million in 2005, which were composed of severance, long-lived asset impairments, exit costs and inventory write-downs of $497 million, $124 million, $84 million and $37 million, respectively.&#160; The severance costs related to the elimination of approximately 8,125 positions, including approximately 1,000 photofinishing, 4,375 manufacturing, 575 research and development and 2,175 administrative positions.&#160; The geographic composition of the positions to be eliminated includes approximately 4,150 in the United States and Canada and 3,975 throughout the rest of the world.&#160; The reduction of the 8,125 positions and the $581 million charges for severance and exit costs are reflected in the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program table below.&#160; The $124 million charge for long-lived asset impairments was included in
restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The charges taken for inventory write-downs of $37 million were reported in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under this Program, on a life-to-date basis as of December 31, 2005, the Company has recorded charges of $1,416 million, which were composed of severance, long-lived asset impairments, exit costs and inventory write-downs of $915 million, $262 million, $183 million and $56 million, respectively.&#160; The severance costs related to the elimination of approximately 17,750 positions, including approximately 5,700 photofinishing, 7,950 manufacturing, 1,000 research and development and 3,100 administrative positions.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 59</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The severance charges of $497 million and the exit costs of $84 million were reported in restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; Included in the $497 million charge taken for severance costs was a net curtailment loss of $6 million.&#160; This net curtailment loss is disclosed in Note 17, &#147;Retirement Plans&#148; and Note 18, &#147;Other Postretirement Benefits.&#148;&#160; Included in the $84 million charge taken for exit costs was a $8 million charge for environmental remediation associated with the closures of the manufacturing facility in Coburg, Australia and Sao Jose dos Campos, Brazil.&#160; The liability related to this charge is disclosed in Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; under &#147;Environmental.&#148;&#160; During 2005, the Company made $377 million of severance payments and $95 million of exit cost payments related to the 2004-2007
Restructuring Program.&#160; During 2005, the Company reversed $3 million of severance reserves, as severance payments were less than originally estimated.&#160; In addition, the Company reversed $6 million of exit costs reserves during 2005, as the Company was able to settle lease and other exit cost obligations for amounts that were less than originally estimated.&#160; These reserve reversals were included in restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The total severance charges of $497 million include pension and other postretirement charges and credits for curtailments, settlements and special termination benefits.&#160; However, because the impact of these charges and credits relate to the accounting for pensions and other postretirement benefits, the related impacts on the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position are reflected in their respective components as opposed to within the accrued restructuring balances at December 31, 2005 or 2004.&#160; Accordingly, other adjustments of $(113) million to the severance reserve in 2005 included reclassifications to Other long-term assets and Pension and other postretirement liabilities for the position elimination-related impacts on the Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement employee benefit plan arrangements, including net curtailment losses, settlement losses, and special termination benefits of $(96) million, which are disclosed in Note 17
&#147;Retirement Plans&#148; and Note 18, &#147;Other Postretirement Benefits&#148;.&#160; Additionally, the other adjustments of $(113) million to the severance reserve in 2005 include: (1) adjustments to the severance reserve of $7 million related to the Creo purchase accounting impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to Restructuring charges, (2) foreign currency translation adjustments of $(12) million, and (3) rebalancing reclassifications to other restructuring reserves of ($12) million, which net to zero on a consolidated basis.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 60</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other adjustments of $4 million to the exit cost reserve in 2005 included: (1) reclassifications to Other long-term liabilities for the restructuring-related impacts on the Company&#146;s environmental remediation liabilities of $(8) million, which are disclosed in Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; under &#147;Environmental&#148;, (2) adjustments to the exit cost reserve of $7 million related to the Creo purchase accounting impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to Restructuring charges, and (3) rebalancing reclassifications to other restructuring reserves of $5 million, which net to zero on a consolidated basis.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a result of the initiatives already implemented under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program, severance payments will be paid during periods through 2007 since, in many instances, the employees whose positions were eliminated can elect or are required to receive their payments over an extended period of time.&#160; Most exit costs were paid during 2005.&#160; However, certain costs, such as long-term lease payments, will be paid over periods after 2005.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a result of initiatives implemented under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program, the Company recorded $391 million of accelerated depreciation on long-lived assets in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The accelerated depreciation relates to long-lived assets accounted for under the held and used model of SFAS No. 144.&#160; The year-to-date amount of $391 million relates to $37 million of photofinishing facilities and equipment, $349 million of manufacturing facilities and equipment, and $5 million of administrative facilities and equipment that will be used until their abandonment.&#160; The Company will record approximately $200 million of additional accelerated depreciation in 2006 related to the initiatives implemented in 2005.&#160; Additional amounts of accelerated depreciation may be recorded in 2006 and 2007 as the Company continues to execute its 2004-2007
Restructuring Program.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The charges of $1,133 million recorded in 2005, excluding reversals, included $222 million applicable to the D&amp;FIS segment, $23 million applicable to the Health Group segment, and $30 million applicable to the Graphic Communications Group segment, and $3 million applicable to All Other.&#160; The balance of $855 million was applicable to manufacturing, research and development, and administrative functions, which are shared across all segments.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The restructuring actions implemented during fiscal year 2005 under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program are expected to generate future annual cost savings of approximately $499 million and future annual cash savings of approximately $476 million.&#160; These cost savings began to be realized by the Company beginning in the first quarter of 2005, and are expected to be fully realized by the end of 2006 as most of the actions and severance payouts are completed.&#160; These total cost savings are expected to reduce future cost of goods sold, SG&amp;A, and R&amp;D expenses by approximately $295 million, $133 million, and $71 million, respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Based on all of the actions taken to date under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program, the program is expected to generate annual cost savings of approximately $984 million, including annual cash savings of $951 million, as compared with pre-program levels.&#160; The Company began realizing these savings in the second quarter of 2004, and expects the savings to be fully realized by the end of 2006 as most of the actions and severance payouts are completed.&#160; These total cost savings are expected to reduce cost of goods sold, SG&amp;A, and R&amp;D expenses by approximately $666 million, $219 million, and $99 million, respectively.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The above savings estimates are based primarily on objective data related to the Company&#146;s severance actions.&#160; Savings resulting from facility closures and other non-severance actions that are more difficult to quantify are not included.&#160; The Company reaffirms its estimate of total annual cost savings under the extended 2004-2007 Restructuring Program of $1.6 billion to $1.8 billion, as announced in July 2005, and does not expect the final annual cost savings to differ materially from this estimate. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 61</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Pre-2004 Restructuring Programs</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had remaining severance and exit costs reserves of $2 million and $13 million, respectively, relating to restructuring plans committed to or executed prior to 2004.&#160; During 2005, reversals of $3 million were made to reduce the severance reserve balance, as severance payments were less than originally estimated. During 2005, reversals of $3 million were made to reduce the exit costs reserve balance, as the Company was able to settle lease and other exit cost obligations for amounts that were less than originally estimated.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining severance payments relate to initiatives already implemented under the Pre-2004 Restructuring Programs and will be paid out during 2006 since, in many instances, the employees whose positions were eliminated can elect or are required to receive their severance payments over an extended period of time.&#160; Most of the remaining exit costs reserves represent long-term lease payments, which will continue to be paid over periods throughout and after 2006.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Cash Flow Activity </i></b><BR>The Company&#146;s cash and cash equivalents increased $410 million to $1,665 million at December 31, 2005 from $1,255 million at December 31, 2004.&#160; The increase resulted primarily from $1,208 million of net cash provided by operating activities and $533 million of net cash provided by financing activities, offset by $1,304 million of net cash used in investing activities.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The net cash provided by operating activities of $1,208 million was primarily attributable to a decrease in receivables, excluding the impacts of acquisitions, of $228 million, and a decrease in inventories, excluding the impacts of acquisitions, of $274 million.&#160;&#160; The decrease in receivables, excluding the impacts of acquisitions, is primarily due to lower customer rebate accruals and lower miscellaneous non-trade receivables, and was also impacted by the Company&#146;s collection efforts, including customer-sponsored payment programs.&#160; The decrease in inventories is primarily due to a combination of: (1) planned inventory reductions driven by corporate initiatives, (2) an increasingly seasonal demand for digital products in anticipation of the holiday season, and (3) a decline in demand for traditional products.&#160; In addition, the Company reported a net loss of $1,362 million, which, when adjusted for the earnings from discontinued
operations, cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle, equity in earnings from unconsolidated affiliates, depreciation and amortization, purchased research and development, the gain on sales of businesses/assets, restructuring costs, asset impairments and other non-cash charges, and provision for deferred taxes, provided $582 million of operating cash.&#160;&#160;&#160; These sources of cash were further increased by the favorable impacts of the Company&#146;s continuing progress in the monetization of its intellectual property. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The net cash used in investing activities of $1,304 million was utilized primarily for capital expenditures of $472 million and business acquisitions of $984 million.&#160; These uses of cash were partially offset by $130 million from the sale of assets and investments.&#160; The net cash provided by financing activities of $533 million was primarily the result of a net increase in borrowings of $722 million due to the funding of the acquisition of Creo during the second quarter of 2005, partially offset by repayments of debt.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s primary uses of cash include debt payments, acquisitions, capital additions, restructuring payments, dividend payments, employee benefit plan payments/contributions, and working capital needs.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Acquisitions were $984 million in 2005, net of cash acquired.&#160; Approximately $927 million and $11 million of this amount is related to the acquisitions of Creo and KPG, respectively.&#160; The acquisition of Creo uniquely positions the Company to be the preferred partner for its customers, helping them improve efficiency, expand their offerings and grow their business.&#160; The acquisition of KPG further establishes the Company as a leader in the graphics communications industry and complements the Company&#146;s existing business in this market.&#160; Both Creo and KPG operate within the Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160; The remaining amount of $46 million was utilized to complete the acquisition of OREX.&#160; The acquisition of OREX adds the technology of OREX&#146;s small format computed radiography products for use in various health imaging markets. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 62</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Capital additions were $472 million in 2005, with the majority of the spending supporting new products, manufacturing productivity and quality improvements, infrastructure improvements, and ongoing environmental and safety initiatives.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company expended $508 million against the related restructuring reserves, primarily for the payment of severance benefits.&#160; Employees whose positions were eliminated could elect to receive their severance payments over a period not to exceed two years following their date of termination.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a result of the cumulative impact of the ongoing position eliminations under its Pre-2004 and 2004-2007 Restructuring Programs as disclosed in Note 16 and above as part of Management&#146;s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations, the Company incurred curtailment gains and losses with respect to certain of its retirement plans in 2005.&#160; These curtailment events resulted in the remeasurement of the respective plans&#146; obligations, which impacted the accounting for the additional minimum pension liabilities.&#160; As a result of these remeasurements, the Company was required to increase its additional minimum pension liabilities by $223 million during 2005.&#160; This increase is reflected in the pension and postretirement liabilities component within the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2005.&#160; The net-of-tax amount of $156 million relating to the increase of the additional
minimum pension liabilities is reflected in the accumulated other comprehensive loss component within the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2005.&#160; The related decrease in the long-term deferred tax asset of $67 million was reflected in the other long-term assets component within the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has a dividend policy whereby it makes semi-annual payments of dividends, when declared, on the Company&#146;s 10th business day each July and December to shareholders of record on the close of the first business day of the preceding month.&#160; On May 11, 2005, the Board of Directors declared a semi-annual cash dividend of $.25 per share payable to shareholders of record at the close of business on June 1, 2005.&#160; This dividend was paid on July 15, 2005.&#160; On October 18, 2005, the Board of Directors declared a semi-annual cash dividend of $.25 per share payable to shareholders of record at the close of business on November 1, 2005.&#160; This dividend was paid on December 14, 2005.&#160; The total dividends paid for the year ended December 31, 2005 was $144 million.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company made contributions (funded plans) or paid benefits (unfunded plans) totaling approximately $185 million relating to its major U.S. and non-U.S. defined benefit pension plans in the year ended December 31, 2005. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company paid benefits totaling approximately $240 million relating to its U.S., United Kingdom and Canada other postretirement benefit plans, which represent the Company&#146;s major other postretirement plans, in the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company believes that its cash flow
from operations in addition to asset sales and intellectual property
monetization will be sufficient to cover its working capital and capital
investment needs and the funds required for future debt reduction, restructuring
payments, dividend payments, employee benefit plan payments/contributions, and
modest acquisitions.&#160; The Company&#146;s cash balances and its financing
arrangements, as described under &#147;Sources of Liquidity&#148; below, will be
used to bridge timing differences between expenditures and cash generated from
operations.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Sources of Liquidity </i></b><BR>Refer to Note 9, &#147;Short-Term Borrowings and Long-Term Debt&#148; of the Notes to Financial Statements for presentation of long-term debt, related maturities and interest rates as of December 31, 2005 and 2004.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Short-Term Borrowings</i></b><BR>As of December 31, 2005, the Company and its subsidiaries, on a consolidated basis, maintained $1,132 million in committed bank lines of credit and $773 million in uncommitted bank lines of credit to ensure continued access to short-term borrowing capacity.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 63</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Secured Credit Facilities
</i></b><BR>On October 18, 2005 the Company closed on $2.7 billion of Senior
Secured Credit Facilities (Secured Credit Facilities) under a new Secured Credit
Agreement (Secured Credit Agreement) and associated Security Agreement and
Canadian Security Agreement. The Secured Credit Facilities consists of a $1.0
billion 5-Year Committed Revolving Credit Facility (5-Year Revolving Credit
Facility) expiring October 18, 2010 and $1.7 billion of Term Loan Facilities
(Term Facilities) expiring October 18, 2012.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The 5-Year Revolving Credit Facility can be used by Eastman Kodak Company (U.S. Borrower) for general corporate purposes including the issuance of letters of credit.&#160; Amounts available under the facility can be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed throughout the term of the facility provided the Company remains in compliance with covenants contained in the Secured Credit Agreement.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, there was no debt outstanding and $111 million of letters of credit issued under this facility.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under the Term Facilities, $1.2 billion was borrowed at closing primarily to refinance debt originally issued under the Company&#146;s previous $1.225 billion 5-Year Facility to finance the acquisition of Creo Inc. on June 15, 2005.&#160; The $1.2 billion consists of a $920 million 7-Year Term Loan to the U.S. Borrower and $280 million 7-Year Term Loan to Kodak Graphic Communications Canada Company (KGCCC or, the Canadian Borrower).&#160; At December 31, 2005, the balances reported in Long-term debt, net of current portion, on the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position were $920 million and $280 million for the U.S. Borrower and the Canadian Borrower, respectively.&#160; Debt issue costs incurred of approximately $57 million associated with the Secured Credit Facilities are recorded as an asset and amortized over the life of the borrowings.&#160; The remaining $500 million under the Term Facilities is committed by the Lenders and available to the U.S.
Borrower, through June 15, 2006.&#160; For this $500 million commitment, a 1.50% annual fee is paid on the unused amount to the Lenders.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition to the $2.7 billion of Secured
Credit Facilities, the Secured Credit Agreement allows for up to an additional
$500 million for a new secured credit loan based on terms and pricing available
and agreed to at the time the new credit loan would be established.&#160; There
are no fees for this feature.
</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pursuant to the Secured Credit Agreement and associated Security Agreement, each subsidiary organized in the U.S. jointly and severally guarantees the obligations under the Secured Credit Agreement and all other obligations of the Company and its subsidiaries to the Lenders.&#160; The guaranty is supported by the pledge of certain U.S. assets of the U.S. Borrower and the Company&#146;s U.S. subsidiaries including, but not limited to, receivables, inventory, equipment, deposit accounts, investments, intellectual property, including patents, trademarks and copyrights, and the capital stock of Material Subsidiaries.&#160; Excluded from pledged assets are real property, &#147;Principal Properties&#148; and equity interests in &#147;Restricted Subsidiaries&#148;, as defined in the Company&#146;s 1988 Indenture.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Material Subsidiaries are defined as those subsidiaries with revenues or assets constituting 5 percent or more of the consolidated revenues or assets of the corresponding borrower.&#160; Material Subsidiaries will be determined on an annual basis under the Secured Credit Agreement.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pursuant to the Secured Credit Agreement
and associated Canadian Security Agreement, Eastman Kodak Company and Kodak
Graphic Communications Company (KGCC, formerly Creo Americas, Inc.), jointly
and severally guarantee the obligations of the Canadian Borrower, to the
Lenders.&#160; Certain assets of the Canadian Borrower in Canada were also
pledged in support of its obligations, including, but not limited to,
receivables, inventory, equipment, deposit accounts, investments, intellectual
property, including patents, trademarks and copyrights, and the capital stock of
the Canadian Borrower&#146;s Material Subsidiaries.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 64</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest rates for borrowings under the
Secured Credit Agreement are dependent on the Company&#146;s Long Term Senior
Secured Credit Rating.&#160; The Secured Credit Agreement contains various
affirmative and negative covenants customary in a facility of this type,
including two quarterly financial covenants: (1) a consolidated earnings before
interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) to consolidated interest
expense (subject to adjustments to exclude interest expense not related to
borrowed money) ratio, on a rolling four-quarter basis, of no less than 3 to 1,
and (2) a consolidated debt for borrowed money to consolidated EBITDA (subject
to adjustments to exclude any extraordinary income or losses, as defined by the
Secured Credit Agreement, interest income and certain non-cash items of
income and expense) ratio of not greater than:&#160; 4.75 to 1 as of December
31, 2005; 4.50 to 1 as of March 31, 2006; 4.25 to 1 as of June 30, 2006; 4.00 to
1 as of S eptember 30, 2006; and 3.50 to 1 as of December 31, 2006 and
thereafter.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, the
Company&#146;s consolidated debt to EBITDA ratio was 2.89 and the consolidated
EBITDA to consolidated interest ratio was 6.24.&#160; Consolidated EBITDA and
consolidated interest expense, as adjusted, are non-GAAP financial
measures.&#160; The Company believes that the presentation of the consolidated
debt to EBITDA and EBITDA to consolidated interest expense financial measures is
useful information to investors, as it provides information as to how the
Company actually performed against the financial restrictions and requirements
under the Secured Credit Facilities, and how much headroom the Company has
within these covenants.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following table reconciles EBITDA, as
included in the computation of the consolidated debt to EBITDA ratio under the
Secured Credit Agreement covenants, to the most directly comparable GAAP measure
of loss from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges), net
and income taxes: </font></p>

 <tr>
  <td width="10%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Adjustments to interest expense relate to items that are not debt for borrowed money.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>


<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition, subject to various conditions and exceptions in the Secured Credit Agreement, in the event the Company sells assets for net proceeds totaling $75 million or more in any year, except for proceeds used within 12 months for reinvestments in the business of up to $300 million, proceeds from sales of assets used in the Company&#146;s non-digital products and services businesses to prepay or repay debt or pay cash restructuring charges within 12 months from the date of sale of the assets, or proceeds from the sale of inventory in the ordinary course of business, the amount in excess of $75 million must be applied to prepay loans under the Secured Credit Agreement.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">If unused, the 5-Year Revolving Credit Facility has a commitment fee of $5.0 million per year at the Company&#146;s current credit rating of Ba3 and B+ from Moody&#146;s Investor Services, Inc. (Moody&#146;s) and Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s Rating Services (S&amp;P), respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At the closing of the Secured Credit Agreement, the Company terminated its previous $1.225 billion 5-Year Facility, a $160 million revolving credit facility established by KPG, and the Company&#146;s $200 million Accounts Receivable Securitization Program.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has other committed and
uncommitted lines of credit at December 31, 2005 totaling $132 million and $773
million, respectively.&#160; These lines primarily support borrowing needs of
the Company&#146;s subsidiaries, which include term loans, overdraft coverage,
letters of credit and revolving credit lines.&#160; Interest rates and other
terms of borrowing under these lines of credit vary from country to country,
depending on local market conditions.&#160; Total outstanding borrowings against
these other committed and uncommitted lines of credit at December 31, 2005 were
$34 million and $65 million, respectively.&#160; These outstanding borrowings
are reflected in the short-term borrowings in the accompanying Consolidated
Statement of Financial Position at December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had outstanding letters of credit totaling $117 million and surety bonds in the amount of $85 million primarily to ensure the payment of casualty claims, workers&#146; compensation claims, and customs.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Debt Shelf Registration and Convertible Securities</i></b><BR>On September 5, 2003, the Company filed a
shelf registration statement on Form S-3 (the primary debt shelf registration)
for the issuance of up to $2.0 billion of new debt securities. Pursuant to Rule
429 under the Securities Act of 1933, $650 million of remaining unsold debt
securities under a prior shelf registration statement were included in the
primary debt shelf registration, thus giving the Company the ability to issue up
to $2.65 billion in public debt.&#160; After issuance of $500 million in notes
in October 2003, the remaining availability under the primary debt shelf
registration was $2.15 billion.&#160; The Company filed its 2004 Form 10-K on
April 6, 2005, which was late relative to the SEC required filing date
(including extension) of March 31, 2005.&#160; The Company also completed the
filing of a Form 8-K/A related to the acquisition of KPG on July 1, 2005, which
was late in relation to the SEC required filing date of June 17, 2005.&#160; As
a result of these late filings, the Company&#146;s primary debt shelf
registration statement on Form S-3 will not be available until the third quarter
of 2006.&#160; In the event the Company wanted to issue registered securities,
the Company could use Form S-1 or a Rule 144A transaction to issue such
securities in the capital markets.&#160; However, the success of future debt
issuances will be dependent on market conditions at the time of such an
offering.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has $575 million aggregate
principal amount of Convertible Senior Notes due 2033 (the Convertible
Securities) on which interest accrues at the rate of 3.375% per annum and is
payable semiannually.&#160; The Convertible Securities are unsecured and rank
equally with all of the Company&#146;s other unsecured and unsubordinated
indebtedness.&#160; The Convertible Securities may be converted, at the option
of the holders, to shares of the Company&#146;s common stock if the
Company&#146;s Senior Unsecured credit rating assigned to the Convertible
Securities by either Moody&#146;s or S&amp;P is lower than Ba2 or BB,
respectively.&#160; At the Company&#146;s current Senior Unsecured credit
rating, the Convertible Securities may be converted by their
holders.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 66</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The recently completed $2.7 billion Secured Credit Facilities, along with other committed and uncommitted credit lines provide the Company with adequate liquidity to meet its working capital and investing needs. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Credit Quality </i></b><BR>Moody&#146;s and S&amp;P&#146;s ratings
for the Company, including their outlooks, as of the filing date of this Form
10-K are as follows:&#160; </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="80%">

 <tr>
  <td width="18%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>

  <td  valign="top">

  <td  valign="top">

  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Negative</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">S&amp;P</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">B+</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">B+</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">B</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Negative</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Starting on April 29, 2005 and through January 31, 2006, Moody&#146;s downgraded its ratings on Kodak on four occasions, resulting in change of the Corporate Rating from Baa3 to B1 and the Senior Unsecured Rating from Baa3 to B2.&#160; On September 21, 2005 Moody&#146;s issued a Ba2 rating on Kodak&#146;s Senior Secured Debt, and subsequently lowered that rating to Ba3 on January 31, 2006.&#160; Moody&#146;s outlook remains negative.&#160; On November 1, 2005, Moody&#146;s assigned an SGL-2 speculative grade liquidity rate to the Company.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Moody&#146;s ratings reflect their views regarding Kodak&#146;s: (i) execution challenges to achieve digital profitability as its business shifts into highly competitive digital imaging markets,&#160; (ii) ongoing exposure to the accelerating secular decline of its consumer film business and potential decline of its entertainment imaging film business, and (iii) variability in the utilization of its traditional manufacturing assets and potential for incremental restructuring costs.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Moody&#146;s Ba3 rating assigned to the Secured Credit Facilities reflects the above factors as well as the security collateral and the secured cross guarantee afforded to the Secured Credit Facilities.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The negative rating outlook reflects Moody&#146;s concern regarding the Company&#146;s challenges to transition to a digital product and services business, including requirements to fund investment and restructuring costs, and uncertain prospects for achieving solid digital business profitability.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Starting on April 22, 2005 and throughout the year, S&amp;P lowered its credit ratings on Eastman Kodak Company five times.&#160; The Company&#146;s Corporate Rating was lowered from BBB- to B+, and the Kodak Senior Unsecured debt rating was cut from BBB- to B.&#160; On September 16, 2005, S&amp;P issued a BB rating on the Company&#146;s $2.7 billion Senior Secured Credit Agreement (Secured Bank Loan), and assigned it a recovery rating of &#147;2,&#148; indicating S&amp;P&#146;s expectation of substantial (80%-100%) recovery of principal in a payment default scenario.&#160; Subsequently, the Secured Bank Loan rating was lowered to B+.&#160; S&amp;P&#146;s rating outlook on the Company remains negative reflecting their &#147;reduced confidence in Kodak&#146;s profitability and cash flow prospects in light of the ongoing and rapid deterioration of its traditional consumer imaging business, unproven profit potential of its emerging digital imaging business, high cash

restructuring costs, and economic uncertainty.&#148;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is in compliance with all
covenants or other requirements set forth in its credit agreements and
indentures.&#160; Further, the Company does not have any rating downgrade
triggers that would accelerate the maturity dates of its debt.&#160; However,
the Company could be required to increase the dollar amount of its letters of
credit or other financial support up to an additional $108 million at the
current credit ratings.&#160; As of the filing date of this Form 10-K, the
Company has not been requested to materially increase its letters of credit or
other financial support.&#160; However, at the current Senior Unsecured Rating
of B2 by Moody&#146;s and B by S&amp;P, Convertible Securities holders may, at
their option, convert their Convertible Securities to common stock.&#160;
Further downgrades in the Company&#146;s credit rating or disruptions in the
capital markets could impact borrowing costs and the nature of its funding
alternatives.&#160; However, further downgrades will not impact borrowing costs
under the Company&#146;s $2.7 billion Secured Credit Facilities.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
