</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Options to purchase 31.2 million, 32.5 million and 35.9 million shares of common stock at weighted-average per share prices of $52.03, $52.47 and $51.63 for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, were outstanding during the years presented but were not included in the computation of diluted earnings per share because the effect would be anti-dilutive, meaning that the options&#146; exercise price was greater than the average market price of the common shares for the respective periods.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>STOCK-BASED COMPENSATION</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On January 1, 2005, the Company early adopted the stock option expensing rules of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 123R, &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; as interpreted by Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) Staff Positions No. 123R-1, 123R-2, 123R-3, and 123R-4, using the fair value recognition provisions of SFAS No. 123, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation.&#148;&#160; The adoption of SFAS No. 123R resulted in the recognition of expense that increased the 2005 loss from continuing operations before income tax, and net loss, by $16 million.&#160; The related impact on basic and diluted earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2005 was a reduction of $.06.&#160; The impact on the Company&#146;s cash flow was not material. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon the adoption of SFAS No. 123R in January 2005, stock-based compensation costs are included in the costs capitalized in inventory at period end.&#160; Under the pro forma disclosures previously provided under SFAS No. 123, the Company was not assuming the capitalization of such costs.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">For all awards issued after adoption of SFAS No. 123R, the Company changed from the nominal vesting approach to the non-substantive vesting approach for purposes of accounting for retirement eligible participants.&#160; The impact of applying the nominal vesting approach vs. the non-substantive approach upon adoption of SFAS No. 123R in 2005 was immaterial.&#160; The Company has a policy of issuing shares of treasury stock to satisfy share option exercises.&#160; The Company does not expect to repurchase stock during 2006, based on an estimate of option exercises.&#160; </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 93</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company previously accounted for its employee stock incentive plans under Accounting Principles Board (APB) Opinion No. 25, &#147;Accounting for Stock Issued to Employees,&#148; and the related interpretations under FASB Interpretation No. 44, &#147;Accounting for Certain Transactions Involving Stock Compensation.&#148;&#160; Accordingly, no stock-based employee compensation cost was reflected in net earnings for the years ended December 31, 2004, and 2003, as all options granted had an exercise price equal to the market value of the underlying common stock on the date of grant.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has determined the pro forma net earnings and net earnings per share information as if the fair value method of SFAS No. 123, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation,&#148; had been applied to its stock-based employee compensation in 2004 and 2003.&#160; The pro forma information is as follows:&#160; </font></p>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  style="margin-left:3em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Diluted - as reported</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">1.94</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">.88</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  style="margin-left:3em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Diluted - pro forma</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">1.90</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">.83</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The fair value of each option award is
estimated on the date of grant using the Black-Scholes option valuation model
that uses the assumptions noted in the following table.&#160; Expected
volatilities are based on historical volatility of the Company&#146;s stock,
management&#146;s estimate of implied volatility of the Company&#146;s stock,
and other factors.&#160; The expected term of options granted is derived from
the vesting period of the award, as well as historical exercise behavior, and
represents the period of time that options granted are expected to be
outstanding.&#160; The risk-free rate is calculated using the U.S. Treasury
yield curve, and is based on the expected term of the option. The Company uses
historical data to estimate forfeitures.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 94</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">1.8% - 5.8%</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The weighted-average fair value per option granted in 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $7.70, $8.77 and $7.70, respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">For purposes of pro forma disclosures, the estimated fair value of the options is amortized to compensation expense over the options&#146; vesting period (1-3 years). </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>COMPREHENSIVE INCOME</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">SFAS No. 130, &#147;Reporting Comprehensive Income,&#148; establishes standards for the reporting and display of comprehensive income and its components in financial statements.&#160; SFAS No. 130 requires that all items required to be recognized under accounting standards as components of comprehensive income be reported in a financial statement with the same prominence as other financial statements.&#160; Comprehensive income consists of net (loss) earnings, the net unrealized gains or losses on available-for-sale marketable securities, foreign currency translation adjustments, minimum pension liability adjustments, and unrealized gains and losses on financial instruments qualifying for cash flow hedge accounting, and is presented in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Shareholders&#146; Equity in accordance with SFAS No. 130.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 95</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>SEGMENT REPORTING</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company reports net sales from continuing operations, earnings (losses) from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges), net and income taxes, earnings (losses) from continuing operations and certain expense, asset and geographical information about its reportable segments.&#160; Reportable segments are components of the Company for which separate financial information is available that is evaluated regularly by the chief operating decision maker in deciding how to allocate resources and in assessing performance.&#160; In September 2005, the Company announced an organizational realignment that will change the current reportable segment structure.&#160; See Note 23, &#147;Segment Information,&#148; for a discussion of this change.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>RECENTLY ISSUED ACCOUNTING STANDARDS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>FASB Staff Position No. 143-1<br></i></b>In June 2005, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB) issued Staff Position No. 143-1, &#147;Accounting for Electronic Equipment Waste Obligations&#148; (FSP 143-1).&#160; FSP 143-1 addresses the accounting for obligations associated with Directive 2002/96/EC on Waste Electrical and Electronic Equipment (the &#147;Directive&#148;) adopted by the European Union, and requires application of the provisions of SFAS No. 143 and FIN 47 as those standards relate to the Directive.&#160; This FSP is effective the later of the first reporting period ending after June 8, 2005, or the date of adoption of the Directive by the individual EU-member countries.&#160;&#160; There have been no material impacts on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements resulting from the adoption of this FSP in those countries for which the Directive has been adopted, and there are no material impacts expected in the future from the

adoption of the Directive in the remaining EU-member countries.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>FASB Interpretation No.
47<br></i></b>In March 2005, the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No. 47,
&#147;Accounting for Conditional Asset Retirement Obligations&#148; (FIN
47).&#160; FIN 47 clarifies that the term &#147;conditional asset retirement
obligation&#148; as used in FASB No. 143, &#147;Accounting for Asset Retirement
Obligations,&#148; refers to a legal obligation to perform an asset retirement
activity in which the timing and/or method of settlement are conditional on a
future event that may or may not be within the control of the Company.&#160; In
addition, FIN 47 clarifies when a company would have sufficient information to
reasonably estimate the fair value of an asset retirement obligation.&#160;<BR>
The Company adopted FIN 47 during the fourth quarter of 2005.&#160; FIN 47
requires that conditional asset retirement obligations, legal obligations to
perform an asset retirement activity in which the timing and/(or) method of
settlement are conditional on a future event, be reported, along with associated
capitalized asset retirement costs, at their fair values.&#160; Upon initial
application, FIN 47 requires recognition of (1) a liability, adjusted for
cumulative accretion from the date the obligation was incurred until the date of
adoption of FIN 47, for existing asset retirement obligations; (2) an asset
retirement cost capitalized as an increase to the carrying amount of the
associated long-lived asset; and (3) accumulated depreciation on the capitalized
asset retirement cost.&#160; Accordingly, the Company has recognized the
following amounts in its Statement of Financial Position at December 31, 2005
and Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005:</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The adoption of FIN 47 reduced 2005 net earnings by $57 million, or $.20 per share.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s conditional asset retirement obligations primarily relate to asbestos contained in buildings that Kodak owns.&#160; Environmental regulations exist in many of the countries that Kodak operates in that require Kodak to handle and dispose of asbestos in a special manner if a building undergoes major renovations or is demolished.&#160; Otherwise, Kodak is not required to remove the asbestos from its buildings.&#160; Kodak records a liability equal to the estimated fair value of its obligation to perform asset retirement activities related to the asbestos, computed using an expected present value technique, when sufficient information exists to calculate the fair value.&#160; Kodak does not have a liability recorded related to each building that contains asbestos because Kodak cannot estimate the fair value of its obligation for certain buildings due to a lack of sufficient information about the range of time over which the obligation may be settled

through demolition, renovation or sale of the building.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has determined the pro forma (loss) earnings from continuing operations, net (loss) earnings, and corresponding per share information as if the provisions of FIN 47 had been adopted prior to January 1, 2003.&#160; The pro forma information is as follows:</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Reconciliations for the years ended December 31, 2004 and December 31, 2003 are not shown due to immateriality.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>FASB Statement No. 123R<br></i></b>In December 2004, the FASB issued Statement No. 123R, &#147;Share-Based Payment,&#148; a revision to SFAS No. 123, &#147;Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation.&#148;&#160; SFAS No. 123R eliminates the alternative to record compensation expense using the intrinsic value method of accounting under Accounting Principles Board Opinion No. 25 (APB No. 25) that was provided in SFAS No. 123 as originally issued. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under Opinion 25, issuing stock options to employees generally resulted in the recognition of no compensation cost if the options were granted with an exercise price equal to their fair value at the date of grant.&#160; SFAS No. 123R requires companies to measure and record the cost of employee services received in exchange for an award of equity instruments based on the fair value of the award at the date of grant (with limited exceptions).&#160; That cost will be recognized over the period during which an employee is required to provide service in exchange for the award (usually the vesting period).&#160; No compensation cost is recognized for equity instruments for which employees do not render the requisite service.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In April 2005, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted to change the effective date of SFAS No. 123R to fiscal years starting after June 15, 2005; however, early application is encouraged.&#160; The Company adopted the modified version of the prospective application of SFAS No. 123R as of January 1, 2005 under which the Company is required to recognize compensation expense, over the applicable vesting period, based on the fair value of (1) any unvested awards subject to SFAS No. 123R existing as of January 1, 2005, and (2) any new awards granted subsequent to the adoption date.&#160; Refer to the &#147;Stock-Based Compensation&#148; section under Note 1 above for the effect of adoption on the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>FASB Statement No. 151<br></i></b>In December 2004, the FASB issued SFAS No. 151, &#147;Inventory Costs&#148; that amends the guidance in Accounting Research Bulletin No. 43, Chapter 4, &#147;Inventory Pricing,&#148; (ARB No. 43) to clarify the accounting for abnormal idle facility expense, freight, handling costs and wasted material (spoilage). &#160;In addition, this Statement requires that an allocation of fixed production overhead to the costs of conversion be based on the normal capacity of the production facilities.&#160; SFAS No. 151 is effective for inventory costs incurred for fiscal years beginning after June 15, 2005 (year ending December 31, 2006 for the Company).&#160; The Company does not expect the implementation of SFAS No. 151 to have a material impact on its financial statements. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 98</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>FASB Staff Position No. 109-2<br></i></b>In December 2004, FASB issued FSP No. 109-2, &#147;Accounting and Disclosure Guidance for the Foreign Earnings Repatriation Provision within the American Jobs Creation Act of 2004 (the &#147;Act&#148;).&#148;&#160; The Act was signed into law in October of 2004.&#160; The Act creates a temporary incentive for U.S. multinationals to repatriate foreign subsidiary earnings by providing an 85% dividends received deduction for certain dividends from controlled foreign corporations.&#160; The deduction is subject to a number of limitations and requirements, including adoption of a specific domestic reinvestment plan for the repatriated earnings.&#160; Accordingly, the FSP provides guidance on accounting for income taxes that relate to the accounting treatment for unremitted earnings in a foreign investment (a consolidated subsidiary or corporate joint venture that is essentially permanent in nature).&#160; Further, the FSP
permits a company time beyond the financial reporting period of enactment to evaluate the effect of the Act on its plan for reinvestment or repatriation of foreign earnings for purposes of applying FASB Statement No. 109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes.&#148;&#160; Accordingly, an enterprise that has not yet completed its evaluation of the repatriation provision for purposes of applying Statement 109 is required to disclose certain information, for each period for which financial statements covering periods affected by the Act are presented.&#160; Subsequently, the total effect on income tax expense (or benefit) for amounts that have been recognized under the repatriation provision must be provided in a company&#146;s financial statements for the period in which it completes its evaluation of the repatriation provision. The provisions of FSP 109-2 were effective in the fourth quarter of 2004.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In 2005, the Company completed its evaluation of the repatriation provision and repatriated approximately $580 million of gross qualifying dividends subject to the 85% dividends received deduction.&#160; Accordingly, the Company recorded a corresponding tax provision of approximately $29 million in 2005 with respect to such dividends.&#160; See Note 15, &#147;Income Taxes,&#148; for further disclosure.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 99</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Inventories costed on the LIFO method are approximately 33% and 35% of total inventories in 2005 and 2004, respectively.&#160; During 2005 and 2004, inventory usage resulted in liquidations of LIFO inventory quantities.&#160; In the aggregate, these inventories were carried at the lower costs prevailing in prior years as compared with the cost of current purchases.&#160; The effect of these LIFO liquidations was to reduce cost of goods sold by $31 million and $69 million in 2005 and 2004, respectively.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company reduces the carrying value of inventories to a lower of cost or market basis for those items that are potentially excess, obsolete or slow-moving based on management&#146;s analysis of inventory levels and future sales forecasts.&#160; The Company also reduces the carrying value of inventories with net book value in excess of market value.&#160; Aggregate reductions in the carrying value with respect to inventories that were still on hand at December 31, 2005 and 2004, and that were deemed to be excess, obsolete, slow-moving or that had a carrying value in excess of market, were $148 million and $100 million, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On January 1, 2006, the Company elected to change its method of costing its U.S. inventories to the FIFO method, whereas in all prior years most of Kodak&#146;s inventory in the U.S. was costed using the LIFO method.&#160; The new method of accounting for inventory in the U.S. was adopted because the FIFO method will provide for a better matching of revenue and expenses given the rapid technological change in the Company&#146;s products.&#160; The FIFO method will also better reflect the cost of inventory on the Company&#146;s Statement of Financial Position.&#160; Prior periods will be restated in future financial statements for comparative purposes in order to reflect the impact of this change in methodology from LIFO to FIFO.&#160; </font></p>
<p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Depreciation expense was $1,281 million, $964 million and $839 million for the years 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, of which approximately $391 million, $183 million and $70 million, respectively, represented accelerated depreciation in connection with restructuring actions. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During 2005, the Company revised the useful lives of certain property, plant and equipment.&#160; Refer to &#147;Change In Estimate&#148; section of Note 1 for further information regarding the useful life change, and refer to the &#147;Properties&#148; section of Note 1 for information regarding the Company&#146;s current useful lives of its property, plant and equipment assets.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The aggregate amount of goodwill acquired during 2005 of $741 million was attributable to $462 for the purchase of Creo, $247 million for the purchase of the remaining 50% of KPG previously owned by Sun Chemical Corporation, both in the Graphic Communications Group segment; and $32 million for the purchase of OREX in the Health Group segment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The gross carrying amount and accumulated amortization by major intangible asset category for 2005 and 2004 were as follows:</font></p>

  <td  colspan="8"  valign="bottom">

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The aggregate amount of intangible assets acquired during 2005 of $445 million was attributable to $77 million of customer-related intangible assets, $45 million of technology-based intangible assets, and $21 million of miscellaneous other intangible assets for the purchase of KPG; $110 million of customer-related intangible assets, $136 million of technology-based intangible assets, and $10 million of miscellaneous other intangible assets for the purchase of Creo; $4 million of customer-related intangible assets and $9 million of technology-based intangible assets for the purchase of OREX; $26 million of other technology-based intangible assets; and $7 million of manufacturing exclusivity intangible assets related to Lucky Film.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Amortization expense related to intangible assets was $125 million, $67 million and $28 million in 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Estimated future amortization expense related to purchased intangible assets at December 31, 2005 is as follows (in millions):</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The miscellaneous component above consists of other miscellaneous long-term assets that, individually, are less than 5% of the Company&#146;s total long-term assets, and therefore, have been aggregated in accordance with Regulation S-X.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005 and 2004, the carrying value of the Company&#146;s equity investment in these significant unconsolidated affiliates was $26 million and $488 million, respectively, and is reported within other long-term assets in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position.&#160; The Company records its equity in the income or losses of these investees and reports such amounts in other income (charges), net, in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations.&#160; See Note 14, &#147;Other Income (Charges), Net.&#148;&#160; Other than KPG, these investments do not meet the Regulation S-X significance test requiring the inclusion of the separate investee financial statements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Through April 1, 2005, the Company held a 50% interest in Kodak Polychrome Graphics (KPG).&#160; This joint venture between the Company and Sun Chemical Corporation was accounted for using the equity method of accounting.&#160; Therefore, the acquisition of KPG in 2005 is the primary reason for the year-over-year decrease in the carrying value of the Company&#146;s equity investment in its unconsolidated affiliates.&#160; On April 1, 2005, the Company acquired Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s 50% interest in KPG, which resulted in KPG becoming a wholly owned and fully consolidated subsidiary of the Company, operating within the Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160; See Note 21, &#147;Acquisitions&#148; for further discussion regarding the KPG acquisition.&#160; </font></p>

</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Full financial statements for the years ended December 31, 2004, 2003 and 2002 and as of December 31, 2004 and 2003 for KPG have been included as an exhibit to this Form 10-K.&#160; In addition, unaudited information for the interim periods ended March 31, 2005 and 2004 has also been included as an exhibit to this Form 10-K.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company&#146;s investment in Express Stop Financing (ESF), a joint venture partnership between the Company&#146;s Qualex subsidiary and a subsidiary of Dana Credit Corporation, was dissolved.&#160; During the first quarter of 2005, the Company received a distribution from the joint venture liquidating its investment balance.&#160; There was no material impact on the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows from the dissolution of the ESF investment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In January 2006, Kodak terminated the SK Display joint venture arrangement with Sanyo Electric Company pursuant to terms of the original agreement.&#160; This termination will not have a material impact on the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.&#160; Kodak will continue as exclusive licensing agent on behalf of Kodak and Sanyo for certain OLED intellectual property.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Kodak has no other material activities with its equity method investees.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Cost Method -</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company also has certain investments with less than a 20% ownership interest in various private companies whereby the Company does not have the ability to exercise significant influence.&#160; These investments are accounted for under the cost method.&#160; The remaining carrying value of the Company&#146;s investments accounted for under the cost method at December 31, 2005 and 2004 of $22 million and $19 million, respectively, is included in other long-term assets in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position.</font></p>

</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The weighted-average interest rates for short-term bank borrowings outstanding at December 31, 2005 and 2004 were 5.82% and 5.02%, respectively.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, the Company and its subsidiaries, on a consolidated basis, maintained $1,132 million in committed bank lines of credit and $773 million in uncommitted bank lines of credit to ensure continued access to short-term borrowing capacity. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has other committed and uncommitted lines of credit at December 31, 2005 totaling $132 million and $773 million, respectively.&#160; These lines primarily support borrowing needs of the Company&#146;s subsidiaries, which include term loans, overdraft coverage, letters of credit and revolving credit lines.&#160; Interest rates and other terms of borrowing under these lines of credit vary from country to country, depending on local market conditions.&#160; Total outstanding borrowings against these other committed and uncommitted lines of credit at December 31, 2005 were $34 million and $65 million, respectively.&#160; These outstanding borrowings are reflected in the short-term borrowings in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position at December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Accounts Receivable Securitization Program<br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s $200 million Accounts Receivable Securitization Program was terminated on October 18, 2005 when the Company closed on $2.7 billion of Secured Credit Facilities under the new Secured Credit Agreement and associated Canadian Security Agreement.</font></p>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 105</font></p>

<table  width="100%"  border="0" align="center"  cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="border-collapse:collapse">
  <tr>
    <td valign="top"><hr size="1"  align="Left" width="25%" noshade color=black>

  <tr>
    <td valign="top"><p> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">*&#160; Represents debt with a variable interest rate.</font></p>      </td>
  </tr>
</table>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Annual maturities (in millions) of long-term debt outstanding at December 31, 2005 are as follows: $706 in 2006, $8 in 2007, $274 in 2008, $35 in 2009, $36 in 2010 and $2,411 in 2011 and beyond.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Secured Credit Facilities<br>
</i></b></font> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On October 18, 2005 the Company closed on
$2.7 billion of Senior Secured Credit Facilities (Secured Credit Facilities)
under a new Secured Credit Agreement (Secured Credit Agreement) and associated
Security Agreement and Canadian Security Agreement. The Secured Credit
Facilities consist of a $1.0 billion 5-Year Committed Revolving Credit Facility
(5-Year Revolving Credit Facility) expiring October 18, 2010 and $1.7 billion of
Term Loan Facilities (Term Facilities) expiring October 18, 2012.&#160;</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The 5-Year Revolving Credit Facility can be used by Eastman Kodak Company (U.S. Borrower) for general corporate purposes including the issuance of letters of credit.&#160; Amounts available under the facility can be borrowed, repaid and re-borrowed throughout the term of the facility provided the Company remains in compliance with covenants contained in the Secured Credit Agreement.&#160; At closing, there was no debt outstanding and approximately $111 million of letters of credit issued under this facility.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 106</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under the Term Facilities, $1.2 billion
was borrowed at closing primarily to refinance debt originally issued under the
Company&#146;s previous $1.225 billion 5-Year Facility to finance the
acquisition of Creo Inc. on June 15, 2005.&#160; The $1.2 billion consists of a
$920 million 7-Year Term Loan to the U.S. Borrower and a $280 million 7-Year
Term Loan to Kodak Graphic Communications Canada Company (KGCCC or, the Canadian
Borrower).&#160; The remaining $500 million under the Term Facilities is
committed by the Lenders and available to the U.S. Borrower, through June 15,
2006.&#160; For this $500 million commitment, a 1.50% annual fee is paid on the
unused amount to the Lenders.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, $920 million of the
7-Year Term Loan to the U.S. Borrower and $280 million of the 7-Year Term Loan
to the Canadian Borrower were outstanding.&#160; In connection with the Secured
Credit Facilities, the Company incurred approximately $57 million of debt issue
costs.&#160; These costs have been recorded as an asset and are being amortized
over the term of the Secured Credit Facilities.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition to the $2.7 billion of
Secured Credit Facilities, the Secured Credit Agreement allows for up to an
additional $500 million for a new secured credit loan based on terms and pricing
available and agreed to at the time the new credit loan would be
established.&#160; There are no fees for this feature.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pursuant to the Secured Credit Agreement and associated Security Agreement, each subsidiary organized in the U.S. jointly and severally guarantees the obligations under the Secured Credit Agreement and all other obligations of the Company and its subsidiaries to the Lenders.&#160; The guaranty is supported by the pledge of certain U.S. assets of the U.S. Borrower and the Company&#146;s U.S. subsidiaries including, but not limited to, receivables, inventory, equipment, deposit accounts, investments, intellectual property, including patents, trademarks and copyrights, and the capital stock of Material Subsidiaries.&#160; Excluded from pledged assets are real property, &#147;Principal Properties&#148; and equity interests in &#147;Restricted Subsidiaries&#148;, as defined in the Company&#146;s 1988 Indenture.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Material Subsidiaries are defined as those subsidiaries with revenues or assets constituting 5 percent or more of the consolidated revenues or assets of the corresponding borrower.&#160; Material Subsidiaries will be determined on an annual basis under the Secured Credit Agreement.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Pursuant to the Secured Credit Agreement
and associated Canadian Security Agreement, Eastman Kodak Company and Kodak
Graphic Communications Company (KGCC, formerly Creo Americas, Inc.), jointly and
severally guarantee the obligations of the Canadian Borrower, to the
Lenders.&#160; Certain assets of the Canadian Borrower in Canada were also
pledged in support of its obligations, including, but not limited to,
receivables, inventory, equipment, deposit accounts, investments, intellectual
property, including patents, trademarks and copyrights, and the capital stock of
the Canadian Borrower&#146;s Material Subsidiaries.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest rates for borrowings under the Secured Credit Agreement are dependent on the Company&#146;s Long Term Senior Secured Credit Rating.&#160; The Secured Credit Agreement contains various affirmative and negative covenants customary in a facility of this type, including two quarterly financial covenants: (1) a consolidated earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization (EBITDA) to consolidated interest expense (subject to adjustments to exclude interest expense not related to borrowed money) ratio, on a rolling four-quarter basis, of no less than 3 to 1, and (2) a consolidated debt for borrowed money to consolidated EBITDA (subject to adjustments to exclude any extraordinary income or losses, as defined by the Secured Credit Agreement, interest income and certain non-cash items of income and expense) ratio of not greater than:&#160; 4.75 to 1 as of December 31, 2005; 4.50 to 1 as of March 31, 2006; 4.25 to 1 as of June 30, 2006; 4.00 to 1 as
of Septe

mber 30, 2006; and 3.50 to 1 as of December 31, 2006 and thereafter.&#160; As of December 31, 2005,
the Company was in compliance with all covenants under the Secured Credit Agreement.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition, subject to various conditions and exceptions in the Secured Credit Agreement, in the event the Company sells assets for net proceeds totaling $75 million or more in any year, except for proceeds used within 12 months for reinvestments in the business of up to $300 million, proceeds from sales of assets used in the Company&#146;s non-digital products and services businesses to prepay or repay debt or pay cash restructuring charges within 12 months from the date of sale of the assets, or proceeds from the sale of inventory in the ordinary course of business, the amount in excess of $75 million must be applied to prepay loans under the Secured Credit Agreement.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 107</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">If unused, the 5-Year Revolving Credit Facility has a commitment fee of $5.0 million per year at the Company&#146;s current credit rating of Ba3 and B+ from Moody&#146;s Investor Services, Inc. (Moody&#146;s) and Standard &amp; Poor&#146;s Rating Services (S&amp;P), respectively.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At the closing of the Secured Credit Agreement, the Company terminated its previous $1.225 billion 5-Year Facility, a $160 million revolving credit facility established by KPG, and the Company&#146;s $200 million Accounts Receivable Securitization Program.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had outstanding letters of credit totaling $117 million and surety bonds in the amount of $85 million primarily to ensure the payment of casualty claims, workers&#146; compensation claims, and customs. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>KPG Notes</i></b></font><BR>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In connection with the April 1, 2005 redemption of Sun Chemical Corporations&#146; (Sun) 50 percent interest in the KPG joint venture, the Company entered into two non-interest bearing note payable arrangements with Sun.&#160; One note is payable in the U.S. (the U.S. note) and the other is payable outside the U.S. (the non-U.S. note).&#160; The U.S. note requires payments of $40 million in 2006 and $10 million in the years 2008-2013.&#160; The non-U.S. note requires payments of $160 million in 2006 and $40 million in the years 2008-2013.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As these notes are non-interest bearing, interest has been imputed at a rate of 6.16% based on the Company&#146;s borrowing rate for debt with similar maturities from third-party financial institutions.&#160; Therefore, the present value of the U.S. note and the non-U.S. note were $83 million and $331 million, respectively, at December 31, 2005.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Debt Shelf Registration and Convertible Securities<br>
</i></b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In May 2003, the Company issued Series A fixed rate medium-term notes under its then existing debt shelf registration totaling $250 million, as follows:</font></p>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(in millions)</font></p>

 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td width="54%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Series A fixed rate</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="3%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p  align=right> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">250</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p  align=right> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">3.625</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">%</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p  align=center> <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">May 2008</font></p></td>
  <td  valign="bottom"><p> <font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p></td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Interest on the notes will be paid quarterly, and the Company may not redeem or repay these notes prior to their stated maturities.&#160; After this issuance, the Company had $650 million of remaining unsold debt securities under its then existing debt shelf registration. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On September 5, 2003, the Company filed a shelf registration statement on Form S-3 (the primary debt shelf registration) for the issuance of up to $2.0 billion of new debt securities.&#160; The primary debt shelf registration became effective on September 19, 2003.&#160; Pursuant to Rule 429 under the Securities Act of 1933, $650 million of remaining unsold debt securities under a prior shelf registration statement were included in the primary debt shelf registration, thus giving the Company the ability to issue up to $2.65 billion in public debt.&#160; After issuance of $500 million in notes in October 2003, the remaining availability under the primary debt shelf registration was at $2.15 billion.&#160; The Company filed its 2004 Form 10-K on April 6, 2005, which was late relative to the SEC required filing date (including extension) of March 31, 2005.&#160; The Company also completed the filing of a Form 8-K/A related to the acquisition of KPG on July 1, 2005,
which was late in relation to the SEC required filing date of June 17, 2005.&#160; As a result of these late filings, the Company&#146;s primary debt shelf registration statement on Form S-3 will not be available until the third quarter of 2006.&#160; In the event the Company wanted to issue registered securities, the Company could use Form S-1 or a Rule 144A transaction to issue securities in the capital markets.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 108</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On October 10, 2003, the Company completed the offering and sale of $500 million aggregate principal amount of Senior Notes due 2013 (the Notes), which was made pursuant to the Company&#146;s new debt shelf registration.&#160; The remaining unused balance under the Company&#146;s new debt shelf is $2.15 billion.&#160; Concurrent with the offering and sale of the Notes, on October 10, 2003, the Company completed the private placement of $575 million aggregate principal amount of Convertible Senior Notes due 2033 (the Convertible Securities) to qualified institutional buyers pursuant to Rule 144A under the Securities Act of 1933.&#160; Interest on the Convertible Securities will accrue at the rate of 3.375% per annum and is payable semiannually.&#160; The Convertible Securities are unsecured and rank equally with all of the Company&#146;s other unsecured and unsubordinated indebtedness.&#160; As a condition of the private placement, on January 6, 2004 the Company
filed a shelf registration statement under the Securities Act of 1933 relating to the resale of the Convertible Securities and the common stock to be issued upon conversion of the Convertible Securities pursuant to a registration rights agreement, and made this shelf registration statement effective on February 6, 2004. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Convertible Securities contain a number of conversion features that include substantive contingencies.&#160; The Convertible Securities are convertible by the holders at an initial conversion rate of 32.2373 shares of the Company&#146;s common stock for each $1,000 principal amount of the Convertible Securities, which is equal to an initial conversion price of $31.02 per share.&#160; The initial conversion rate of 32.2373 is subject to adjustment for: (1) stock dividends, (2) subdivisions or combinations of the Company&#146;s common stock, (3) issuance to all holders of the Company&#146;s common stock of certain rights or warrants to purchase shares of the Company&#146;s common stock at less than the market price, (4) distributions to all holders of the Company&#146;s common stock of shares of the Company&#146;s capital stock or the Company&#146;s assets or evidences of indebtedness, (5) cash dividends in excess of the Company&#146;s current cash dividends,

or (6) certain payments made by the Company in connection with tender offers and exchange offers. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The holders may convert their Convertible
Securities, in whole or in part, into shares of the Company&#146;s common stock
under any of the following circumstances:&#160; (1) during any calendar quarter,
if the price of the Company&#146;s common stock is greater than or equal to 120%
of the applicable conversion price for at least 20 trading days during a 30
consecutive trading day period ending on the last trading day of the previous
calendar quarter; (2) during any five consecutive trading day period following
any 10 consecutive trading day period in which the trading price of the
Convertible Securities for each day of such period is less than 105% of the
conversion value, and the conversion value for each day of such period was less
than 95% of the principal amount of the Convertible Securities (the Parity
Clause); (3) if the Company has called the Convertible Securities for
redemption; (4) upon the occurrence of specified corporate transactions such as
a consolidation, merger or binding share exchange pursuant to which the
Company&#146;s common stock would be converted into cash, property or
securities; and (5) if the Senior Unsecured credit rating assigned to the
Convertible Securities by either Moody&#146;s or S&amp;P is lower than Ba2 or
BB, respectively, or if the Convertible Securities are no longer rated by at
least one of these services or their successors (the Credit Rating
Clause).&#160; At the Company&#146;s current credit rating, the Convertible
Securities may be converted by their holders.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company may redeem some or all of the Convertible Securities at any time on or after October 15, 2010 at a purchase price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Convertible Securities plus any accrued and unpaid interest.&#160; Upon a call for redemption by the Company, a conversion trigger is met whereby the holder of each $1,000 Convertible Senior Note may convert such note to shares of the Company&#146;s common stock.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The holders have the right to require the Company to purchase their Convertible Securities for cash at a purchase price equal to 100% of the principal amount of the Convertible Securities plus any accrued and unpaid interest on October 15, 2010, October 15, 2013, October 15, 2018, October 15, 2023 and October 15, 2028, or upon a fundamental change as described in the offering memorandum filed under Rule 144A in conjunction with the private placement of the Convertible Securities.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, the Company has reserved 18,536,447 shares in treasury stock to cover potential future conversions of these Convertible Securities into common stock.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 109</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Certain of the conversion features contained in the Convertible Securities are deemed to be embedded derivatives as defined under SFAS No. 133, &#147;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities.&#148;&#160; These embedded derivatives include the Parity Clause, the Credit Rating Clause, and any specified corporate transaction outside of the Company&#146;s control such as a hostile takeover.&#160; Based on an external valuation, these embedded derivatives were not material to the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.&#160; </font></p>
<p>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">7</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">8</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Site   remediation costs</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">3</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  style="margin-left:3em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Total</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">88</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">85</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">84</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005 and 2004, the Company&#146;s undiscounted accrued liabilities for environmental remediation costs amounted to $171 million and $153 million, respectively.&#160; These amounts are reported in other long-term liabilities in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is currently implementing a Corrective Action Program required by the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) at the Kodak Park site in Rochester, NY.&#160; As part of this program, the Company has completed the RCRA Facility Assessment (RFA), a broad-based environmental investigation of the site.&#160; The Company is currently in the process of completing, and in some cases has completed, RCRA Facility Investigations (RFI) and Corrective Measures Studies (CMS) for areas at the site.&#160; At December 31, 2005, estimated future investigation and remediation costs of $67 million are accrued for this site and are included in the $171 million reported in other long-term liabilities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company announced the closing of four manufacturing facilities outside the United States in 2004 and 2005.&#160; The Company has obligations with estimated future investigation, remediation and monitoring costs of $27 million at three of these facilities.&#160; There were no such costs associated with the fourth facility.&#160; At December 31, 2005, these costs are accrued and included in the $171 million reported in other long-term liabilities.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 110</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has obligations relating to other operating sites and former operations with estimated future investigation, remediation and monitoring costs of $25 million.&#160; At December 31, 2005, these costs are accrued and included in the $171 million reported in other long-term liabilities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has completed its acquisition of KPG through the redemption of Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s 50 percent interest in the joint venture.&#160; The Company also completed its acquisition of Creo.&#160; As a result of the two acquisitions, the Company has obligations with estimated future investigation, remediation and monitoring costs of $29 million.&#160; The closure of a plant located in West Virginia was announced in the third quarter with remediation at a cost of $24 million and is included in the $29 million.&#160; At December 31, 2005, these costs are accrued and included in the $171 million reported in other long-term liabilities.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has retained certain obligations for environmental remediation and Superfund matters related to certain sites associated with the non-imaging health businesses sold in 1994.&#160; At December 31, 2005, estimated future remediation costs of $23 million are accrued for these sites and are included in the $171 million reported in other long-term liabilities.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Cash expenditures for the aforementioned investigation, remediation and monitoring activities are expected to be incurred over the next thirty years for many of the sites.&#160; For these known environmental liabilities, the accrual reflects the Company&#146;s best estimate of the amount it will incur under the agreed-upon or proposed work plans.&#160; The Company&#146;s cost estimates were determined using the ASTM Standard E 2137-01, &#147;Standard Guide for Estimating Monetary Costs and Liabilities for Environmental Matters,&#148; and have not been reduced by possible recoveries from third parties.&#160; The overall method includes the use of a probabilistic model which forecasts a range of cost estimates for the remediation required at individual sites.&#160; The projects are closely monitored and the models are reviewed as significant events occur or at least once per year.&#160; The Company&#146;s estimate includes equipment and operating costs for
remediation and long-term monitoring of the sites.&#160; The Company does not believe it is reasonably possible that the losses for the known exposures could exceed the current accruals by material amounts.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A Consent Decree was signed in 1994 in settlement of a civil complaint brought by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and the U.S. Department of Justice. &#160;In connection with the Consent Decree, the Company is subject to a Compliance Schedule, under which the Company has improved its waste characterization procedures, upgraded one of its incinerators, and is evaluating and upgrading its industrial sewer system.&#160; The total expenditures required to complete this program are currently estimated to be approximately $2 million over the next four years.&#160; These expenditures are incurred as part of plant operations and, therefore, are not included in the environmental accrual at December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is presently designated as a potentially responsible party (PRP) under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation and Liability Act of 1980, as amended (the Superfund Law), or under similar state laws, for environmental assessment and cleanup costs as the result of the Company&#146;s alleged arrangements for disposal of hazardous substances at five Superfund sites.&#160; With respect to each of these sites, the Company&#146;s liability is minimal.&#160; In addition, the Company has been identified as a PRP in connection with the non-imaging health businesses in four active Superfund sites.&#160; Numerous other PRPs have also been designated at these sites.&#160; Although the law imposes joint and several liability on PRPs, the Company&#146;s historical experience demonstrates that these costs are shared with other PRPs.&#160; Settlements and costs paid by the Company in Superfund matters to date have not been material.&#160; Future costs
are also not expected to be material to the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Clean Air Act Amendments were enacted in 1990.&#160; Expenditures to comply with the Clean Air Act implementing regulations issued to date have not been material and have been primarily capital in nature.&#160; In addition, future expenditures for existing regulations, which are primarily capital in nature, are not expected to be material.&#160; Many of the regulations to be promulgated pursuant to this Act have not been issued.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 111</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Uncertainties associated with environmental remediation contingencies are pervasive and often result in wide ranges of outcomes.&#160; Estimates developed in the early stages of remediation can vary significantly.&#160; A finite estimate of costs does not normally become fixed and determinable at a specific time.&#160; Rather, the costs associated with environmental remediation become estimable over a continuum of events and activities that help to frame and define a liability, and the Company continually updates its cost estimates.&#160; The Company has an ongoing monitoring and identification process to assess how the activities, with respect to the known exposures, are progressing against the accrued cost estimates, as well as to identify other potential remediation sites that are presently unknown.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Estimates of the amount and timing of future costs of environmental remediation requirements are by their nature imprecise because of the continuing evolution of environmental laws and regulatory requirements, the availability and application of technology, the identification of presently unknown remediation sites and the allocation of costs among the potentially responsible parties.&#160; Based upon information presently available, such future costs are not expected to have a material effect on the Company&#146;s competitive or financial position.&#160; However, such costs could be material to results of operations in a particular future quarter or year.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Additionally, as of December 31, 2005, the Company has recorded approximately $66 million of asset retirement obligations in its Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, primarily related to asbestos removal costs.&#160; Refer to discussion of the implementation of FASB Interpretation No. 47 in Note 1 for further information.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Other Commitments and Contingencies<br>
</b></font>
  <font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has entered into agreements with several companies, which provide Kodak with products and services to be used in its normal operations.&#160; These agreements are related to supplies, production and administrative services, as well as marketing and advertising.&#160; The terms of these agreements cover the next two to sixteen years.&#160; The minimum payments for these agreements are approximately $204 million in 2006, $200 million in 2007, $173 million in 2008, $98 million in 2009, $105 million in 2010 and $241 million in 2011 and thereafter.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had outstanding letters of credit totaling $117 million and surety bonds in the amount of $85 million primarily to ensure the completion of payment of possible casualty claims, workers&#146; compensation claims, and customs.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Rental expense, net of minor sublease income, amounted to $149 million in 2005, $161 in 2004 and $157 million in 2003.&#160; The approximate amounts of noncancelable lease commitments with terms of more than one year, principally for the rental of real property, reduced by minor sublease income, are $138 million in 2006, $120 million in 2007, $98 million in 2008, $75 million in 2009, $58 million in 2010 and $80 million in 2011 and thereafter.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In December 2003, the Company sold a property in France for approximately $65 million, net of direct selling costs, and then leased back a portion of this property for a nine-year term.&#160; In accordance with SFAS No. 98, &#147;Accounting for Leases,&#148; the entire gain on the property sale of approximately $57 million was deferred and no gain was recognizable upon the closing of the sale as the Company&#146;s continuing involvement in the property is deemed to be significant.&#160; As a result, the Company is accounting for the transaction as a financing.&#160; Future minimum lease payments under this noncancelable lease commitment are approximately $5 million per year for 2006 through 2010, and approximately $10 million for 2011 and thereafter.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>


<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 112</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On March 8, 2004, the Company filed a complaint against Sony Corporation in federal district court in Rochester, New York, for digital camera patent infringement.&#160; Several weeks later, on March 31, 2004, Sony sued the Company for digital camera patent infringement in federal district court in Newark, New Jersey.&#160; Sony subsequently filed a second lawsuit against the Company in Newark, New Jersey, alleging infringement of a variety of other Sony patents.&#160; The Company filed a counterclaim in the New Jersey action, asserting infringement by Sony of the Company&#146;s kiosk patents.&#160; The Company successfully moved to transfer Sony&#146;s New Jersey digital camera patent infringement case to Rochester, New York, and the two digital camera patent infringement cases are now consolidated for purposes of discovery.&#160; In June 2005, the federal district court in Rochester, New York appointed a special master to assist the court with discovery and the
claims construction briefing process.&#160; Based on the current discovery schedule, the Company expects that claims construction hearings in the digital camera cases will take place in 2006.&#160; Both the Company and Sony Corporation seek unspecified damages and other relief.&#160; Although this lawsuit may result in the Company&#146;s recovery of damages, the amount of the damages, if any, cannot be quantified at this time.&#160; Accordingly, the Company has not recognized any gain or loss in the financial statements as of December 31, 2005, in connection with this matter. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 13, 2005, a purported shareholder class action lawsuit was filed against the Company and two of its current executives in the United States District Court for the Southern District of New York.&#160; On June 20, 2005 and August 10, 2005, similar lawsuits were filed against the same defendants in the United States District Court for the Western District of New York.&#160; The cases have been consolidated in the Western District of New York and the lead plaintiffs are John Dudek and the Alaska Electrical Pension Fund.&#160; The complaints filed in each of these actions (collectively, the &#147;Complaints&#148;) seek to allege claims under the Securities Exchange Act on behalf of a proposed class of persons who purchased securities of the Company between April 23, 2003 and September 25, 2003, inclusive.&#160; The substance of the Complaints is that various press releases and other public statements made by the Company during the proposed class period
allegedly misrepresented the Company&#146;s financial condition and omitted material information regarding, among other things, the state of the Company&#146;s film and paper business.&#160; An amended complaint was filed on January 20, 2006, containing essentially the same allegations as the original complaint but adding an additional named defendant. Defendants&#146; initial responses to the Complaints are not yet due.&#160; The Company intends to defend these lawsuits vigorously but is unable currently to predict the outcome of the litigation or to estimate the range of potential loss, if any.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On or about November 9, 2005, the Company was served with a purported derivative lawsuit that had been commenced against the Company, as a nominal defendant, and eleven current and former directors and officers of the Company, in the New York State Supreme Court, Monroe County.&#160; The Complaint seeks to allege claims on behalf of the Company that, between April 2003 and September 2003, the defendant officers and directors caused the Company to make allegedly improper statements, in press release and other public statements, which falsely represented or omitted material information about the Company&#146;s financial results and guidance.&#160; The plaintiff alleges that this conduct was a breach of the defendants&#146; common law fiduciary obligations to the Company, and constituted an abuse of control, gross mismanagement, waste and unjust enrichment.&#160; Defendants&#146; initial responses to the Complaint are not yet due.&#160; The Company intends to
defend this lawsuit vigorously but is unable currently to predict the outcome of the litigation or to estimate the range of possible loss, if any.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition to the matters described above, the Company and its subsidiary companies are involved in other lawsuits, claims, investigations and proceedings, including product liability, commercial, intellectual property, environmental, and health and safety matters, which are being handled and defended in the ordinary course of business.&#160; There are no such matters pending representing contingent losses that the Company and its General Counsel expect to be material in relation to the Company&#146;s business, financial position, results of operations or cash flows.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 113</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 12:&#160; GUARANTEES </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company guarantees debt and other obligations under agreements with certain affiliated companies and customers to ensure that financing is obtained to facilitate ongoing business operations and selling activities, respectively.&#160; At December 31, 2005, these guarantees totaled a maximum of $204 million, with outstanding guaranteed amounts of $134 million.&#160; The guarantees for the other unconsolidated affiliates and third party debt mature between 2006 and 2011.&#160; The customer financing agreements and related guarantees typically have a term of 90 days for product and short-term equipment financing arrangements, and up to five years for long-term equipment financing arrangements.&#160; These guarantees would require payment from Kodak only in the event of default on payment by the respective debtor.&#160; In some cases, particularly for guarantees related to equipment financing, the Company has collateral or recourse provisions to recover and sell
the equipment to reduce any losses that might be incurred in connection with the guarantees.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Management believes the likelihood is remote that material payments will be required under any of the guarantees disclosed above.&#160; With respect to the guarantees that the Company issued in the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company assessed the fair value of its obligation to stand ready to perform under these guarantees by considering the likelihood of occurrence of the specified triggering events or conditions requiring performance as well as other assumptions and factors.&#160; The Company has determined that the fair value of the guarantees was not material to the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company also guarantees debt owed to banks for some of its consolidated subsidiaries.&#160; The maximum amount guaranteed is $740 million, and the outstanding debt under those guarantees, which is recorded within the short-term borrowings and long-term debt, net of current portion components in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, is $109 million.&#160; These guarantees expire in 2006 through 2012.&#160; As of the closing of the $2.7 billion Secured Credit Facilities on October 18, 2005, a $160 million KPG credit facility was closed.&#160; Debt outstanding under the KPG credit facility of $57 million was repaid and the guarantees of $160 million were terminated.&#160; Pursuant to the terms of the Company&#146;s Senior Secured Credit Agreement dated October 18, 2005, obligations under the Secured Credit Facilities and other obligations of the Company and its subsidiaries to the Secured Credit Facilities lenders are guaranteed.&#160;
This accounts for the majority of the increase in the Company&#146;s guarantees to banks for its consolidated subsidiaries.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Indemnifications<br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company issues indemnifications in certain instances when it sells businesses and real estate, and in the ordinary course of business with its customers, suppliers, service providers and business partners.&#160; Further, the Company indemnifies its directors and officers who are, or were, serving at Kodak&#146;s request in such capacities.&#160; Historically, costs incurred to settle claims related to these indemnifications have not been material to the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows.&#160; Additionally, the fair value of the indemnifications that the Company issued during the year ended December 31, 2005 was not material to the Company&#146;s financial position, results of operations or cash flows. </font></p>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 114</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Warranty Costs <br>
</b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has warranty obligations in connection with the sale of its equipment.&#160; The original warranty period for equipment products is generally one year or less.&#160; The costs incurred to provide for these warranty obligations are estimated and recorded as an accrued liability at the time of sale.&#160; The Company estimates its warranty cost at the point of sale for a given product based on historical warranty experience and related costs to repair.&#160; The change in the Company&#146;s accrued warranty obligations balance, which is reflected in accounts payable and other current liabilities in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, was as follows: </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company also offers extended warranty arrangements to its customers that are generally one year, but may range from three months to three years after the original warranty period.&#160; The Company provides repair services and routine maintenance under these arrangements.&#160; The Company has not separated the extended warranty revenues and costs from the routine maintenance service revenues and costs, as it is not practicable to do so.&#160; The change in the Company&#146;s deferred revenue balance in relation to these extended warranty arrangements, which is reflected in accounts payable and other current liabilities in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, was as follows: </font></p>
