<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Marketable securities are valued at quoted market prices.&#160; The fair values of long-term borrowings are determined by reference to quoted market prices or by obtaining quotes from dealers.&#160; The fair values for the remaining financial instruments in the above table are based on dealer quotes and reflect the estimated amounts the Company would pay or receive to terminate the contracts.&#160; The carrying values of cash and cash equivalents, receivables, short-term borrowings and payables approximate their fair values.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company, as a result of its global operating and financing activities, is exposed to changes in foreign currency exchange rates, commodity prices and interest rates, which may adversely affect its results of operations and financial position.&#160; The Company manages such exposures, in part, with derivative financial instruments.&#160; The fair value of these derivative contracts is reported in other current assets or accounts payable and other current liabilities in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Financial Position.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Foreign currency forward contracts are used to hedge existing foreign currency denominated assets and liabilities, especially those of the Company&#146;s International Treasury Center, as well as forecasted foreign currency denominated intercompany sales.&#160; Silver forward contracts are used to mitigate the Company&#146;s risk to fluctuating silver prices.&#160; The Company&#146;s exposure to changes in interest rates results from its investing and borrowing activities used to meet its liquidity needs.&#160; Long-term debt is generally used to finance long-term investments, while short-term debt is used to meet working capital requirements.&#160; The Company does not utilize financial instruments for trading or other speculative purposes.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company enters into foreign currency forward contracts that are designated as cash flow hedges of exchange rate risk related to forecasted foreign currency denominated intercompany sales. Hedge gains and losses are reclassified into cost of goods sold as the inventory transferred in connection with the intercompany sales is sold to third parties. At December 31, 2005, the Company had no open foreign currency cash flow hedges.&#160; During 2005, gains of $11 million (pre-tax) were reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income to cost of goods sold.&#160; Hedge ineffectiveness was insignificant. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company does not apply hedge accounting to the foreign currency forward contracts used to offset currency-related changes in the fair value of foreign currency denominated assets and liabilities.&#160; These contracts are marked to market through net (loss) earnings at the same time that the exposed assets and liabilities are remeasured through net (loss) earnings (both in other income (charges), net).&#160; The majority of the contracts of this type held by the Company are denominated in euros.&#160; At December 31, 2005, the fair value of these open contracts was an unrealized gain of $1 million (pre-tax).</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has entered into silver forward contracts that are designated as cash flow hedges of price risk related to forecasted worldwide silver purchases.&#160; Hedge gains and losses are reclassified into cost of goods sold as silver-containing products are sold to third parties. At December 31, 2005, the Company had open forward contracts with maturities through April 2006. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 116</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the fair value of open silver forward contracts was an unrealized gain of&#160; $2 million (pre-tax), included in accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income.&#160; If this amount were to be realized, all of it would be reclassified into cost of goods sold during the next twelve months.&#160; Additionally, realized gains of $1 million (pre-tax), related to closed silver contracts, have been deferred in accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income.&#160; These gains will be reclassified into cost of goods sold within the next twelve months.&#160; During 2005, gains of $5 million&#160; (pre-tax) were reclassified from accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income to cost of goods sold.&#160; Hedge ineffectiveness was insignificant.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s financial instrument counterparties are high-quality investment or commercial banks with significant experience with such instruments.&#160; The Company manages exposure to counterparty credit risk by requiring specific minimum credit standards and diversification of counterparties.&#160; The Company has procedures to monitor the credit exposure amounts.&#160; The maximum credit exposure at December 31, 2005 was not significant to the Company.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 14:&#160; OTHER INCOME (CHARGES), NET </b></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 15:&#160; INCOME TAXES </b></font></p>

<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 117</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The differences between income taxes computed using the U.S. federal income tax rate and the provision (benefit) for income taxes for continuing operations were as follows:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="80%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>(in millions)</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2003</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td width="53%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Amount   computed using the statutory rate</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="11%" valign="bottom">

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Valuation Allowance - U.S.<br></i></b>During the third quarter of 2005, based on management&#146;s assessment of positive and negative evidence regarding the realization of the net deferred tax assets, the Company recorded a valuation allowance of approximately $900 million against its net U.S. deferred tax assets.&#160; In accordance with SFAS No. 109, &#147;Accounting for Income Taxes&#148; (SFAS 109), managements&#146; assessment included the evaluation of scheduled reversals of deferred tax assets and liabilities, estimates of projected future taxable income, carryback potential and tax planning strategies.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Prior to the Company&#146;s third quarter 2005 assessment of realizability, it was believed, based on available evidence including tax planning strategies, that the Company would more likely than not realize its net U.S. deferred tax assets.&#160; The third quarter 2005 assessment considered the following significant matters based upon some recent changes that occurred in the quarter:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In July 2005, management announced plans
to significantly accelerate its restructuring efforts and to significantly
reduce the assets supporting its traditional business by the end of 2007.&#160;
This global plan includes accelerating the reduction of traditional film assets
from $2.9 billion in January 2004 to approximately $1 billion by 2007 and
terminating approximately 10,000 employees.&#160; These actions will have a
negative impact on Kodak&#146;s ability to generate taxable income in the
U.S.</font></p>
</td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On October   18, 2005, the Company entered into a new secured credit facility pursuant to   which the borrowings in the U.S. are collateralized by certain U.S. assets,   including the Company&#146;s intellectual property assets.&#160; Thus, management determined that the   previous tax planning strategy to sell the U.S. intellectual property to a   foreign subsidiary to generate taxable income in the U.S. was no longer   prudent nor feasible and should not be relied upon as part of the third   quarter assessment of realizability of the Company&#146;s U.S. deferred tax   assets.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>



<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Based upon management&#146;s above-mentioned September 30, 2005 assessment of realizability, management concluded that it was no longer more likely than not that the U.S. net deferred tax assets would be realized and, as such, recorded a valuation allowance of approximately $900 million.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the fourth quarter of 2005, management updated its assessment of the realizability of its net deferred tax assets.&#160; As a result of management&#146;s assessment of positive and negative evidence regarding the realization of the net deferred tax assets, which included the evaluation of scheduled reversals of deferred tax assets and liabilities, estimates of projected future taxable income, carryback potential and tax planning strategies, the Company maintained that it was still no longer more likely than not that the U.S. net deferred tax assets would be realized and, as such, increased the valuation allowance by approximately $181 million relating to deferred tax benefits generated in the fourth quarter.&#160; In addition, the Company expects to record a valuation allowance on all U.S. tax benefits generated in the future until an appropriate level of profitability in the U.S. is sustained or until the Company is able to generate enough taxable income
through other tax planning strategies and transactions.&#160; Both the net deferred tax asset balances and the offsetting valuation allowance include estimates attributable to the recent acquisitions of KPG and Creo.&#160; Deferred tax amounts attributable to these businesses are expected to be finalized during 2006 with the completion of the Company&#146;s purchase accounting for these acquired entities.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, the Company
had a valuation allowance of $1,229 million relating to its net deferred tax
assets in the U.S. of $1,308 million.&#160; The valuation allowance of $1,229
million is attributable to (i) the charges totaling $1,081 million that were
recorded in the third and fourth quarters of 2005 and (ii) a valuation allowance
of $148 million recorded in a prior year for certain state tax carryforward
deferred tax assets relating to which management believes it is not more likely
than not that the assets will be realized.&#160; The remaining net deferred tax
assets in excess of the valuation allowance of $79 million relate to certain
foreign tax credit deferred tax assets relating to which management believes it
is more likely than not that the assets will be
realized.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 118</font></p>


<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Valuation Allowance &#150; Outside the U.S.<br></i></b>As of December 31, 2005, the Company had a valuation allowance of approximately $177 million relating to its deferred tax assets outside of the U.S. of $534 million.&#160; The valuation allowance of $177 million is attributable to certain net operating loss and capital loss carryforwards relating to which management believes it is not more likely than not that the assets will be realized.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Tax Settlements, Including
Interest<br></i></b>During 2005, the Company reached a settlement with the
Internal Revenue Service covering tax years 1993-1998.&#160; As a result, the
Company recognized a tax benefit from continuing operations of&#160; $44
million, including interest.&#160; Net income from discontinued operations for
2005 was $150 million, which was net of a $203 million tax benefit.&#160; The $203
million tax benefit for 2005 results from the Company&#146;s audit settlement
with the Internal Revenue Service for tax years covering 1993 through
1998.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During 2004, the Company reached a settlement with the Internal Revenue Service covering tax years 1982-1992.&#160; As a result, the Company recognized a tax benefit of $37 million in 2004, which consisted of benefits of $32 million related to a formal concession concerning the taxation of certain intercompany royalties that could not legally be distributed to the parent entity and $9 million related to the income tax treatment of a patent infringement litigation settlement, and a $4 million charge related to other tax items.&#160; The Company also reached a favorable resolution of interest calculations for these years, and recorded a benefit of&#160; $8 million.&#160; Finally, the Company recorded net charges of $13 million for adjustments for audit years 1993 and thereafter.&#160; Net income from discontinued operations for 2004 was $475 million, which was net of a tax provision of $275 million. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company and its subsidiaries&#146; income tax returns are routinely examined by various authorities.&#160; In management&#146;s opinion, adequate provision for income taxes has been made for all open years in accordance with SFAS No. 5, &#147;Accounting for Contingencies.&#148;&#160; A degree of judgment is required in determining our effective tax rate and in evaluating our tax position.&#160; The Company establishes reserves when, despite significant support for the Company&#146;s filing position, a belief exists that these positions may be challenged by the respective tax jurisdiction.&#160; The reserves are adjusted upon the occurrence of external, identifiable events, including the settlement of the related tax audit year with the Internal Revenue Service.&#160; A change in our tax reserves could have a significant impact on our effective tax rate and our operating results<b>.</b></font></p>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Intellectual Property Donation<br></i></b>During 2003, the Company recorded a tax benefit of $13 million related to the donation of intellectual property in the form of technology patents to a tax-qualified organization.&#160; </font></p>




<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The significant components of deferred tax assets and liabilities were as follows:</font></p>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had
available net operating loss carryforwards both inside and outside of the U.S.
of approximately $584 million for income tax purposes, of which approximately
$373 million has an indefinite carryforward period.&#160; The remaining $211
million expires between the years 2006 and 2025.&#160; Utilization of these net
operating losses may be subject to limitations in the event of significant
changes in stock ownership of the Company.&#160; The Company also has $447
million of unused foreign tax credits at December 31, 2005, with various
expiration dates through 2015.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The valuation allowance as of December 31, 2005 of $1,406 million is attributable to $177 million of net foreign deferred tax assets, including certain net operating loss and capital loss carryforwards and&#160; $1,229 million of U.S. net deferred tax assets, including current year losses and credits, which the Company is unable to benefit.&#160; The valuation allowance as of December 31, 2004 of $284 million is attributable to certain net operating loss and capital loss carryforwards outside the U.S. and to other tax credits in the U.S.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has recognized the balance of its deferred tax assets on the belief that it is more likely than not that they will be realized.&#160; This belief is based on an assessment of all available evidence, including an evaluation of scheduled reversals of deferred tax assets and liabilities, estimates of projected future taxable income, carryback potential and tax planning strategies.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company has been utilizing net operating loss carryforwards to offset taxable income from its operations in China that have become profitable.&#160; The Company has been granted a tax holiday in China that became effective when the net operating loss carryforwards were fully utilized during 2004.&#160; The tax holiday thus became effective during 2004, and the Company&#146;s tax rate in China was zero percent for 2004 and 2005.&#160; For 2006, 2007 and 2008, the Company&#146;s tax rate will be 7.5%, which is 50% of the normal 15% tax rate for the jurisdiction in which Kodak operates.&#160; Thereafter, the Company&#146;s tax rate will be 15%.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Retained earnings of subsidiary
companies outside the U.S. were approximately $1,906 million and $2,265
million at December 31, 2005 and 2004, respectively.&#160; Deferred taxes have
not been provided on such undistributed earnings, as it is the Company&#146;s
policy to permanently reinvest its retained earnings, and it is not practicable
to determine the deferred tax liability on such undistributed earnings in the
event they were to be remitted.&#160; However, the Company periodically
repatriates a portion of these earnings to the extent that it can do so
tax-free, or at minimal cost.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As discussed, the Jobs Creation Act was signed into law in October of 2004.&#160; The Act creates a temporary incentive for U.S. multinationals to repatriate foreign subsidiary earnings by providing a 85% dividends received deduction for certain dividends from controlled foreign corporations.&#160; The deduction is subject to a number of limitations and requirements, including adoption of a specific domestic reinvestment plan for the repatriated earnings.&#160; The Company repatriated approximately $580 million in dividends subject to the 85% dividends received deduction.&#160; Accordingly, the Company recorded a corresponding tax provision of $29 million with respect to such dividends during 2005.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 120</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 16:&#160; RESTRUCTURING COSTS AND OTHER</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company is currently undergoing the transformation from a traditional products and services company to a digital products and services company.&#160; In connection with this transformation, the Company announced a cost reduction program in January 2004 that would extend through 2006 to achieve the appropriate business model and to significantly reduce its worldwide facilities footprint.&#160; In July 2005, the Company announced an extension to this program into 2007 to accelerate its digital transformation, which included further cost reductions that will result in a business model consistent with what is necessary to compete profitably in digital markets.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In connection with its announcement relating to the extended &#147;2004-2007 Restructuring Program,&#148; the Company has provided estimates with respect to (1) the number of positions to be eliminated, (2) the facility square footage reduction, (3) the reduction in its traditional manufacturing infrastructure, and&#160; (4) the total restructuring charges to be incurred.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The actual charges for initiatives under this program are recorded in the period in which the Company commits to formalized restructuring plans or executes the specific actions contemplated by the program and all criteria for restructuring charge recognition under the applicable accounting guidance have been met.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 121</font></p>

 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Pre-2004 Restructuring Programs:</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">

<BR>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="top">
  <hr size="1"  align="Left" width="25%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(1)</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The total   restructuring charges of $1,133 million include: (1) pension and other   postretirement charges and credits for curtailments, settlements and special   termination benefits, and (2) environmental remediation charges that resulted   from the Company&#146;s ongoing restructuring actions.&#160; However, because the impact of these charges and credits relate   to the accounting for pensions, other postretirement benefits, and   environmental remediation costs, the related impacts on the Consolidated   Statement of Financial Position are reflected in their respective components   as opposed to within the accrued restructuring balances at December 31, 2005   or 2004.&#160; Accordingly, the Other   Adjustments and Reclasses column of the table above includes: (1)   reclassifications to Other long-term assets and Pension and other   postretirement liabilities for the position elimination-related impacts on   the Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement
employee benefit plan arrangements,   including net curtailment losses, settlement losses, and special termination   benefits of $(98) million, and (2) reclassifications to Other long-term   liabilities for the restructuring-related impacts on the Company&#146;s   environmental remediation liabilities of $(8) million.&#160; Additionally, the Other Adjustments and   Reclasses column of the table above includes: (1) adjustments to the   restructuring reserves of $14 million related to the Creo purchase accounting   impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to   Restructuring charges, (2) foreign currency translation adjustments of $(12)   million, which are reflected in Accumulated other comprehensive loss in the   Consolidated Statement of Financial Position, and (3) rebalancing   reclassifications between the restructuring reserves, which net to zero on a   consolidated basis.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<BR>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The costs incurred, net of reversals, which total $1,118 million for the year ended December 31, 2005, include $391 million and $37 million of charges related to accelerated depreciation and inventory write-downs, respectively, which were reported in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The remaining costs incurred, net of reversals, of $690 million, were reported as restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The severance costs and exit costs require the outlay of cash, while long-lived asset impairments, accelerated depreciation and inventory write-downs represent non-cash items. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 122</font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004-2007 Restructuring Program</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company announced on January 22, 2004 that it planned to develop and execute a comprehensive cost reduction program throughout the 2004 to 2006 timeframe.&#160; The objective of these actions was to achieve a business model appropriate for the Company&#146;s traditional businesses, and to sharpen the Company&#146;s competitiveness in digital markets.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Program was expected to result in total charges of $1.3 billion to $1.7 billion over the three-year period, of which $700 million to $900 million related to severance, with the remainder relating to the disposal of buildings and equipment.&#160; Overall, Kodak&#146;s worldwide facility square footage was expected to be reduced by approximately one-third.&#160; Approximately 12,000 to 15,000 positions worldwide were expected to be eliminated through these actions primarily in global manufacturing, selected traditional businesses and corporate administration.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On July 20, 2005, the Company announced that it would extend the restructuring activity, originally announced in January 2004, as part of its efforts to accelerate its digital transformation and to respond to a faster-than-expected decline in consumer film sales.&#160; The Company now plans to increase the total employment reduction to a range of 22,500 to 25,000 positions, and to reduce its traditional manufacturing infrastructure to approximately $1 billion, compared with $2.9 billion as of December 31, 2004.&#160; When largely completed by the middle of 2007, these activities will result in a business model consistent with what is necessary to compete profitably in digital markets.&#160; As a result of this announcement, this program has been renamed the &#147;2004-2007 Restructuring Program.&#148;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company implemented certain actions under this program during 2005.&#160; As a result of these actions, the Company recorded charges of $742 million in 2005, which were composed of severance, long-lived asset impairments, exit costs and inventory write-downs of $497 million, $124 million, $84 million and $37 million, respectively.&#160; The severance costs related to the elimination of approximately 8,125 positions, including approximately 1,000 photofinishing, 4,375 manufacturing, 575 research and development and 2,175 administrative positions.&#160; The geographic composition of the positions to be eliminated includes approximately 4,150 in the United States and Canada and 3,975 throughout the rest of the world.&#160; The reduction of the 8,125 positions and the $581 million charges for severance and exit costs are reflected in the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program table below.&#160; The $124 million charge for long-lived asset impairments was included in
restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The charges taken for inventory write-downs of $37 million were reported in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under this Program, on a life-to-date basis as of December 31, 2005, the Company has recorded charges of $1,416 million, which were composed of severance, long-lived asset impairments, exit costs and inventory write-downs of $915 million, $262 million, $183 million and $56 million, respectively.&#160; The severance costs related to the elimination of approximately 17,750 positions, including approximately 5,700 photofinishing, 7,950 manufacturing, 1,000 research and development and 3,100 administrative positions.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 123</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The severance charges of $497 million and the exit costs of $84 million were reported in restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; Included in the $497 million charge taken for severance costs was a net curtailment loss of $6 million.&#160; This net curtailment loss is disclosed in Note 17, &#147;Retirement Plans&#148; and Note 18, &#147;Other Postretirement Benefits.&#148;&#160; Included in the $84 million charge taken for exit costs was a $8 million charge for environmental remediation associated with the closures of the manufacturing facility in Coburg, Australia and Sao Jose dos Campos, Brazil.&#160; The liability related to this charge is disclosed in Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; under &#147;Environmental.&#148;&#160; During 2005, the Company made $377 million of severance payments and $95 million of exit cost payments related to the 2004-2007
Restructuring Program.&#160; During 2005, the Company reversed $3 million of severance reserves, as severance payments were less than originally estimated.&#160; In addition, the Company reversed $6 million of exit costs reserves during 2005, as the Company was able to settle lease and other exit cost obligations for amounts that were less than originally estimated.&#160; These reserve reversals were included in restructuring costs and other in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The total severance charges of $497 million include pension and other postretirement charges and credits for curtailments, settlements and special termination benefits.&#160; However, because the impact of these charges and credits relate to the accounting for pensions and other postretirement benefits, the related impacts on the Consolidated Statement of Financial Position are reflected in their respective components as opposed to within the accrued restructuring balances at December 31, 2005 or 2004.&#160; Accordingly, other adjustments of $(113) million to the severance reserve in 2005 included reclassifications to Other long-term assets and Pension and other postretirement liabilities for the position elimination-related impacts on the Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement employee benefit plan arrangements, including net curtailment losses, settlement losses, and special termination benefits of $(96) million, which are disclosed in Note 17
&#147;Retirement Plans&#148; and Note 18, &#147;Other Postretirement Benefits&#148;.&#160; Additionally, the other adjustments of $(113) million to the severance reserve in 2005 include: (1) adjustments to the severance reserve of $7 million related to the Creo purchase accounting impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to Restructuring charges, (2) foreign currency translation adjustments of $(12) million, and (3) rebalancing reclassifications to other restructuring reserves of ($12) million, which net to zero on a consolidated basis.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 124</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Other adjustments of $4 million to the exit cost reserve in 2005 included: (1) reclassifications to Other long-term liabilities for the restructuring-related impacts on the Company&#146;s environmental remediation liabilities of $(8) million, which are disclosed in Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148; under &#147;Environmental&#148;, (2) adjustments to the exit cost reserve of $7 million related to the Creo purchase accounting impacts that were charged appropriately to Goodwill as opposed to Restructuring charges, and (3) rebalancing reclassifications to other restructuring reserves of $5 million, which net to zero on a consolidated basis.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a result of the initiatives already implemented under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program, severance payments will be paid during periods through 2007 since, in many instances, the employees whose positions were eliminated can elect or are required to receive their payments over an extended period of time.&#160; Most exit costs were paid during 2005.&#160; However, certain costs, such as long-term lease payments, will be paid over periods after 2005.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As a result of initiatives implemented under the 2004-2007 Restructuring Program, the Company recorded $391 million of accelerated depreciation on long-lived assets in cost of goods sold in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.&#160; The accelerated depreciation relates to long-lived assets accounted for under the held and used model of SFAS No. 144.&#160; The year-to-date amount of $391 million relates to $37 million of photofinishing facilities and equipment, $349 million of manufacturing facilities and equipment, and $5 million of administrative facilities and equipment that will be used until their abandonment.&#160; The Company will record approximately $200 million of additional accelerated depreciation in 2006 related to the initiatives implemented in 2005.&#160; Additional amounts of accelerated depreciation may be recorded in 2006 and 2007 as the Company continues to execute its 2004-2007
Restructuring Program.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The charges of $1,133 million recorded in 2005, excluding reversals, included $222 million applicable to the D&amp;FIS segment, $23 million applicable to the Health Group segment, and $30 million applicable to the Graphic Communications Group segment, and $3 million applicable to All Other.&#160; The balance of $855 million was applicable to manufacturing, research and development, and administrative functions, which are shared across all segments.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align="center">
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Pre-2004 Restructuring Programs</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">At December 31, 2005, the Company had remaining severance and exit costs reserves of $2 million and $13 million, respectively, relating to restructuring plans committed to or executed prior to 2004.&#160; During 2005, reversals of $3 million were made to reduce the severance reserve balance, as severance payments were less than originally estimated.&#160; During 2005, reversals of $3 million were made to reduce the exit costs reserve balance, as the Company was able to settle lease and other exit cost obligations for amounts that were less than originally estimated.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining severance payments relate to initiatives already implemented under the Pre-2004 Restructuring Programs and will be paid out during 2006 since, in many instances, the employees whose positions were eliminated can elect or are required to receive their severance payments over an extended period of time.&#160; Most of the remaining exit costs reserves represent long-term lease payments, which will continue to be paid over periods throughout and after 2006.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 17:&#160; RETIREMENT PLANS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Substantially all U.S. employees are covered by a noncontributory defined benefit plan, the Kodak Retirement Income Plan (KRIP), which is funded by Company contributions to an irrevocable trust fund.&#160; The funding policy for KRIP is to contribute amounts sufficient to meet minimum funding requirements as determined by employee benefit and tax laws plus additional amounts the Company determines to be appropriate.&#160; Generally, benefits are based on a formula recognizing length of service and final average earnings.&#160; Assets in the trust fund are held for the sole benefit of participating employees and retirees.&#160; They are comprised of corporate equity and debt securities, U.S. government securities, partnership and joint venture investments, interests in pooled funds, and various types of interest rate, foreign currency and equity market financial instruments.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 125</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On March 25, 1999, the Company amended this plan to include a separate cash balance formula for all U.S. employees hired after February 1999.&#160; All U.S. employees hired prior to that date were granted the option to choose the KRIP plan or the Cash Balance Plus plan.&#160; Written elections were made by employees in 1999, and were effective January 1, 2000.&#160; The Cash Balance Plus plan credits employees&#146; accounts with an amount equal to 4% of their pay, plus interest based on the 30-year treasury bond rate.&#160; In addition, for employees participating in this plan and the Company&#146;s defined contribution plan, the Savings and Investment Plan (SIP), the Company will match SIP contributions for an amount up to 3% of pay, for employee contributions of up to 5% of pay.&#160; Company contributions to SIP were $13 million, $15 million and $15 million for 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively.&#160; As a result of employee elections to the Cash Balance Plus
plan, the reductions in future pension expense will be almost entirely offset by the cost of matching employee contributions to SIP.&#160; The impact of the Cash Balance Plus plan is shown as a plan amendment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company also sponsors unfunded defined benefit plans for certain U.S. employees, primarily executives.&#160; The benefits of these plans are obtained by applying KRIP provisions to all compensation, including amounts being deferred, and without regard to the legislated qualified plan maximums, reduced by benefits under KRIP.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Most subsidiaries and branches operating outside the U.S. have defined benefit retirement plans covering substantially all employees.&#160; Contributions by the Company for these plans are typically deposited under government or other fiduciary-type arrangements.&#160; Retirement benefits are generally based on contractual agreements that provide for benefit formulas using years of service and/or compensation prior to retirement.&#160; The actuarial assumptions used for these plans reflect the diverse economic environments within the various countries in which the Company operates.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The measurement date used to determine the pension obligation for all major funded and unfunded U.S. and Non-U.S. defined benefit plans comprising a majority of the plan assets and benefit obligations is December 31.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 126</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The prepaid pension cost asset amounts for the U.S. and Non-U.S. at December 31, 2005 and 2004 are included in other long-term assets.&#160; The accrued benefit liability and additional minimum pension liability amounts (net of the intangible asset amounts) for the U.S. and Non-U.S. at December 31, 2005 and 2004 are included in pension and other postretirement liabilities.&#160; The accumulated other comprehensive income amounts for the U.S. and Non-U.S. at December 31, 2005 and 2004 are included as a component of shareholders&#146; equity, net of taxes.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The accumulated benefit obligations for all the major funded and unfunded U.S. and Non-U.S. defined benefit plans are as follows:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="5"  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="5"  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>

  <td  valign="bottom">

  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The special termination benefits of $101 million, $52 million and $30 million for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003, respectively, were incurred as a result of the Company&#146;s restructuring actions and, therefore, have been included in restructuring costs and other in the Consolidated Statement of Operations for those respective periods.&#160; In addition, curtailment and settlement charges totaling $21 million and $11 million for 2005, $8 million and $0 million for 2004 and $0 million and $2 million for 2003 were also incurred as a result of the Company&#146;s restructuring actions and, therefore, have been included in restructuring costs and other in the Consolidated Statement of Operations for those respective periods.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In connection with the divestiture of
RSS, the final asset transfer was completed in November 2005.&#160; In
connection with the final asset transfer, a one-time settlement charge of $54
million was recognized during the fourth quarter in discontinued
operations.&#160; See Note 22, &#147;Discontinued Operations.&#148;&#160;
</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Japanese Welfare Pension Insurance Law
(JWPIL) was amended in June 2001 to permit employers with Employees&#146;
Pension Funds (EPFs) to separate the pay related portion of the old-age pension
benefits under the JWPIL (Substitutional Portion) from the EPF.&#160; This
obligation and related plan assets are transferred to a government agency,
thereby relieving the EPF from paying the substitutional portion of
benefits.&#160; The Kodak Japan Limited EPF completed the transfer of the
substitutional portion to the Japanese Government in December 2004.&#160; The
effect of the transfer resulted in a one-time credit due to the derecognition of
future salary increases in the amount of $3 million, a one-time credit due to
the government subsidy from the transfer of liabilities and related plan assets
of $25 million and a one-time charge due to the accelerated recognition of
unrecognized loss in accordance with SFAS No. 88 settlement accounting in the
amount of $20 million.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The increase (decrease) in the additional minimum liability (net of the change in the intangible asset) included in other comprehensive income for the major funded and unfunded U.S. and Non-U.S. defined benefit plans is as follows: </font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">8.12</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">%</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">9.00</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">%</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">7.86</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">%</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Of the total plan assets attributable to the major U.S. defined benefit plans at December 31, 2005 and 2004, 98% and 98%, respectively, relate to the KRIP plan.&#160; The expected long-term rate of return on plan assets assumption (EROA) is determined from the plan&#146;s asset allocation using forward-looking assumptions in the context of historical returns, correlations and volatilities.&#160; The investment strategy underlying the asset allocation is to manage the assets of the U.S. plans to provide for the long-term liabilities while maintaining sufficient liquidity to pay current benefits.&#160; This is primarily achieved by holding equity-like investments while investing a portion of the assets in long duration bonds in order to provide for benefits included in the projected benefit obligation.&#160; The Company undertakes an asset and liability modeling study once every three years or when there are material changes in the composition of the plan liability
or capital markets.&#160; The Company completed its most recent study in 2005, which supports the EROA of 9%.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The expected return on plan assets for the major non-U.S. pension plans range from 4.38% to 9.0% for 2005.&#160; Every three years or when market conditions have changed materially, the Company will undertake new asset and liability modeling studies for each of its larger pension plans.&#160; The asset allocations and expected return on plan assets are individually set to provide for benefits included in the projected benefit obligation within each country&#146;s legal investment constraints.&#160; The investment strategy is to manage the assets of the non-U.S. plans to provide for the long-term liabilities while maintaining sufficient liquidity to pay current benefits.&#160; This is primarily achieved by holding equity-like investments while investing a portion of the assets in long duration bonds in order to partially match the long-term nature of the liabilities.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s weighted-average asset allocations for its major U.S. defined benefit pension plans at December 31, 2005 and 2004, by asset category, are as follows: </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s weighted-average asset allocations for its major non-U.S. Defined Benefit Pension Plans at December 31, 2005 and 2004, by asset category are as follows: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>Asset Category</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>Target</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="65%" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Other asset category in the tables above is primarily composed of private equity, venture capital, cash and other investments.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company expects to contribute
approximately $22 million and $103 million in 2006 for U.S. and Non-U.S. defined
benefit pension plans, respectively.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 18:&#160; OTHER POSTRETIREMENT BENEFITS </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company provides healthcare, dental and life insurance benefits to U.S. eligible retirees and eligible survivors of retirees.&#160; Generally, to be eligible for the plan, individuals retiring prior to January 1, 1996 were required to be 55 years of age with ten years of service or their age plus years of service must have equaled or exceeded 75.&#160; For those retiring after December 31, 1995, the individuals must be 55 years of age with ten years of service or have been eligible as of December 31, 1995.&#160; Based on the eligibility requirements, these benefits are provided to U.S. retirees who are covered by the Company&#146;s KRIP plan and are funded from the general assets of the Company as they are incurred.&#160; However, those under the Cash Balance Plus portion of the KRIP plan would be required to pay the full cost of their benefits under the plan.&#160; The Company&#146;s subsidiaries in the United Kingdom and Canada offer similar healthcare
benefits.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 131</font></p>


<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The measurement date used to determine the net benefit obligation for the Company&#146;s other postretirement benefit plans is December 31.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the quarter ended June 30, 2004,
the Company adopted the provisions of FSP 106-2 with respect to its U.S. Other
Postretirement Plan, which resulted in a remeasurement of the Plan&#146;s
accumulated projected benefit obligation (APBO) as of April 1, 2004.&#160; This
remeasurement takes into account the impact of the subsidy the Company will
receive under the Medicare Prescription Drug, Improvement and Modernization Act
of 2003 (the Act) and certain actuarial assumption changes including: (1)
changes in participation rates, (2) a decrease in the Company&#146;s Medicare
plan premiums, and (3) a decrease in the discount rate from 6.00% to
5.75%.&#160; The actuarially determined impact of the subsidy reduced the APBO
by approximately $228 million.&#160; The effect of the subsidy on the
measurement of the net periodic other postretirement benefit cost in 2004 was to
reduce the cost by approximately $52 million as follows: </font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="80%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="8"  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>12 months ended<br>   </b></font>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>December   31, 2004</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>

  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The effect of the subsidy will be
included in the measurement of the net periodic other postretirement cost for
all annual periods subsequent to 2004 as well.</font></p>


<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The U.S. plan represents approximately 97% of the total other postretirement net benefit obligation as of both December 31, 2005 and 2004 and, therefore, the weighted-average assumptions used to compute the other postretirement benefit amounts approximate the U.S. assumptions.</font></p>
<p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Assumed healthcare cost trend rates have a significant effect on the amounts reported for the healthcare plans.&#160; A one-percentage point change in assumed healthcare cost trend rates would have the following effects:</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="60%">

 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>1%<br>   increase</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td  colspan="2" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>1%<br>   decrease</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td width="76%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td width="2%" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td width="8%" valign="bottom">
  <hr size="1" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td width="1%" valign="bottom">
  <p  align="center"><font size=1 face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
 <tr bgcolor="#cceeff">
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Effect on   total service and interest cost</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">2</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">

  <td  valign="bottom">

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company expects to contribute $264 million to its other postretirement benefit plans in 2006.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 20:&#160; STOCK OPTION AND COMPENSATION PLANS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s stock incentive plans consist of the 2005 Omnibus Long-Term Compensation Plan (the 2005 Plan), the 2000 Omnibus Long-Term Compensation Plan (the 2000 Plan), and the 1995 Omnibus Long-Term Compensation Plan (the 1995 Plan).&#160; The Plans are administered by the Executive Compensation and Development Committee of the Board of Directors.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under the 2005 Plan, 11 million shares of
the Company&#146;s common stock may be granted to employees between January 1,
2005 and December 31, 2014.&#160; This share reserve may be increased by: shares
that are forfeited pursuant to awards made under the 1995 and 2000 Plans;
shares retained for payment of tax withholding; shares issued in connection with
reinvestments of dividends and dividend equivalents; shares delivered for
payment or satisfaction of tax withholding; shares reacquired on the open market
using option exercise price cash proceeds; and awards that otherwise do not
result in the issuance of shares.&#160; The 2005 Plan is substantially similar
to and is intended to replace the 2000 Plan, which expired on January 18,
2005.&#160; Stock options are generally non-qualified and are issued at prices
not less than 100% of the per share fair market value on the date of
grant.&#160; Options granted under the 2005 Plan generally expire seven years
from the date of grant, but may be forfeited or canceled earlier if the
optionee&#146;s employment terminates prior to the end of the contractual
term.&#160; The 2005 Plan also provides for Stock Appreciation Rights (SARs) to
be granted, either in tandem with options or freestanding.&#160; SARs allow
optionees to receive payment equal to the increase in the Company&#146;s stock
market price from the grant date to the exercise date.&#160; At December 31,
2005, no freestanding SARs were outstanding under the 2005 Plan.&#160;&#160;
</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 134</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under the 2000 Plan, 22 million shares of the Company&#146;s common stock were eligible for grant to a variety of employees between January 1, 2000 and December 31, 2004.&#160; The 2000 Plan is substantially similar to, and was intended to replace, the 1995 Plan, which expired on December 31, 1999.&#160; Stock options are generally non-qualified and are at prices not less than 100% of the per share fair market value on the date of grant, and the options generally expire ten years from the date of grant, but may expire sooner if the optionee&#146;s employment terminates.&#160; The 2000 Plan also provides for SARs to be granted, either in tandem with options or freestanding.&#160; At December 31, 2005, 47,138 freestanding SARs were outstanding under the 2000 Plan at option prices ranging from $23.25 to $62.44.&#160; Compensation expense recognized in 2005 on those freestanding SARs, the majority of which had option prices less than the market value of the
Company&#146;s underlying common stock, was not material. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Under the 1995 Plan, 22 million shares of the Company&#146;s common stock were eligible for grant to a variety of employees between February 1, 1995 and December 31, 1999.&#160; Stock options are generally non-qualified and are at prices not less than 100% of the per share fair market value on the date of grant, and the options generally expire ten years from the date of grant, but may expire sooner if the optionee&#146;s employment terminates.&#160; The 1995 Plan also provides for SARs to be granted, either in tandem with options or freestanding.&#160; At December 31, 2005, 249,665 freestanding SARs were outstanding under the 1995 Plan at option prices ranging from $31.30 to $90.63.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In addition, the 2005 Plan, the 2000 Plan, and the 1995 Plan provide for, but are not limited to, grants of unvested stock and performance awards.&#160; Compensation expense recognized in 2005 for these awards, based on their fair value, was not material. </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 135</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The table above excludes approximately 68 (in thousands) options granted by the Company in 2001 at an exercise price of $.05-$21.91 as part of an acquisition.&#160; At December 31, 2005, approximately 8 (in thousands) stock options were outstanding in relation to this acquisition.</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The weighted-average remaining contractual term and aggregate intrinsic value of all options outstanding at December 31, 2005 was 3.75 years and negative $869,962 thousand, respectively.&#160; The weighted-average remaining contractual term and aggregate intrinsic value of all options exercisable at December 31, 2005 was 3.49 and negative $850,122 thousand, respectively.&#160; The negative aggregate intrinsic value of all options outstanding and exercisable, respectively, reflects the fact that the market price of the Company&#146;s common stock as of December 31, 2005 was below the weighted-average exercise price of options.&#160; The total intrinsic value of options exercised during years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was (in thousands) $1,238, $417, and $3,153, respectively.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, there was $8.7 million of total unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested options.&#160; The cost is expected to be recognized over a weighted-average period of 2.14 years.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The total fair value of shares vested during the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $16 million, $15 million and $20 million, respectively.&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 136</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Cash received for option exercises for the years ended December 31, 2005, 2004 and 2003 was $12 million, $5 million and $12 million, respectively.&#160; The actual tax benefit realized for the tax deductions from option exercises was not material for 2005, 2004 or 2003.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 21:&#160; ACQUISITIONS</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Creo Inc.<br>
</i></b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On June 15, 2005, the Company completed the acquisition of Creo Inc. (Creo), a premier supplier of prepress and workflow systems used by commercial printers around the world.&#160; The acquisition of Creo uniquely positions the Company to be the preferred partner for its customers, helping them improve efficiency, expand their offerings and grow their businesses.&#160; The Company paid $954 million (excluding approximately $13 million in transaction related costs), or $16.50 per share, for all of the outstanding shares of Creo.&#160; The Company used its bank lines to initially fund the acquisition, which has been refinanced through the Company&#146;s Secured Credit Facilities.&#160; Creo&#146;s extensive solutions portfolio is now part of the Company&#146;s Graphic Communications Group segment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following represents the total purchase price of the acquisition (in millions):</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="60%">

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon closing of an acquisition, the Company estimates the fair values of assets and liabilities acquired in order to consolidate the acquired balance sheet.&#160; Given the time it takes to obtain pertinent information to finalize the acquired balance sheet, it is not uncommon for initial estimates to be revised in subsequent quarters.&#160; The Company is currently in the process of finalizing the purchase price allocation with respect to the acquisition of Creo and must complete (1) the final review of the independent third party valuation prepared, and (2) the allocation of the purchase price to the proper tax jurisdictions, which will allow the Company to complete the final valuation of the deferred tax liability associated with the acquisition.&#160; The purchase price allocation, including the allocation to the proper tax jurisdictions, will be completed in the second quarter of 2006.&#160; A preliminary estimate of the deferred tax liability has been
calculated and is included in the preliminary purchase price allocation, which is as follows: </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>At June 15, 2005 &#150; (in millions):</b></font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">967</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em">
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <hr size="3" width="100%" noshade color=black>

  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 137</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Of the $292 million of acquired intangible assets, approximately $36 million was assigned to in-process research and development assets that were written off at the date of acquisition.&#160; Approximately $48 million was assigned to in-process research and development assets during the second quarter of 2005, which was offset by a $12 million adjustment during the third quarter of 2005 due to a change in the third party valuation.&#160; These amounts were determined by identifying research and development projects that had not yet reached technological feasibility and for which no alternative future use existed.&#160; The value of the projects identified to be in progress was determined by estimating the future cash flows from the projects once commercialized, less costs to complete development and discounting these net cash flows back to their present value.&#160; The discount rate used for these research and development projects was 23%.&#160; The charges for
the write-off were included as research and development costs in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining $256 million of intangible assets, which relate to developed technology, trademarks and customer relationships, have useful lives ranging from six to eight years.&#160; The $462 million of goodwill is assigned to the Company&#146;s Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160; Because the final purchase price allocation has not been completed, the deductibility for tax purposes of the goodwill balance, or any portion of the goodwill balance, has not been determined. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of the acquisition date, management began to assess and formulate restructuring plans at Creo.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, management has completed its assessment and approved actions on some of the plans.&#160; Accordingly, the Company recorded a related liability of approximately $27 million.&#160; This liability is included in the current liabilities amount reported above and represents restructuring charges related to Creo and net assets acquired.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, management had not approved all plans and actions to be taken and, therefore, the Company was not committed to specific actions.&#160; Accordingly, the amount related to future actions is not estimable and has not been recorded.&#160; However, once management approves and commits the Company to the plans, the accounting for the restructuring charges will be reflected in the purchase accounting as an increase to goodwill to the extent the actions relate to Creo and the net assets
acquired.&#160; Refer to Note 16, &#147;Restructuring Costs and Other,&#148; for further discussion of these restructuring charges.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Kodak Polychrome Graphics </i></b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On April 1, 2005, the Company completed its acquisition of Kodak Polychrome Graphics (KPG) through the redemption of Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s 50 percent interest in the joint venture.&#160; The transaction further established the Company as a leader in the graphic communications industry and will complement the Company&#146;s existing business in this market.&#160; Under the terms of the transaction, the Company redeemed all of Sun Chemical Corporation&#146;s shares in KPG by providing $317 million in cash (excluding $7 million in transaction costs) at closing and by entering into two notes payable arrangements, one that will be payable within the U.S. (the U.S. note) and one that will be payable outside of the U.S. (the non-U.S. note), that will require principal and interest payments of $200 million in the third quarter of 2006, and $50 million annually from 2008 through 2013.&#160; The total payments due under the U.S note and the non-U.S. note are $100
million and $400 million, respectively.&#160; The aggregate fair value of these note payable arrangements of approximately $395 million was recorded in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of the acquisition date and was presented as a non-cash investing activity in the Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows.&#160; KPG now operates within the Company&#146;s Graphic Communications Group segment.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following represents the total purchase price of the acquisition (in millions):</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 138</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon closing of an acquisition, the Company estimates the fair values of assets and liabilities acquired in order to consolidate the acquired balance sheet.&#160; Given the time it takes to obtain pertinent information to finalize the acquired balance sheet, it is not uncommon for initial estimates to be revised in subsequent quarters.&#160; The Company is currently in the process of finalizing the purchase price allocation with respect to the acquisition of KPG and must complete (1) the final review of the independent third party valuation prepared, and (2) the allocation of the purchase price to the proper tax jurisdictions, which will allow the Company to complete the final valuation of the deferred tax liability associated with the acquisition.&#160; The purchase price allocation, including the allocation to the proper tax jurisdictions, will be completed in the first quarter of 2006.&#160; A preliminary estimate of the deferred tax liability has been
calculated and is included in the preliminary purchase price allocation, which is as follows: </font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Of the $159 million of acquired intangible assets, approximately $16 million was assigned to research and development assets that were written off at the date of acquisition.&#160; This amount was determined by identifying research and development projects that had not yet reached technological feasibility and for which no alternative future uses exist.&#160; The value of the projects identified to be in progress was determined by estimating the future cash flows from the projects once commercialized, less costs to complete development and discounting these net cash flows back to their present value.&#160; The discount rate used for these research and development projects was 22%.&#160; The charges for the write-off were included as research and development costs in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining $143 million of intangible assets, which relate to developed technology, trademarks and customer relationships, have useful lives ranging from three to sixteen years.&#160; The $218 million of goodwill is assigned to the Company&#146;s Graphic Communications Group segment.&#160; Because the final purchase price allocation has not been completed, the deductibility for tax purposes of the goodwill balance, or any portion of the goodwill balance, has not been determined. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of the acquisition date, management began to assess and formulate restructuring plans at KPG.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, management has completed its assessment and approved actions on some of the plans.&#160; Accordingly, the Company recorded a related liability of approximately $5 million on those approved actions.&#160; This liability is included in the current liabilities amount reported above and represents restructuring charges related to the net assets acquired.&#160; To the extent such actions related to the Company&#146;s historical ownership in the KPG joint venture, the restructuring charges will be reflected in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, management had not approved all plans and actions to be taken and, therefore, the Company was not committed to specific actions.&#160; Accordingly, the amount related to future actions is not estimable and has not been recorded.&#160; However, once
management approves and commits the Company to the plans, the accounting for the restructuring charges will be reflected in the purchase accounting as an increase to goodwill to the extent the actions relate to the net assets acquired.&#160; Refer to Note 16, &#147;Restructuring Costs and Other,&#148; for further discussion of these restructuring charges.&#160; </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 139</font></p>
