<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 140</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>NexPress-Related Entities<br>
</i></b></font>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On May 1, 2004, the Company completed the purchase of Heidelberger Druckmaschinen AG&#146;s (Heidelberg) 50 percent interest in NexPress Solutions LLC, a 50/50 joint venture of Kodak and Heidelberg that makes high-end, on-demand digital color printing systems, and the equity of Heidelberg Digital LLC, a leading maker of digital black-and-white variable-data printing systems.&#160; Kodak also announced the acquisition of NexPress GmbH, a German subsidiary of Heidelberg that provides engineering and development support, and certain inventory, assets and employees of Heidelberg&#146;s regional operations or market centers.&#160; There was no cash consideration paid to Heidelberg at closing.&#160; Under the terms of the acquisition, Kodak and Heidelberg agreed to use a performance-based earn-out formula whereby Kodak will make periodic payments to Heidelberg over a two-year period, if certain sales goals are met.&#160; If all sales goals are met during the two
calendar years ended December 31, 2005, the Company will pay a maximum of $150 million in cash.&#160; None of these sales goals were met during the two calendar years ended December 31, 2005 and therefore, no amounts were paid.&#160; Additional payments may also be made relating to the incremental sales of certain products in excess of a stated minimum number of units sold during a five-year period following the closing of the transaction.&#160; This acquisition advances the Company&#146;s strategy of diversifying its business portfolio, and accelerates its participation in the digital commercial printing industry.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The following table summarizes the estimated fair value of the assets acquired and liabilities assumed at the date of acquisition.&#160; The purchase price allocation is as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>At May 1, 2004 &#150; (in millions)</b></font></p>

  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The excess of fair value of acquired net assets over cost of $30 million represents negative goodwill and was recorded as a component of other long-term liabilities in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Financial Position.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of the acquisition date, management began to assess and formulate plans to restructure the NexPress-related entities.&#160; As of December 31, 2005, management had completed its assessment and approved actions on the plans.&#160; Accordingly, as of December 31, 2005, the related liability was $6 million.&#160; This liability is included in the current liabilities amount reported above and represents restructuring charges related to the entities and net assets acquired.&#160; To the extent such actions related to the Company&#146;s historical ownership in the NexPress Solutions LLC joint venture, the restructuring charges will be reflected in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations.&#160; This amount was $1 million as of December 31, 2005. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 141</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>China Lucky Film Co. Ltd. <br></i></b>On October 22, 2003, the Company announced that it signed a twenty-year agreement with China Lucky Film Corp.&#160; On February 10, 2004, the Chinese government approved the Company&#146;s acquisition of 20 percent of Lucky Film Co. Ltd. (Lucky Film), the largest maker of photographic film in China, in exchange for total consideration of approximately $174 million.&#160; The total consideration of $174 million was composed of $90 million in cash, $47 million in additional net cash to build and upgrade manufacturing assets, $30 million of contributed assets consisting of a building and equipment, and $7 million for technical support and training that the Company will provide to Lucky Film.&#160; Under the twenty-year agreement, Lucky Film will pay Kodak a royalty fee for the use of certain of the Company&#146;s technologies as well as dividends on the Lucky Film shares that Kodak will acquire.&#160; In addition, Kodak has

obtained a twenty-year manufacturing exclusivity arrangement with Lucky Film as well as access to Lucky Film&#146;s distribution network.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As the total consideration of $174 million will be paid through 2007, the amount was discounted to $171 million for purposes of the purchase price allocation.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The preliminary purchase price allocation is as follows:</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The acquired intangible assets consist of the manufacturing exclusivity agreement and the distribution rights agreement.&#160; In accordance with the terms of the twenty-year agreement, the Company had acquired a 13 percent interest in Lucky Film as of March 31, 2004 and, therefore, $26 million of the $42 million of value allocated to the 20 percent interest was recorded as of March 31, 2004.&#160; During 2005, the Company recorded an impairment charge of $19 million related to the investment in Lucky Film.&#160; The impairment was recognized as a result of an other-than-temporary decline in the market value of Lucky Film&#146;s stock.&#160; As a result, the value allocated to the 20 percent interest in Lucky Film has been adjusted to $23 million and the corresponding value of the 13 percent interest has been adjusted to $14 million.&#160; The Company will record the $9 million of value associated with the additional 7 percent interest in Lucky Film when it
completes the acquisition of those shares in 2007.&#160; The Company&#146;s interest in Lucky Film is accounted for under the equity method of accounting, as the Company has the ability to exercise significant influence over Lucky Film&#146;s operating and financial policies. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Scitex Digital Printing (Renamed Versamark)<br></i></b>On January 5, 2004, the Company completed its acquisition of Scitex Digital Printing (SDP) from its parent for $252 million, inclusive of cash on hand at closing which totaled approximately $13 million.&#160; This resulted in a net cash price of approximately $239 million, inclusive of transaction costs.&#160; SDP is the leading supplier of high-speed, continuous inkjet printing systems, primarily serving the commercial and transactional printing sectors.&#160; Customers use SDP&#146;s products to print utility bills, banking and credit card statements, direct mail materials, as well as invoices, financial statements and other transactional documents.&#160; SDP now operates under the name Kodak Versamark, Inc.&#160; The acquisition will provide the Company with additional capabilities in the transactional printing and direct mail sectors while creating another path to commercialize proprietary inkjet
technology.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 142</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">

  </td>

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Of the $95 million of acquired intangible assets, $9 million was assigned to research and development assets that were written off at the date of acquisition.&#160; This amount was determined by identifying research and development projects that had not yet reached technological feasibility and for which no alternative future uses exist.&#160; The value of the projects identified to be in progress was determined by estimating the future cash flows from the projects once commercialized, less costs to complete development and discounting these net cash flows back to their present value.&#160; The discount rate used for these three research and development projects was 17%.&#160; The charges for the write-off were included as research and development costs in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2004.&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining $86 million of intangible assets, which relate to developed technology, customer relationships, and trade names, have useful lives ranging from two to fourteen years.&#160; The $17 million of goodwill will be assigned to the Graphic Communications Group segment and is expected to be deductible for tax purposes.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2003</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>PracticeWorks, Inc. <br></i></b>On October 7, 2003, Kodak acquired all of the outstanding shares of PracticeWorks, Inc. (PracticeWorks), a leading provider of dental practice management software (DPMS) and digital radiographic imaging systems, for approximately $475 million in cash, inclusive of transaction costs.&#160; Accordingly, Kodak also became the 100% owner of Paris-based subsidiary, Trophy Radiologie, S.A., a developer and manufacturer of dental digital radiography equipment, which PracticeWorks acquired in December 2002.&#160; This acquisition will enable Kodak&#146;s Health Group to offer its customers a full spectrum of dental imaging products and services from traditional film to digital radiography and photography.&#160; Earnings from continuing operations for 2003 include the results of PracticeWorks from the date of acquisition. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 143</font></p>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Of the $179 million of acquired intangible assets, $10 million was assigned to research and development assets that were written off at the date of acquisition.&#160; This amount was determined by identifying research and development projects that had not yet reached technological feasibility and for which no alternative future uses exist.&#160; As of the acquisition date, there were two projects that met these criteria.&#160; The value of the projects identified to be in progress was determined by estimating the future cash flows from the projects once commercialized, less costs to complete development, and discounting these net cash flows back to their present value.&#160; The discount rate used for these projects was 14%.&#160; The charges for the write-off were included as research and development costs in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2003.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The remaining $169 million of intangible assets have useful lives ranging from three to eighteen years.&#160; The intangible assets that make up that amount include customer relationships of $123 million (eighteen-year weighted-average useful life), developed technology of $44 million (seven-year weighted-average useful life), and other assets of $2 million (three-year weighted-average useful life).&#160; As the acquisition was effected through the Company&#146;s purchase of PracticeWorks stock, the $350 million of goodwill is assigned to the Health Group segment and is not deductible for tax purposes.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<br>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 144</font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">$</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">64</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>

  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p style="margin-left:1em; text-indent:-1em"><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="bottom">

<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2005</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Earnings from discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2005 of approximately $150 million was due to the items discussed below.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company was informed that the United States Congress Joint Committee on Taxation had approved, and the Internal Revenue Service had signed, a settlement between the Company and the Internal Revenue Service concerning the audit of the tax years 1993-1998.&#160; As a result of the settlement, the Company was able to reverse certain tax accruals relating to the aforementioned years under audit.&#160; The reversal of the tax accruals of approximately $203 million, which primarily relates to and which was established in 1994 in connection with the sale of Sterling Winthrop Inc., the Company&#146;s pharmaceutical, consumer health, and household products businesses during that year, was recognized in earnings from discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On August 13, 2004 the Company completed the sale of the assets and business of the Remote Sensing Systems operation, including the stock of Kodak&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary, Research Systems, Inc. (collectively known as RSS), to ITT Industries for $725 million in cash.&#160; As a result of the sale of RSS, the Company transferred the related employees&#146; plan assets of the Company&#146;s pension plan. &#160;This transfer was subject to a true-up provision, which was completed in the fourth quarter of 2005 and resulted in a settlement loss of $54 million being recognized in earnings from discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 145</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The contract with ITT also included a provision under which Kodak could receive up to $35 million in cash (the &#147;Cash Amount&#148;) from ITT depending on the amount of pension plan assets that were ultimately transferred from Kodak&#146;s defined benefit pension plan trust in the U.S. to ITT.&#160; The total amount of assets that Kodak transferred to ITT was actuarially determined in accordance with the applicable sections under the Treasury Regulations and ERISA (the &#147;Transferred Assets&#148;).&#160; The Cash Amount was equal to 50% of the amount by which the Transferred Assets exceed the maximum amount of assets that would be required to be transferred in accordance with the applicable U.S. Government Cost Accounting Standards (the &#147;CAS Assets&#148;), up to $35 million.&#160; Based on preliminary actuarial valuations, the estimated Cash Amount was approximately $30 million.&#160; Accordingly, the after-tax gain from the sale of RSS included an
estimated pre-tax amount of $30 million, representing the Company&#146;s estimate of the Cash Amount that would be received following the transfer of the pension plan assets to ITT.&#160; This amount was recorded in assets of discontinued operations in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2004.&#160; The actual Cash Amount received during the fourth quarter of 2005 was approximately $29 million.&#160; Accordingly, the difference in the estimated Cash Amount and the actual Cash Amount received of approximately $1 million was recorded in earnings from discontinued operations for the year ended December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2004</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">On August 13, 2004, the Company completed the sale of the assets and business of the Remote Sensing Systems operation, including the stock of Kodak&#146;s wholly owned subsidiary, Research Systems, Inc. (collectively known as RSS), to ITT Industries for $725 million in cash.&#160; RSS, a leading provider of specialized imaging solutions to the aerospace and defense community, was part of the Company&#146;s commercial and government systems&#146; operation within the Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems segment.&#160; Its customers include NASA, other U.S. government agencies, and aerospace and defense companies.&#160;&#160; The sale was completed on August 13, 2004.&#160; RSS had net sales for the years ended December 31, 2004 and 2003 of approximately $312 million and $424 million, respectively.&#160; RSS had earnings before taxes for the years ended December 31, 2004 and 2003 of approximately $44 million and $66 million, respectively.&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The sale of RSS resulted in an after-tax gain of approximately $439 million.&#160; The after-tax gain excluded the ultimate impact from the settlement loss that was incurred in connection with the Company&#146;s pension plan of approximately $55 million, as this amount was not recognizable until the final transfer of plan assets occurred, which was in the fourth quarter of 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The contract with ITT included a provision under which Kodak could receive up to $35 million in cash (the &#147;Cash Amount&#148;) from ITT depending on the amount of pension plan assets that were ultimately transferred from Kodak&#146;s defined benefit pension plan trust in the U.S. to ITT.&#160; The total amount of assets that Kodak transferred to ITT was actuarially determined in accordance with the applicable sections under the Treasury Regulations and ERISA (the &#147;Transferred Assets&#148;).&#160; The Cash Amount was equal to 50% of the amount by which the Transferred Assets exceed the maximum amount of assets that would be required to be transferred in accordance with the applicable U.S. Government Cost Accounting Standards (the &#147;CAS Assets&#148;), up to $35 million.&#160; Based on preliminary actuarial valuations, the estimated Cash Amount was approximately $30 million.&#160; Accordingly, the after-tax gain from the sale of RSS included an estimated

pre-tax amount of $30 million, representing the Company&#146;s estimate of the Cash Amount that would be received following the transfer of the pension plan assets to ITT.&#160; This amount was recorded in assets of discontinued operations in the Company&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Financial Position as of December 31, 2004.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Earnings from discontinued operations for the years ended December 31, 2004 and 2003 of approximately $36 million (excluding the $439 million RSS after-tax gain) and $64 million, respectively, were net of provisions for income taxes of $6 million and&#160; $10 million, respectively.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 146</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>2003</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the three month period ended March 31, 2003, the Company repurchased certain properties that were initially sold in connection with the 1994 divestiture of Sterling Winthrop Inc., which represented a portion of the Company&#146;s non-imaging health businesses.&#160; The repurchase of these properties allows the Company to directly manage the environmental remediation that the Company is required to perform in connection with those properties, which will result in better overall cost control (see Note 11, &#147;Commitments and Contingencies&#148;).&#160; In addition, the repurchase eliminated the uncertainty regarding the recoverability of tax benefits associated with the indemnification payments that were previously being made to the purchaser.&#160; Accordingly, the Company reversed a tax reserve of approximately $15 million through earnings from discontinued operations in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Operations for the twelve months ended
December 31, 2003, which was previously established through discontinued operations. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the three month period ended March 31, 2003, the Company received cash relating to the favorable outcome of litigation associated with the 1994 sale of Sterling Winthrop Inc.&#160; The related gain of $19 million was recognized in loss from discontinued operations in the Consolidated Statement of Operations for the year ended December 31, 2002.&#160; The cash receipt is reflected in the net cash provided by (used in) discontinued operations component in the accompanying Consolidated Statement of Cash Flows for the year ended December 31, 2003. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the fourth quarter of 2003, the Company recorded a net of tax credit of $7 million through discontinued operations for the reversal of an environmental reserve, which was primarily attributable to positive developments in the Company&#146;s remediation efforts relating to a formerly owned manufacturing site in the U.S.&#160; In addition, during the fourth quarter of 2003, the Company reversed state income tax reserves of $3 million, net of tax, through discontinued operations due to the favorable outcome of tax audits in connection with a formerly owned business.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>NOTE 23:&#160; SEGMENT INFORMATION </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Current Segment Reporting Structure</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of and for the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company had three reportable segments aligned based on aggregation of similar products and services: Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems (D&amp;FIS); Health Group; and Graphic Communications Group.&#160; The balance of the Company&#146;s operations, which individually and in the aggregate do not meet the criteria of a reportable segment, are reported in All Other.&#160; A description of the segments is as follows:&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems
Segment:</b>&#160; The D&amp;FIS segment provides consumers, professionals and
cinematographers with digital and traditional products and services.&#160;
D&amp;FIS digital products and services include digital capture, kiosks, home
printing systems, and digital imaging
services.&#160; D&amp;FIS traditional products and services include consumer and
professional film, photographic paper and photofinishing, aerial and industrial
film, and entertainment products and services.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Health Group Segment:</b>&#160; The Health Group segment provides digital medical imaging and information products, and systems and solutions, which are key components of sales and earnings growth.&#160; These include laser imagers, digital print films, computed and digital radiography systems, dental radiographic imaging systems, dental practice management software, advanced picture-archiving and communications systems (PACS), and healthcare information systems (HCIS).&#160; Products of the Health Group segment also include traditional analog medical films, chemicals, and processing equipment.&#160; Kodak&#146;s history in traditional analog imaging has made it a leader in this area and has served as the foundation for building its important digital imaging business.&#160; The Health Group segment serves the general radiology market and specialty health markets, including dental, mammography, orthopedics and oncology.&#160; The segment also provides
molecular imaging for the biotechnology research market.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 147</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Graphic Communications Group
Segment:</b>&#160; The Graphic Communications Group segment is composed of the
Company&#146;s equity investments in KPG (Kodak&#146;s 50/50 joint venture with
Sun Chemical) prior to its acquisition in April 2005; the results of KPG
subsequent to the acquisition in April 2005; the results of Creo Inc., a premier
supplier of prepress and workflow systems used by commercial printers worldwide, which was
acquired in June 2005; NexPress Solutions, Inc., a producer of digital color and
black and white printing solutions, which was acquired in May 2004; the results
of Scitex Digital Printing, a provider of continuous inkjet technology, which
was acquired in January 2004 and has since been renamed Kodak Versamark; and the
results of Encad, Inc., a maker of wide-format inkjet printers, inks and
media.&#160; Kodak&#146;s Document Product and Services organization, which
includes market-leading production and desktop document scanners, microfilm,
worldwide

service and support and business process services operations, is also part of this segment.&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Graphic Communications Group segment serves a variety of customers in the creative, in-plant, data center, commercial printing, packaging, newspaper and digital service bureau market segments with a range of software, media and hardware products that provide customers with a variety of solutions for prepress equipment, workflow software, digital and traditional printing, document scanning and multi-vendor IT services.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>All Other:&#160;</b> All Other is composed of Kodak&#146;s display and components business for image sensors and other small, miscellaneous businesses.&#160; It also includes development initiatives in consumer inkjet technologies.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Transactions between segments, which are immaterial, are made on a basis intended to reflect the market value of the products, recognizing prevailing market prices and distributor discounts.&#160; Differences between the reportable segments&#146; operating results and assets and the Company&#146;s consolidated financial statements relate primarily to items held at the corporate level, and to other items excluded from segment operating measurements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">No single customer represented 10% or more of the Company&#146;s total net sales in any period presented. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company changed its methodology for allocating post employment benefit costs for retirees to the segments to which these costs are primarily attributable.&#160; Prior period results have been adjusted to reflect this change in methodology.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">This reallocation (decreased) increased segment earnings (losses) from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges) net, and income taxes as follows:</font></p>

  <td  valign="bottom">

  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">1</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="bottom">
  <p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 148</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The reallocation also had insignificant impacts on the line items comprising the consolidated and segment earnings (losses) from continuing operations before interest, other income (charges), net and income taxes, as amounts were reclassified between the (1) cost of goods sold, (2) selling, general and administrative expenses, and (3) research and development costs expense lines.&#160; </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Segment financial information is shown
below.&nbsp; Prior period results have been restated to conform to the current
period segment reporting structure.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>New Kodak Operating Model and Change in Reporting Structure </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of and for the year ended December 31, 2005, the Company reported financial information for three reportable segments (Digital &amp; Film Imaging Systems, Health Group, and Graphic Communications Group) and All Other.&#160; However, in September of 2005, the Company announced the realignment of its operations to accelerate growth in the commercial, consumer and health markets.&#160; The move is designed to enhance the Company&#146;s operational performance and to accelerate profitable growth.&#160; In connection with the realignment, the Company&#146;s new reporting structure will be implemented beginning in the first quarter of 2006 as outlined below: </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Consumer Digital Imaging Group Segment:</b>&#160; The Consumer Digital Imaging Group segment encompasses digital capture, kiosks, home printing systems, business development, inkjet systems, digital imaging services and imaging sensors.&#160; This segment provides consumers, professionals and cinematographers with digital products and services.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Film and Photofinishing Systems Group Segment:&#160; </b>The Film and Photofinishing Systems Group segment encompasses consumer and professional film, photographic paper and photofinishing, aerial and industrial film, and entertainment products and services.&#160; This segment provides consumers, professionals and cinematographers with traditional products and services.&#160;&#160;&#160;&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Health Group Segment:</b>&#160; There are no changes to the Health Group segment.&#160;&#160; The Health Group segment provides digital medical imaging and information products, and systems and solutions, which are key components of sales and earnings growth.&#160; These include laser imagers, digital print films, computed and digital radiography systems, dental radiographic imaging systems, dental practice management software, advanced picture-archiving and communications systems (PACS), and healthcare information systems (HCIS).&#160; Products of the Health Group segment also include traditional analog medical films, chemicals, and processing equipment.&#160; Kodak&#146;s history in traditional analog imaging has made it a leader in this area and has served as the foundation for building its important digital imaging business.&#160; The Health Group segment serves the general radiology market and specialty health markets, including dental, mammography,
orthopedics and oncology.&#160; The segment also provides molecular imaging for the biotechnology research market.</font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 151</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Graphic Communications Group
Segment:</b>&#160; As of January 1, 2006, the Graphic Communications Group
segment consists of Kodak Polychrome Graphics LLC (KPG), a leader in the graphic
communications industry; Creo Inc., a premier supplier of prepress and workflow systems used
by commercial printers worldwide; NexPress Solutions, Inc., a producer of
digital color and black and white printing solutions; Kodak Versamark, Inc., a
provider of continuous inkjet technology; and Encad, Inc., a maker of
wide-format inkjet printers, inks and media.&#160; Kodak&#146;s Document
Products and Services organization, which includes market-leading production and
desktop document scanners, microfilm, worldwide service and support and business
process services operations, is also part of this segment.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>All Other</b>:&#160; All Other is composed of Kodak&#146;s display and components business for image sensors and other small, miscellaneous businesses.&#160; Effective January 1, 2006, the development initiatives in consumer inkjet technologies will be reported within the Consumer Digital Imaging Group segment.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Additionally, effective January 1, 2006, the Company will change its cost allocation methodologies related to distribution costs, indirect selling, general and administrative expenses, and Corporate research and development costs.</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Changes in Estimates Recorded During the Fourth Quarter December 31, 2005</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the fourth quarter ended December 31, 2005, the Company recorded approximately $25 million, net of tax, related to changes in estimate with respect to certain of its employee benefit and compensation accruals.&#160; These changes in estimates negatively impacted the results for the fourth quarter by $.09 per share.</font></p>

  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">None.</font></p>


<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="10%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 9A.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>



<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company maintains disclosure controls
and procedures that are designed to ensure that information required to be
disclosed in the Company&#146;s reports under the Exchange Act is recorded,
processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the
SEC&#146;s rules and forms, and that such information is accumulated and
communicated to management, including the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer
and Chief Financial Officer, as appropriate, to allow timely decisions regarding
required disclosure.&nbsp; The Company&#146;s management, with participation of
the Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, has
evaluated the effectiveness of the Company&#146;s disclosure controls and
procedures as of the end of the fiscal year covered by this Annual Report on
Form 10-K.&nbsp; As described below under &#147;Management&#146;s Report on
Internal Control Over Financial Reporting,&#148; the Company continues to report
a material weakness in the internal control over financial reporting as of
December 31, 2005.&#160; The Company&#146;s Chief Executive Officer and Chief
Financial Officer have concluded that, as of the end of the period covered by
this Annual Report on Form 10-K, the Company&#146;s disclosure controls and
procedures (as defined in Rules 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Exchange Act)
were not effective as a result of the reported material weakness. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.&nbsp; The Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting is designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America.&nbsp; The Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that: (i) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the Company; (ii) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the United States of America, and that receipts and expenditures
of the Company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the Company; and (iii) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company&#146;s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Internal control over financial reporting cannot provide absolute assurance of achieving financial reporting objectives because of its inherent limitations.&#160; Internal control over financial reporting is a process that involves human diligence and compliance and is subject to lapses in judgment or breakdowns resulting from human failures.&#160; Internal control over financial reporting also can be circumvented by collusion or improper management override.&#160; Because of such limitations, there is a risk that material misstatements may not be prevented or detected on a timely basis by internal control over financial reporting.&#160; However, these inherent limitations are known features of the financial reporting process.&#160; Therefore, it is possible to design into the process safeguards to reduce, though not eliminate, this risk. Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect
misstatements.&nbsp; Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Management assessed the effectiveness of
the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31,
2005.&nbsp; In making this assessment, management used the criteria set forth by
the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission (COSO) in
&#147;Internal Control-Integrated Framework.&#148;&nbsp; Management excluded
Kodak Polychrome Graphics (KPG) and Creo Inc. from its assessment of internal
control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2005 because they were
acquired by the Company in purchase business combinations during 2005.&nbsp; KPG
and Creo Inc. are wholly owned subsidiaries of the Company that represent 9% and
8%, respectively, of consolidated total assets and 9% and 3%, respectively, of
consolidated revenue as of and for the year ended December 31, 2005. </font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 157</font></p>




<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Based on management&#146;s assessment using the COSO criteria, management has concluded that the Company did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2005 as a result of a material weakness in internal controls as described below. </font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A material weakness is a control deficiency, or combination of control deficiencies, that results in more than a remote likelihood that a material misstatement of the annual or interim financial statements will not be prevented or detected.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, management has
concluded that the controls surrounding the completeness and accuracy of the
Company&#146;s deferred income tax valuation allowance account were ineffective.
Specifically, certain incorrect assumptions were made with respect to certain
deferred income tax valuation allowance computations that were not detected in
the related review and approval process.&#160; This control deficiency resulted
in audit adjustments to the 2005 consolidated financial statements. In addition, this control deficiency, if unremediated, could result in a misstatement of the
deferred income tax valuation allowance account and the related provision for
income taxes that would result in a material misstatement of the annual or
interim financial statements that might not be prevented or detected.
Accordingly, management has concluded that this control deficiency constitutes a
material weakness.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Company&#146;s independent registered
public accounting firm has audited management&#146;s assessment of the
effectiveness of the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting as
of December 31, 2005, as stated in their report which appears on page 75 of this
Form 10-K under the heading, <i>Report of Independent Registered Public
Accounting Firm.</i></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As disclosed in the Company&#146;s 2004 Annual Report on Form 10-K, and in its Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q for each of the first three quarters of 2005, the Company reported material weaknesses in the Company&#146;s internal controls surrounding the accounting for income taxes and in its internal controls surrounding the accounting for pension and other postretirement benefit plans.&#160;&#160; In addition, in the Company&#146;s Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for the three and nine-month periods ended September 30, 2005, the Company also reported a material weakness in its internal controls surrounding the preparation and review of spreadsheets that include new or changed formulas.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As of December 31, 2005, the Company has remediated the previously reported material weaknesses in internal control over financial reporting related to the accounting for pension and other postretirement benefit plans and related to the preparation and review of spreadsheets that include new or changed formulas.&#160; With the help of external advisors (other than the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm), the following remedial actions have been undertaken:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><u>Accounting for Pension and Other Postretirement Benefit Plans</u></font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A root cause   analysis was performed on all control deficiencies.&#160; Using the results of this analysis, new processes and   procedures, with appropriate controls, were developed, documented and   implemented in the third quarter of 2005 and followed in the third and fourth   quarters of 2005 for all of the relevant processes that are critical to the   Company&#146;s quarterly and annual reporting requirements, as well as the annual   actuarial valuations for the Company&#146;s pension and other postretirement   benefit plans.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the third quarter of 2005, the Company
developed and rolled out clearly defined and enhanced roles and responsibilities
across the Finance, Human Resource, Information Technology, and Global Shared
Services functions for those individuals with responsibilities in this
area.</font></p> </td>
 </tr>
</table>

  <p>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <p>

 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the third and fourth quarters of 2005, the Company has undertaken and completed, as appropriate, its testing to validate compliance with the newly implemented policies, procedures and controls.&#160; The Company has undertaken this testing over these two quarters so as to be able to demonstrate operating effectiveness over a period of time that is sufficient to support its conclusion.&#160; In reviewing the results from this testing, Management has concluded that the internal controls over the accounting for pension and other postretirement benefit plans have been significantly improved and that the above referenced material weakness in internal controls over financial reporting has been remediated as of December 31, 2005. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><u>Preparation and Review of Spreadsheets that Include New or Changed Formulas</u></font></p>

 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In the fourth quarter of 2005, the Company has undertaken and completed, as appropriate, its testing to validate compliance with the newly implemented policies, procedures and controls.&#160;&#160; The Company has undertaken this testing in order to demonstrate operating effectiveness over a period of time that is sufficient to support its conclusion.&#160; In reviewing the results from this testing, management has concluded that the internal controls over the preparation and review of spreadsheets that include new or changed formulas has been significantly improved and that the above referenced material weakness in internal controls over financial reporting has been remediated as of December 31, 2005.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><u>Remediation Efforts on the Internal Controls Surrounding the Accounting for Income Taxes</u></font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">During the year ended December 31, 2005 the Company hasmade significant progress in executing the remediation plans that were established to address the material weakness in its internal controls surrounding the accounting for income taxes.&nbsp; This resulted in material improvements in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.&#160; With the help of external advisors (other than the Company&#146;s independent registered public accounting firm), the following remedial actions have been undertaken:</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">PAGE 159</font></p>


<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

  <td width="5%" valign="top">

  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>

 </tr>

  <td  valign="top">

  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A root cause   analysis was performed on all control deficiencies.&#160; Using the results of this analysis, new processes and   procedures, with appropriate controls, were developed, documented and   implemented in the third quarter of 2005 and followed in the third and fourth   quarters of 2005 for the processes that are critical to the Company&#146;s income   tax provision calculations reflected in its periodic financial reporting.</font></p>  </td>

 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">A detailed,   quarterly income tax reporting package, which collects tax-sensitive data and   information at the jurisdictional level, was developed and rolled out in the   third quarter of 2005.&#160; This package   was appropriately utilized in connection with the preparation of the year-end   income tax provision and the income tax related balance sheet accounts.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In August   and September 2005, the Company held training sessions for the worldwide   income tax organization, as well as certain Controller&#146;s personnel.&#160; Topics covered in the sessions included   accounting for income taxes, training on the newly developed processes,   procedures, internals controls and the income tax reporting package, and   Sections 302 and 404 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">&#149;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Management   is utilizing personnel from a third-party professional services firm with   expertise in accounting for income taxes to assist in the preparation and   review of the Company&#146;s income tax provision and the income tax related   balance sheet accounts.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As demonstrated by the above, the Company has made significant progress in its efforts to remediate this material weakness during 2005.&#160; This is further supported by the Company&#146;s overall positive results from its 2005 internal control compliance testing required by the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002, which was carried out by the Company in the third and fourth quarters of 2005. In making its determination as to the status of the remediation of this material weakness, the Company has considered all of the factors outlined above and has concluded that the internal controls surrounding the accounting for income taxes are effectively designed, however, as a result of the audit adjustments identified, the Company has not demonstrated operating effectiveness with respect to controls over the completeness and accuracy of its deferred income tax valuation allowance account.&#160; Accordingly, as discussed in &#147;Management&#146;s Report on Internal Control Over
Financial Reporting&#148; above, the Company reported this as a material weakness as of December 31, 2005.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">In order to remediate this deficiency in internal controls, the Company will continue its training and education efforts in this area so that operating effectiveness can be demonstrated over a period of time that is sufficient to support the conclusion that the material weakness has been remediated.&#160; In addition, to further enhance the controls surrounding the accounting for income taxes, the Company continues to progress with the implementation of an IT solution to enable the collection, tracking and bookkeeping of detailed tax information on a global basis.&nbsp; Further, the Company will continue its efforts with respect to 1) enhancing the overall design of the worldwide income tax organization, 2) further upgrading its tax personnel, and 3) developing an effective and efficient forecasting process for purposes of determining its effective tax rate.</font></p>
<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Except as otherwise discussed above, there have been no changes in the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting during the most recently completed fiscal quarter that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company&#146;s internal control over financial reporting.</font></p>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="10%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>ITEM 13.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="90%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>CERTAIN RELATIONSHIPS AND RELATED TRANSACTIONS</b></font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The information required by Item 13 is incorporated by reference from the information under the caption &#147;Transactions with Management&#148; in the Proxy Statement. </font></p>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(Incorporated   by reference to the Eastman Kodak Company Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q for   the quarterly period ended June 30, 1999, the Quarterly Report on Form 10-Q   for the quarterly period ended September 30, 1999, the Annual Report on Form   10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 1999, the Annual Report on Form   10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2001, the Quarterly Report on   Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended March 31, 2004, and the Quarterly   Report on Form 10-Q for the quarterly period ended September 30, 2004,   Exhibit 10.)</font></p>  </td>

   <td  valign="top"><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">(Incorporated by reference to the Eastman Kodak Company Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended December 31, 2004, Exhibit 10.)</font></td>
 </tr>

<DOCUMENT>
<TYPE>EX-10.A
<SEQUENCE>2
<FILENAME>ek111562ex10a.htm
<DESCRIPTION>EXHIBIT 10.A

<html>

<head>
<title></title>
</head>

<body bgcolor="white">




<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Exhibit (10) A.</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">November 3, 2004</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> (address intentionally omitted)</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Dear Phil:</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">We are delighted to extend you an offer to join Eastman Kodak Company (&#147;Kodak&#148;) as Director, Inkjet Systems.&#160; We are confident that your professional talent will be a tremendous asset to our company and we are enthusiastic about welcoming you as a member of our senior management team.&#160; Kodak is at a turning point in its proud more than 115-year history, where technology and the Internet have the potential to unleash unprecedented value from our brand and other corporate assets.&#160; We look forward to you playing a major leadership role, working with others throughout the company to realize our potential.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">This letter outlines the role, compensation and benefits of your offer of employment with Kodak.&#160; Due to the strategic importance of your role, we are pleased to offer you a comprehensive program with the following elements.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The term &#147;Company&#148; as used in this letter agreement means Kodak and all of its subsidiaries and affiliates.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Position</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Your position will be Director, Inkjet Systems.&#160; This position will report to Antonio Perez in his capacity as President and Chief Operating Officer, Eastman Kodak Company.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Your position will be located in Rochester, New York.&#160; Consequently, you will be expected to relocate your residence to the Rochester, New York area upon commencement of your employment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Employment Date</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will commence your employment on or before November 15, 2004.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b><i>Robert L. Berman, Director, Human Resources and Vice President<br> </i></b></font>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman"><b>EASTMAN KODAK COMPANY &#149; 343 STATE STREET &#149; ROCHESTER, NEW YORK 14650-0233<br>
TEL (585) 724-7674 &#149; FAX (585) 724-1655, E-Mail: robert.berman@kodak.com</b></font></p>


<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Base Salary</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Your base salary will be at the rate of $420,000 per year.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Executive Compensation for Excellence and Leadership </b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will be eligible to participate in Kodak&#146;s short-term variable pay plan for its management level employees, Executive Compensation for Excellence and Leadership (&#147;EXCEL&#148;).&#160; Your annual target award under EXCEL will be 62% of your base salary, making your total targeted annual compensation $680,400.&#160; Your actual award for a year will vary based on Company performance, unit performance, your job performance, and such other criteria selected by the Company.&#160; Any award you earn for 2004 will be prorated based on your length of service for 2004.&#160; That is, you will not receive a full award for 2004 since you will not be employed for the full year.&#160; You will receive a summary of this plan from Human Resources shortly after the commencement of your employment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Leadership Stock Program</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Last year, Kodak implemented changes to its long-term incentive compensation program.&#160; These changes entail the adoption of a new restricted stock unit plan, entitled the &#147;Leadership Stock Program.&#148;&#160; As an executive of Kodak, you will be eligible to participate in this new program.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Leadership Stock Program has two-year overlapping performance cycles, denominates awards in the form of restricted share units, uses corporate EPS as the plan&#146;s sole performance criterion, conditions awards on the achievement of a pre-established corporate EPS target for a performance cycle, and imposes a one-year vesting requirement on any award earned under the plan.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The Compensation Committee determines the size of a participant&#146;s actual target award under the program for a cycle based primarily on the participant&#146;s relative leadership assessment.&#160; The first performance cycle that you will be eligible for is that cycle scheduled to commence on January 1, 2005.&#160; For this cycle, Kodak management will recommend to the Compensation Committee that you be allocated an award of 5,925 units.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Shortly after your employment, you will receive a copy of a brochure which will explain in further detail the terms and conditions of the new Leadership Stock Program.&#160; </font></p>
<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 2 of 13</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Signing Bonus - Cash</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon your employment by Kodak, we will pay
you a $50,000 gross cash signing bonus, subject to all federal, state, and FICA
withholding, which will be paid within 30 days of your start date. The cash
signing bonus will not be &#147;benefits bearing&#148;.&#160; In other words,
the amount will not be taken into account or considered for any reasons for
purposes of determining any company provided benefits or compensation to which
you may become eligible, including by way of illustration and not by way of
limitation, any pension or other retirement benefit.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Signing Bonus &#150; Stock Option Award</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon your employment, Kodak will propose to the Compensation Committee that you be granted, as a signing bonus, a one-time grant of 32,800 non-qualified stock options.&#160; The options will be issued to you under the terms of the Eastman Kodak Company 2000 Omnibus Long-Term Compensation Plan (the &#147;Omnibus Plan&#148;).&#160; The options will vest 33 1/3% on each of the first three anniversaries of the date of grant.&#160; If your employment terminates for any reason, other than a &#147;Permitted Reason&#148; as determined by the CEO, during the one-year period following the date of grant, you will immediately forfeit all of the options.&#160; Thereafter, so long as the options remain unvested, the unvested portion will be subject to forfeiture in the event of your termination of employment for any reason other than for death or for &#147;Disability&#148; or an &#147;Approved Reason&#148; as those terms are defined under the terms of the Omnibus Plan.&#160;
The options will be granted for 7 years and have an exercise price equal to the mean between the high and low at which Eastman Kodak common stock trades on the New York Stock Exchange on the date of grant by the Compensation Committee.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The specific terms, conditions and restrictions of your stock option grant will be contained in an award notice delivered to you shortly after the commencement of your employment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Signing Bonus &#150; Restricted Stock Award</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Upon your employment, Kodak will also propose to the Compensation Committee that you be granted, as a signing bonus, a one-time grant under the Omnibus Plan of 10,000 shares of restricted Kodak Common Stock.&#160; One half of these shares, i.e., 5000 shares, will vest on the third anniversary of the date of their grant.&#160; The remaining 5,000 shares will vest on the fifth anniversary of the date of their grant.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">If your employment terminates for any reason, other than a &#147;Permitted Reason&#148; as determined by the CEO in the exercise of his sole discretion, during the one-year period following the date of the grant, you will immediately forfeit the shares.&#160; Thereafter, so long as these shares remain unvested, they will be subject to forfeiture in the event of your termination of employment for any reason other than for death or for &#147;Disability&#148; or an &#147;Approved Reason,&#148; as those terms are defined under the terms of the Omnibus Plan.</font></p>
<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 3 of 13</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">The specific terms, conditions and restrictions of your restricted stock grant will be contained in an award notice delivered to you shortly after the commencement of your employment.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Vacation</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will be entitled to 4 weeks&#146; vacation per calendar year.&#160; Your vacation for the current calendar year will be pro-rated based on your service in 2004.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Benefits</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will be eligible to immediately participate in Kodak&#146;s Flexible Benefits Plan, which includes health and dental coverage, long-term disability coverage, life insurance and eligibility for long-term care insurance.&#160; With regard specifically to life insurance coverage, Kodak annually contributes for each plan participant an amount sufficient to cover the cost of coverage equal to one times the participant&#146;s total target annual compensation (base salary plus target EXCEL award).&#160; You will also be eligible for coverage under Kodak&#146;s Short-Term Disability Plan.</font></p>

<p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will be eligible to participate in the 1982 Eastman Kodak Company Executive Deferred Compensation Plan (&#147;EDCP&#148;).&#160; This is a non-qualified/unfunded plan in which you may elect to defer a portion of your base salary and EXCEL award.&#160; A description of the plan is enclosed.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our executives also qualify for company-paid coverage of $5 million of personal umbrella liability insurance (&#147;PULI&#148;).</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Our executives are provided with individual financial counseling services through one of three companies.&#160; You will be immediately eligible for this benefit. </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You are also eligible to participate in the Kodak Executive Health Management plan.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Immediately upon your employment, you will also be eligible to participate in the Eastman Kodak Employees&#146; Savings and Investment Plan (&#147;SIP&#148;), Kodak&#146;s 401(k) plan.&#160; You will be eligible to make rollover deferrals from other qualified plans within two years from the date of your hire.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Retirement Benefits</b></font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>A.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Cash Balance Plan</b>.&#160;   Upon your employment, you will be eligible for the cash balance   benefit provided under the Kodak Retirement Income Plan (&#147;KRIP&#148;).&#160; This program is Kodak&#146;s retirement plan   for all employees hired on or after March 1, 1999.&#160; The enclosed brochure describes this program in more detail.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 4 of 13</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>

<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>B.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Enhanced Pension</b>.&#160;   In addition to the retirement benefits you are eligible for under the   cash balance benefit of KRIP, you will be eligible for an enhanced pension   benefit.&#160; Assuming you satisfy the conditions   of this letter agreement, including but not limited to Subsection (C) below,   and subject to the offset provisions contained Subsection (E) below, Kodak   will provide you a retirement income benefit (1) as if you were eligible to   participate in Kodak&#146;s retirement plans by virtue of being employed by Kodak   after December 31, 1995, but prior to March 1, 1999, and (2) based on one and   a half (1.5) additional years of deemed service for every actual full year of   service you earn under the terms of KRIP; subject, however, to a maximum of   20 years of deemed service.&#160; The names   of the specific retirement plans that you will be treated as if you were   eligible to participate in by virtue of being treated as employed
after   December 31, 1995, but prior to March 1, 1999, are KRIP, the Kodak Unfunded   Retirement Plan (&#147;KURIP&#148;) and the Kodak Excess Retirement Income Plan   (&#147;KERIP&#148;).&#160; These three plans insofar   as they apply to employees employed by Kodak after March 31, 1995, but prior   to March 1, 1999, will be collectively referred to as the &#147;Retirement   Plan.&#148;&#160; You should recognize, though,   that to the extent you earn the enhanced pension benefit to which you are   eligible under this Subsection (B), it will be paid to you pursuant to the   terms and conditions of this letter agreement, not under the Retirement   Plan.&#160; That is, you will not be   eligible to participate in the Retirement Plan by virtue of this Subsection   (B).</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p><font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">As explained in   Subsection (C) below, however, prior to being treated as if credited with any   deemed service under the Retirement Plan, you must complete at least 5 years   of actual service.&#160; Thus, upon   completion of these 5 years of service, you will have 12.5 years of service   in total, 5 years of actual service and 7.5 years of deemed service.&#160; After completing 12 years of service, you   will have 30 years in total, 12 years of actual service and 18 years of   deemed service.&#160; You will not receive   any deemed service for any partial years of actual service that you are   treated as having earned under the Retirement Plan.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Any service that is treated as if credited to you   under the Retirement Plan (whether actual or deemed) will only apply for   purposes of establishing under the Retirement Plan: (i) the total amount of   your &#147;Vesting Service&#148;; (ii) the total amount of your &#147;Accrued Service&#148; used   to calculate your retirement income benefit; and (iii) your &#147;Total Service&#148;   for purposes of determining the applicability of any early retirement   reduction factor.&#160; The crediting of   service applies solely for these purposes and is not intended to enhance any   other Kodak benefit or compensation.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p  align=right>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 5 of 13</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>
<table align="center"  border="0" style="border-collapse:collapse" cellspacing="0"  cellpadding="0"  width="100%">

 <tr>
  <td width="5%" valign="top">
  <p><font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>C.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td width="95%" valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Continuous Employment</b>.&#160;   In order to be eligible for the enhanced retirement benefit described   above, you must remain continuously employed with Kodak during the 5-year   period commencing on the date of the commencement of your employment.&#160; Except as provided in Subsection (D)   below, if your employment terminates for any reason, whether voluntarily or   involuntarily, prior to the fifth anniversary of the commencement of your   employment with Kodak, you will not be entitled to receive any of the   enhanced retirement benefits described above.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="1" face="Times New Roman">&nbsp;</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
 <tr>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>D</b>.</font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Severance Benefits</b>.&#160;   Notwithstanding Subsection (C) above, if Kodak terminates your   employment prior to the fifth anniversary of the commencement of your   employment and, as a result, you qualify for benefits under the section   entitled &#147;Severance Benefits&#148; below, you will, for purposes of Subsection (B)   above, receive your actual years of service and a pro rata portion of the   deemed service.&#160; The pro rata portion   will be determined by multiplying 7.5 years of deemed service by the   following fraction:</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Offset</b>.&#160; The amount of the   retirement income benefit or survivor benefit, if any, provided under   Subsection (B) will be offset by: (1) the retirement benefits payable to you   under the cash balance benefit of KRIP and any supplemental and successor   plan(s) thereto; (2) any company matching contribution made to your account   under the Eastman Kodak Employees&#146; Savings and Investment Plan (&#147;SIP&#148;) or any   supplement or successor plan(s) thereto; and (3) any other retirement benefit   provided to you pursuant to the retirement plan or program of any employer   with whom you were employed prior to Kodak.</font></p>  </td>

  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Payment</b>.&#160; The amount of the enhanced   retirement benefit, if any, payable to you under Subsection (B) will: (i) be   paid in the form of a monthly annuity commencing on the date(s) permitted   under the terms of the Retirement Plan; (ii) be paid out of Kodak&#146;s general   assets, not under KRIP; (iii) not be funded in any manner; (iv) be included   in your gross income as ordinary income, subject to all income and payroll   tax withholding required to be made under all applicable laws; and (v) not be   grossed up or be given any other special tax treatment by Kodak.</font></p>  </td>

  <p>

  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>G.</b></font></p>  </td>
  <td  valign="top">
  <p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Employee Benefit Plan</b>.&#160;   To the extent the terms of this enhanced retirement benefit constitute   an &#147;employee benefit plan&#148; under Section 3(3) of the Employee Retirement   Income Security Act of 1974 (&#147;ERISA&#148;), the Vice President, Eastman Kodak   Company and Director, Human Resources will be the plan administrator of the   plan.&#160; The plan administrator will   have total and exclusive responsibility to control, operate, manage and   administer the plan in accordance with its terms and all the authority that   may be necessary or helpful to enable him/her to discharge his/her   responsibilities with respect to the plan.&#160;   Without limiting the generality of the preceding sentence, the plan   administrator shall have the exclusive right to: interpret the plan, decide   all questions concerning eligibility for and the amount of benefits payable   under the plan, construe any ambiguous provision of the plan, correct any
default, supply any omission, reconcile any inconsistency, and decide all   questions arising in the administration, interpretation and application of   the plan.&#160; The plan administrator will   have full discretionary authority in all matters related to the discharge of   his/her responsibilities and the exercise of his/her authority under the   plan, including, without limitation, his/her construction of the terms of the   plan and his/her determination of eligibility for benefits under the   plan.&#160; It is the intent of the plan,   as well as both parties hereto, that the decisions of the plan administrator   and his/her action with respect to the plan shall be final and binding upon   all persons having or claiming to have any right or interest in or under the   plan and that no such decision or actions shall be modified upon judicial   review unless such decision or action is proven to be arbitrary or capricious.</font></p>  </td>
 </tr>
</table>

<p  align=right><font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Page 7 of 13</font></p>

<div style="page-break-before:always"></div>
<PAGE>
<br>

<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">Mr. Philip Faraci<br> November 3, 2004</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Relocation</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">You will be eligible to participate in the Company&#146;s Enhanced New Hire Relocation Program (the &#147;Relocation Program&#148;).&#160; Enclosed is a summary of this Program.&#160; One of the features of the Program is a Mortgage Interest Subsidy (&#147;MIS&#148;) whereby Kodak will protect you for two (2) years if your new first mortgage interest rate is more than 1.1% higher than the rate on your existing first mortgage.&#160; The Mortgage Interest Subsidy will be calculated based on the difference, if any, between (x) the rate of interest on your new first mortgage, and (y) the rate on your existing first mortgage plus one percent.&#160; MIS is paid annually in the form of a lump sum payment subject to all applicable income and payroll tax withholdings.&#160; </font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Temporary Housing</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">To assist you in finding a permanent residence in the Rochester, NY area, Kodak agrees to reimburse you for your temporary housing expenses.&#160; More specifically, for up to a nine-month period commencing on your first day of employment, Kodak agrees to reimburse you for your temporary housing expenses up to a maximum dollar amount of $2,500 per month.&#160; These expenses must be incurred for temporary housing in the Rochester, NY area.&#160; Proper documentation of these expenses will be required in accordance with the terms of Kodak&#146;s relocation program.&#160; To the extent you are subject to Federal or state income tax on these expense reimbursements, Kodak will &#147;gross-up&#148; the reimbursements so that after such taxes are incurred by you, you shall receive a net payment equal to the amount of the expense.&#160; The amount of any such &#147;gross-up&#148; will not be included in the calculation of the $2,500 per month limit.</font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman"><b>Air Travel</b></font></p>
<p>
<font size="2" face="Times New Roman">After the commencement of your employment, Kodak agrees to reimburse you for the air travel expenses you incur in traveling back and forth between Rochester, NY and Oregon until such time as you relocate to Rochester.&#160; In order to be eligible for reimbursement, the air travel must be coach class, not exceed in the aggregate $15,000 and be incurred prior to the earlier of the date of your relocation to Rochester or the nine month anniversary of the date of your commencement of employment.&#160; Proper documentation of these expenses will be required in accordance with the terms of Kodak&#146;s relocation program.&#160; To the extent you are subject to Federal or state income tax on these expense reimbursements, Kodak will &#147;gross-up&#148; the reimbursements so that after such taxes are incurred by you, you shall receive a net payment equal to the amount of the expense.&#160; The amount of any such &#147;gross-up&#148; will not be included in the
calculation of the $15,000 limit.</font></p>
